movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's a feast here, particularly in the amazing opening, an unexpected essay on King Kong, and performances by Pitt, Laurent, and Waltz. It's just been placed on a huge table with no consideration of whether it adds up to a meal.
Funny ideas bubble up from time to time only to disappear into a morass of stripper jokes and desperation.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Julie & Julia is two movies in one. That's one more movie than it needs to be.
Every beat of Yi's manufactured crisis of faith feels as pre-programmed in its own way as a Michael Bay movie.
Its turgid pace creates a queasy fascination all its own, drawing viewers into an ever-darkening locus of sin and obsession where even the wish for redemption comes at a terrible cost.
It's refreshingly unformulaic, but a rambling mess. It's also tremendously funny.
A mercilessly funny film that, beneath the laughs, chillingly falls on the believable side of how politics really gets done.
This has been a good decade for movies about New York vampires.
If director Jaume Collet-Serra set out to make a parody of horror-film clichés, he succeeded brilliantly.

When a film whose cast includes Michael Keaton, Jane Lynch, Fred Armisen, Craig Robinson, Demetri Martin, and the now rarely seen Carol Burnett can't scare up more than a smattering of laughs, the patient was never meant to live in the first place.
It seems to be targeted at eight-year-old boys with attention-deficit disorder, and could have been more competently made by any one of them.

Shot with dry discipline in striking black and white, the deliberately paced, consistently unnerving film invites viewers into every corner of its town, from its stately manor to its humblest abode, finding in each an air of unease and discontentment.
The holiday spirit feels real, but the film does not.
It all goes awry in the end, but for a good stretch, Chloe neatly fixes Egoyan's career-long obsessions with identity and communication to the familiar framework of the erotic thriller.
It's a time-waster with brains, but ultimately not enough brains, and one that wastes too much time.
Too much of Public Enemies feels disappointingly smaller than life.
Demme's excitement for Young and his music is evident throughout, and the songs fit comfortably in the unvarnished setting.
Gone: the liquid reality of dreams and a sense that anything can happen. In its place: another story of quests, destinies, and chosen ones.
It's nice to see a film unafraid to be quiet and sensitive, but one good gust of coastal breeze would blow this one away.
Without the rotting ickiness of proper zombies, they just seem like methed-out Iowans looking for a fix. That's scary, but not scary enough.
A few stray livers and severed heads aside, this is a monster too polite for its own good.

Reduced to bare description, its desperate dames and crooked cops resemble the stuff of Noir 101, but the series owes more to the moral murk of James Ellroy's L.A. and the civic spiderweb of The Wire than conventional thrillers.

The film treats the responsibilities of parenthood like another film would treat cancer, as a dream-killing condition to be endured until it passes or kills you. As a contraceptive device, that works brilliantly.
Rhodes doesn't find much more for them to do than flit from one quirk-filled vignette to the next.
The Spierigs get a lot of points for inventiveness, but their cleverly constructed, uncomfortably familiar world makes a deeper impression than much of what happens within it.
It's a highly entertaining example of the form, directed with just the right amount of panache by Guy Ritchie, whose showmanship finally finds the right side of self-indulgence.
Fellini provides a tough point of comparison for anyone, but maybe Nine should have stayed on the stage, where it could benefit from having a medium all to itself.

Director Jean-Marc Vallée bathes the frames in the details of its luxurious surroundings, and the screenplay, by Gosford Park writer Julian Fellowes, does a passable job of laying out all the factions jockeying for power around Blunt's Victoria.
Clint Eastwood brings his usual late-career leisureliness behind the camera to the movie, in an initially frustrating approach that becomes increasingly satisfying as the film moves along.
Jason Reitman's direction nicely translates the seductive appeal of sterile public places while letting the assured performances do much of the work.
Largely forgetting the kids as it subjects its stars to one humiliation after another, Old Dogs doesn't even have the courage to commit to its familiar but serviceable premise.

Broken Embraces welds Douglas Sirk melodrama to the most gracefully unsettling elements of Alfred Hitchcock, wrapping both in the stylish, hushed elegance that's become Almodóvar's trademark since his mid-'90s reinvention.

Independence Day began a game of landmark-destroying one-upmanship. Here, Emmerich takes the competition global, but the soundtrack's organ-rattling low-end makes a deeper impact than the film's visuals.
Edge Of Darkness quickly devolves into another showcase for Gibson's snorting-bull act, a routine he could happily have shelved during his time off.
Following 27 Dresses, this is the second high-concept, low-impact, wedding-themed comedy in 18 months for choreographer-turned-director Anne Fletcher. It might be time to move on.
In both halves, Soderbergh emphasizes observation over ideology with an eye toward the mundane details of life on the front lines of a revolution.
It's a film about forgetting that seems designed to be forgotten.
It almost goes without saying that the film looks gorgeous, but the filmmaking behind it feels unsure how to work on this grand a scale. Australia is big. But it never fills the screen.
Quantum is content merely to be the second episode in what's shaping up to be a viable series, good enough but disappointing for those expecting greatness.
It's a sweetly queasy film that suggests the spirit that sustains us, the demons we hide from the world, and the monsters that prey upon us in the dark might all be variations on the same beast.
It's a horror film better suited for skittish cats than humans.
Where much of Changeling works at once as a compelling mystery and an agonizing human drama, it starts to drift in a series of final scenes that finish the story while losing all sense of urgency.
Provides a fascinating glimpse down a path perhaps advisedly not taken.
It's solid filmmaking that, bafflingly, leaves little to talk about on the way home.
For kids who like dogs and grown-ups who don't mind a movie filled with pro-adopt-a-shelter-dog messages, it could theoretically be worse.
Maher's too smart to make a movie this dumb.

Adopting the once-over-the-most-famous-moments-lightly approach favored by the sort of movies and retrospectives that VH1 Classic airs on a loop, Cadillac Records plays more like a collection of costumed episodes than a cohesive film.
The film drags as it reaches the hours before sunrise, but Cera and Denning's passive-aggressive flirtation keeps its pulse alive.
The original was a tart dipped in acid; this one's a biscuit sprinkled in Splenda.
The novelty of watching De Niro and Pacino team up wears off pretty quickly.
Even if it never finds an audience outside L.A., someone ought to write a book called When Dull Films Happen To Clever Production Designers.
It's the perfect end-of-summer film, and a sign that summer needs to end soon.
A witless reprise of '60s and '70s biker movies written, directed by, and starring Larry Bishop.
As an acting showcase that builds to some unexpectedly moving moments, Elegy has much to recommend it.
The film ends by closing the door on future sequels, which is probably fine. Everyone here looks like they've learned their lesson and can now move on.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: How To Train Your Dragon retains a dash of the modern, winking attitude that's served as the not-always-welcome trademark of DreamWorks Animation, but its emphasis falls squarely on heartfelt storytelling and sumptuous images.

Where Batman Begins was largely about the considerable personal toll exacted by its hero's decision to fight back against the forces of evil while adhering to a code of honor, The Dark Knight expands those weighty themes to city scale.
Burn's land of the perpetually deluded works as an amusing place to visit, but an even better place to flee.

It doesn't help that neither Ferrell nor McBride bring their best material, with McBride offering yet another variation on an angry redneck, and Ferrell falling back on Ron Burgundy-like bluster and nonsense exclamations.
It's a joyless plunge into gunfire that doesn't even know how to draw blood.
Director Peyton Reed keeps the movie handsome, but there's little of the style he brought to the overlooked Down With Love or even the dire-but-distinctive The Break-Up.
Here's a great way to start savoring life: Don't waste it on pat manipulations like this.
As long as McG keeps the action moving, the film remains on solid ground, matching and often surpassing the thoroughly adequate 2003 entry Terminator 3: Rise Of The Machines.
Johnson sets viewers up for greatness, but ultimately offers much milder pleasures.
It boldly goes somewhere different and makes it hard to leave the film not hoping for a return voyage soon.

It provides just enough information to invite further study without going into much detail. It's an intriguing film about what goes on beneath the surface of the objects we take for granted, but one that never digs as deep as it should.
A couple of halfway decent action scenes do little to distract from the story's mounting ludicrousness, or a conclusion that's only a little more satisfying than a projector breakdown. Maybe.
Only Sarsgaard shows a pulse, creating a self-destructive, omnisexual rogue who, for all his faults, would probably be great company. The same can't be said for the film around him.
There's no shortage of either the originals or imitators, so why make Alien Trespass, a send-up of second-shelf '50s sci-fi so straight-faced, it could almost pass as the real thing?
A handsomely mounted but achingly undistinguished film from writer-director Christophe Barratier.

Eastwood directs with his usual relaxed pace and bursts of intensity, a style that's pleasing to watch -- and which, also as usual, never fully compensates for any shortcomings of the script handed to him.
A franchise that started as a corrective for distressing action-movie trends becomes what it started out hating. Time for something new.

Proyas remains a skilled director of mood and spectacle, but a striking look and a handful of remarkable setpieces -- look out for that plane -- can't elevate what's ultimately a silly movie with a queasy subtext.

Watchmen deserves credit for staying true to the characters, plot (up to a point), and look of the original material while still generating his own kind of energy, even though that energy sometimes feels misapplied and overcranked.
The particulars of the story, Gray's moody compositions and feel for the neighborhood, and especially the performances rescue Two Lovers from the obvious.

It's hard to imagine any sort of alchemy transforming the script's parade of Star Wars references and tired nostalgic '90s signifiers into gold, or -- this many years after Jar Jar Binks -- make their passion seem anything but sadly misplaced.
The Pink Panther 2 plays like an undeserved victory lap for a series that only limped to the finish line the last time.
There's no disguising fluff this fluffy.
What darkness the movie achieves comes solely from the lighting.
It's keenly observed, handsomely mounted, supremely well-acted, and distant in a way the period trappings can't quite explain away.
Fincher's visual mastery and Pitt's charisma almost compensate for a gimmick in search of a meaning. The more time Fincher gives viewers with Button, the thinner the character grows.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a piece of storytelling, The Haunting In Connecticut is pretty lazy. As a horror movie, it's lazier still, bringing out every annoying shock-cut and disorienting sound-design trick of the last decade.
It's a trifle, but a trifle that sticks.
Even Big Momma deserves better than this.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film about wannabes who use attitude and bluster to emulate their inspirations, this ersatz blockbuster ends up seeming a little too much like its heroes.
The tone and subject at times recall David Lynch's Lost Highway and Mulholland Dr., but the approach is Hellman's own.
Its pleasures are borrowed, but durable.
Entertaining enough, but unmistakably the work of a later, lesser era.
Even those with giant soft spots for beautiful catastrophes will be hard-pressed to find anything to like in Passion Play.
It's a film about teen angst that's too caught up in its characters' state of mind to see its way through to the other side.
It's a film with its own identity, the simple, thrilling story of a handsome god who falls to Earth and reminds everyone what heroes do.
Lets the likeable erstwhile Superman do his best impression of a jaded P.I., down to one of the most ineffectually boyish attempts at a grizzled voiceover in memory.

Kids have seen much better animation in other films, and it's hard to imagine too many grown-ups ready to smile and nod at yet more smirking takes on famous moments from Scarface and The Silence Of The Lambs.
Winkler directs with a borrowed sense of assurance.
In spite of the film's serious subtext, it's unmistakably a romantic comedy, and Leclerc keeps a light touch throughout.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Brand can be funny in supporting parts. But he doesn't yet know how to command a front-and-center role, and Arthur groans with the effort from its first moments...
Anyone bewailing the near-absence of tacky family films inspired by Easter need bewail no more: Hop has arrived to fill the void.
Frammartino uses long, carefully observed takes to capture the natural world and the way the same patterns keep erupting from beneath humanity's attempts to impose order upon it.

Ultimately, the film's slow-building, eventually overwhelming emotional pull gives Certified Copy its shape and pace.
An entertaining, accomplished movie that shows off what its signature technology can do...
It's like The Matrix, as remade by the Hallmark Channel.
Though the film never balances the grown-up stuff with the gross-out gags, it suggests the Farrellys might be able to do mature after all.
It's more Thompson-for-beginners than an exhaustive inquiry, but as introductions go, it's thorough and thoughtful.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Grau effectively mixes wry, bloody, deadpan gags, family drama, and stomach-churning violence.

It's Jones' restrained direction that keeps Source Code moving, and confirms him as the rare filmmaker able, or maybe just choosing, to understand that even movies with explosions don't have to be dumb to entertain.

Mostly, Just Go With It offers scenes of Aniston and Sandler deceiving Decker, whose inability to see through fabrications that wouldn't fool a canny toddler suggest she might be suffering from some kind of undiagnosed neurological disease.
It's as if Hanks and co-writer Nia Vardalos assumed that getting everyone in one place would be enough, and didn't think much further.

You want cowboys and aliens in the same movie? This one's for you. If you want anything beyond what the title promises, look elsewhere. And that means even anything resembling a clever mash-up of established genres.
It's as dull as it is brainless, the work of creators who've spent far more time concocting silly stories about Shakespeare than learning from him.

This version of the Musketeers story can't decide if it wants to be an old-fashioned tale of swashbuckling adventure and palace intrigue or a cheeky, effects-heavy rethink of some iconic characters a la the Guy Ritchie-directed Sherlock Holmes.
Formulas work if you know how to work them, but writer-director Tim Chambers, making his theatrical debut, only gets the beats right part of the time.

Sanchez and Myrick's film knows that what's not seen frightens more easily that what is, and that the imagination's thoughts of what might have happened generally horrify on a deeper level than knowing what did.

Operating under the principle that a moving camera is always better than a static one, and not above throwing in a terrifying evil doll, Deep Red showcases the technical bravado and loopy shock tactics that made Argento famous.

We get to know the detectives at the film's core, how they work, what drives them, and the place they're sworn to protect. And then the film ends after telling only one story, which seems kind of odd these days.
Owen Wilson and Jack Black appear on the verge of succumbing to the same terminal blandness that's gripped Martin for so long.
Directors Chris Metzler and Lev Anderson seem to have considered several different approaches for their film and settled on all of them.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The first Human Centipede had audacity on its side. Human Centipede II has only excess.

As a study in insanity, Zookeeper is mildly interesting. But as a kiddie comedy, it's something to watch only once the little ones have worn out their Dr. Doolittle DVD (maybe even their Dr. Doolittle 2 DVD, for that matter).

Despite a wrenching opening that saddles Paquin's character with more guilt than most anyone could bear, much less a less-than-steady-on-her-feet teen, the film lets some great performances and compelling moments drift in a sea of shapelessness.
Somehow, Van Sant has made a film about life and death in which the stakes never seem higher than whether one insolent kid will stop being such a horrible mope.
Soderbergh places a queasy emphasis on the way the things that make the world we live in smaller make us that much more vulnerable.
Make no mistake, Apollo 18 is a *terrible* movie.
While the new Brighton Rock makes a great case for Brighton being a fine setting for a grim crime drama, it only intermittently looks like the sort of film that setting deserves.
The film's greatest pleasures come from Noxon's script -- which puts the sexual chaos created by Farrell's attractive bloodsucker front and center -- and from the performances.
[Momoa] barks and growls his dialogue with the unpracticed enthusiasm of a first-time Ren Fair performer.
It is, without a doubt, a striking debut. But it's also punishingly distasteful and disjointed almost beyond coherence, a repetitive heap of a film that feels disgorged rather than crafted.
Wyatt ... keeps the action compelling whether focusing on apes as they run amok or as they quietly contemplate their next move.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though Cheadle is good as a man pushed to his breaking point at every moment, the movie belongs to Gleeson, who keeps his character enigmatic even while engaging in every possible act of slovenly excess and gross negligence.
A rote revenge thriller attempting to shoulder more philosophical weight than it can bear.
Leterrier aims no higher than competence and achieves just that, shepherding a series of slick, CGI creations across the screen to the accompaniment of an organ-rattling sound design.
Though Levy's film feels shapeless at times, what it loses in structure, it gains in handheld intimacy, letting viewers get to know the mercurial but fundamentally sweet Pleskun.
No Strings Attached isn't a bad piece of formulaic product. Until its endless final act, Elizabeth Meriwether's script and Ivan Reitman's old-hand direction keep the scenes moving briskly...
It's a postcard-lovely movie that, in spite of its best intentions, ends up feeling a little touristy.
Noyce's past excursions into action filmmaking, most notably the Harrison Ford-as-Jack Ryan films, have been a bit flavorless, but here he delivers one from the gut.

There's nothing really wrong with it. But there's nothing amazingly right about it either, unless, of course, it sends young viewers marching off to libraries to find the real Klickitat Street for themselves.
In retrospect, Todd Solondz probably should have hung it up after Happiness.
Thankfully, the story -- and especially Clouzot's existing footage -- is fascinating enough to transcend the treatment.
An intimate, funny, occasionally upsetting depiction of a loving family that is, like so many families, often only just functional.
The film moves at a chug when it should put the pedal to the floor.
As bad as you've heard. Actually, it's worse.
Where to start with this one? How about this: If any movie ever warranted a class-action lawsuit against the filmmakers, it's The Last Airbender.

Stone's film, more an act of boosterism than inquiry, is a tremendous missed opportunity.

Ondine looks heavy and it ends up feeling a little slight, but between those two extremes there's a beguiling siren song of a movie about the way the unexpected has a way of intruding on even the most fatalistic lives.
Kids love dogs and fart jokes. The goods are being delivered to the target audience. All others should look away.
If well done, a film like Letters To Juliet should need no surprises. But it does need more than the postcard-ready vistas against which director Gary Winick frames much of the action.
A film that, in bare description, sounds like the greatest outrage ever put to screen, but ends up being fairly tedious when watched.

While Scott is one of the few directors who could field-marshal this sort of spectacle and still deliver a coherent film, simply ending up with a fitfully engaging behemoth of a movie isn't accomplishment enough.
It would feel overly theatrical if Watts, Bening, and Washington didn't convey the vulnerability beneath every firm demurral, lacerating insult, and refusal to engage.
The film cops virtually every memorable image from the original, but loses the depth that gave them power and the sense of place that grounded them.
Every once in a while, a film limps into theaters so stitched together, it's a wonder it doesn't rip apart in the projector. Jonah Hex is such a film.
You know what isn't terrifying? Mules. Also not terrifying: mules with red eyes and baleful expressions.
While Daniel Stamm doesn't reinvent the form with the low-budget pseudo-doc The Last Exorcism, he exploits it well.
Easy A has two strong elements in its favor: heart, and Stone's terrific lead performance.
It's a strange, shapeless, rarely satisfying, but generally amiable movie in which everyone appears to be faking it as they go along, and almost -- almost -- getting away with it.

Feste captures the heightened reality of performing before a massive crowd, when audience expectations and JumboTron screens can blow delicate emotions up to monstrous proportions. The problem is everything else.

Somewhere has strong echoes of Lost In Translation in particular, from the luxury hotels to an encounter with another country's bizarre television, but the style breaks rewardingly with what she's done before.
The Coens direct True Grit with a light touch, but like Portis' stark, funny novel, their adventure tale shaves off none of the rough edges. It's simultaneously rollicking and grave.

Rabbit Hole is a tremendously sad movie, but it's also the furthest thing from a miserablist wallow, portraying grief as something that doesn't arrive in neat stages, but in unpredictable waves with forceful undercurrents.
Taymor seems to have assembled an interesting cast and colorful costumes and chosen a fitting locale-some scenic, forbidding corners of Hawaii-and hoped for the best. Occasionally she gets it.
Black Swan is a florid, often lurid, completely enthralling film held in place by a disarming Portman, who rarely leaves the frame.
It's as fun as it sounds, but only up to a point.
The women look like ordinary people pushed too far. They also look like they have far more interesting stories to tell than those found in the rest of the film.

The film is all over the place, really, until the plot kicks in, at which point Zhang hits the dimmer and plunges everyone into darkness, even a pair of characters seemingly on hand purely for comic relief.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At a mere 88 minutes, it feels a bit glancing. But as an introduction or refresher course, it gets the job done.
movie_title: William S. Burroughs: A Man Within (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's no right way to do an adaptation, particularly a difficult-to-adapt work like this, but there are plenty of wrong ways, and Perry's film offers a casebook of things-not-to-do.
It's good, theoretically at least, to have Craven back. But why come back for this?
There's adversity, triumph, and lessons learned on the way to a happy ending. And upbeat scenes set to stirring, era-appropriate songs? Do you even have to ask?
Pity any poor kid stuck in a house like that. Pity, too, anyone who has to stop by for a visit.
Nowhere Boy is modest in scope and more rewarding for it, highlighted by particularly strong performances by Thomas and Johnson, and a keen sense of time and place.

The Social Network sometimes relegates the actual effects of Facebook to passing lines of dialogue and offhand references. But there's plenty to explore in its causes, and Zuckerberg's story ends up feeling bigger than his own life.
Even the best performers can only do so much to elevate mediocre material.
Happily, Ginsberg's words still cut recklessly through the years.

The first time around, Wall Street felt like a warning about the perils of excess just as excess started to exact its toll. This one's little more than a reminder that we all got, and remain, screwed. Noted.
Directing with more focus -- and eventually, more heart -- than he brought to The Hangover, Todd Phillips smartly lets his leads' chemistry power the movie.
It's comedy that doesn't ask anyone, onscreen or in the audience, to try too hard.
Though contrived and artificial in ways that don't always work, the film is also heartfelt and made with genuine affection for its characters, qualities in too short a supply to dismiss.
[Director] Brooks plunges into the thick of a largely unfamiliar subculture in Quid Pro Quo, but the journey involves a series of well-telegraphed twists and turns.
Its star's interpretation of teenage manhood for some reason involves talking like an effeminate Alabaman.

Only when the script and visuals stray too far from the source does the film lose its way, getting bogged down in the mechanics of big-budget action filmmaking and ponderous dialogue as it works toward a way-too-tidy, sentimental finale.
The approach is dry as the Wyoming landscape, and while it occasionally threatens to pull the film out of shape, it's still the right one for these men.
Despite a shaky start and the presence of questionable elements throughout, by the time it arrives at its finale The Phantom Menace has won its place alongside the original Star Wars trilogy.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Everyone looks like they're struggling to appear human, and only one has a huge, fishy tail as an excuse.
A wet teabag of a movie.

A prime example of how a historical drama can be politically correct but thoroughly embalmed. The memory of Patrice Lumumba deserves better.

Best of all, nobody, including actors Show Aikawa and rock star Riki Takeuchi as the cop and the criminal, takes the flick very seriously. So neither should you.
It's a schoolboy ghost story, the kind best told after lights-out.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Based on this film's honest, meat-and-potatoes appeal, it would be a treat to see more of Pontecorvo's rare filmography. In the meantime, careful with that dynamite.
movie_title: The Wide Blue Road (La Grande strada azzurra) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The film bristles with dramatic and prurient possibilities, only about ten percent of which are realized.
Sort of a Dilbert riff, only lower on the food chain.
Don't be put off by the bitchy-familiar chick-flick wrapper. This one's a keeper.
Director/co-writer Kim certainly enjoys ransacking genres. We're holding out for his remake of Gone with the Wind.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A deceptively slender documentary that opens up enormous questions about guilt, forgiveness, and moral responsibility. It will stay with you.

All the while, in newsreel footage, Pinochet struts around pompously in his absurd, operatic uniform, keeping Chile safe. For whom?

For all its transparent outrageousness, filmmaker Kurys' tribute to those free spirits is an entertainment for squares.
movie_title: Les enfants du siècle (The Children of the Century) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: She has a British accent and gets part of the giant female organ implanted in her tummy. This movie is so terrible it's terrific.
For many admirers In a Lonely Place is the ultimate inside-Hollywood sour-grape ball, eclipsing even Sunset Boulevard.
This 1954 Freudian Western is one of the all-time left-field wonders of the studio system, a film so subversive it's a wonder it ever got made.
The epitome of a social problem film, in which the "crisis of conformism" bursts open in every single tension-producing frame.
Like a Mike Leigh film on steroids, situations don't dawn slowly on these characters, they come crashing down on their heads.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably Chabrol and Huppert's finest joint effort, it matches Huppert with Sandrine Bonnaire as a disgruntled postal clerk and sinister housekeeper.
What few ironies there are, are overpowered by the firm, calm, institutionalized oppression imposed on the women of Panahi's country.
Predictable? Maybe, but for artists like these the motivation is always more important than the act itself.
The French, as is widely known, adore suffering. That's why they love Leonard Cohen, Bud Powell, and Jim Thompson.
Anybody can wear a dragon tattoo, play with fire, or kick a hornet's nest, but there's only one Noomi Rapace.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Could very well be the pilot for a new Comedy Central series about the antics of a pair of zany lesbian mothers trying to raise their teenagers. Well, yes and no.
Lance Daly's Ireland is not the scenic Irish wonderland of Ondine.
The germ of Steinbauer's apparently harmless, seemingly brainless doc goes right to the heart of the community-building aspect of the internet.
There's too much Scorsese-izing, and all the characters with the exception of Wilson and Ramsey's illicit lovers look as if they were drawn by a fifteen-year-old.
The characters march around in a circle and we learn one important thing: Stay away from hotels and restaurants in Florida.
Takes a deep look at an everyday tragedy and provides the humorous dimension that underscores the pathos. Who says Bollywood is only interested in lightweight romantic musicals?
To win her, he needs to duel her ex-boyfriends in fantasy sequences based on video games. Oh, great.
She's needy, he's mean, they gradually get on each others' nerves. And we get to watch. Filmmaker Ade is a talent to keep an eye on.
Despite the bloodthirstiness of the Christian mob there's a surprising lack of dramatic tension.
It's not often we get to see a true Russian farce.
Earnest entry in the "fear documentary" category promotes nuclear disarmament after shocking us with statistics.
Stack this one up beside Tender Mercies, Sling Blade, and The Apostle in Duvall's remarkable scrapbook of countrified eccentrics.
Not funny "ha-ha" but funny "huh?"
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: No one in Bucharest gives a damn about anything. And he takes 113 long, drawn-out minutes to send this bit of news.
Director James Mangold amps up the blood and thunder without sacrificing the moral complexity of Elmore Leonard's original short story.
The cast turns utter naturalism into a raging zoo of survivalism, with brilliant little scenes scattered like spilled cereal throughout the screenplay.

movie_review_blurb: The only thing missing from this gothic-romance version of Ben Sherwood's novel is a choir of angels.

Air Doll wears that compassion on its sleeve a little too earnestly and humorlessly. Even an airhead could see that.
As a romantic comedy, Cyrus ranks just ahead of Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer.
When you wake up after napping through this earnest timewaster, you'll feel relieved, but you won't know why. Here's a clue: Gracie can't bend it.
The most resonant moments in Paris, Je T'Aime happen to be the bleakest, and they're about immigrants and other outsiders.
A sorrowful and beautiful film, the kind you never see from mainstream Tinseltown studios, then or now.

Doesn't exactly oust The Royal Tenenbaums or The Squid and the Whale, but this family-go-round sitcom is a lot more accessible.

Shares a gentle, observant tone with the early films of Ken Loach.
Such a visual grabber, with so much unexpected food for thought, that it's hard to see how it could be topped.
On the sweet side of bittersweet, but will not rot your teeth.
Embarrassingly stupid costumed adventure has sand in its gears and fleas in its screenplay.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Jordan is a master of such chimerical narratives.
One way to salvage some fun with this blunderbuss would be to fall asleep while watching and dream up a better movie yourself. Try it. You'll avoid a headache.
Chalk up this provocative doc as the type of project only an Oliver Stone could swing: a contrarian report that dares to air points of view that routinely go missing from mainstream news in the US.
Restrepo deserves some highlighting as one of the very few films from our current "war years" that resonates after the lights go up.
Fast and violent, with feral demon kids and a surplus of imaginative restatements of the genre's best-loved clichés.
Winterbottom frequently cuts away to period rockabilly and country jukebox tunes, as if he were shying away from Thompson's nastiness. And maybe he should.

Typical of Ptushko's work, it mixes gothic horror, from a short story by Nikolai Gogol, and grotesque animated effects in a proletarian automatic blender.
Presents a fairy-tale Eastern Europe glimpsed from far off through the telescope of melancholy nostalgia.

All the midnight bulimic binges, suicide attempts, sleepwalking, marital chicanery, and little pills don't mean a thing compared to the thrill of being a middle-aged woman sneaking through the bedroom window like a teenager in heat.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Nobody plays the guilty corporate insider better than Clooney. Let him through. He's got a titanium ticket.
Englishman Christian McKay walks off with the Orson Welles impersonation prize, and he'll be difficult to top. No telling how many times he's watched Citizen Kane.
Let's not all pile on at once, but Nine is really one of the worst films of 2009, a truly hideously ill-conceived piece of work.
We have to go all the way back to Junior Brown, the psychopathic strip club owner in Kiss of Death (1994), to find a meatier heavy in Cage's filmography.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Holmes is primarily about a very small handful of things: men's fashions, Victorian clutter, fistfights and explosions, and "period detail," London at its soot-blackened, Industrial Age grimiest, foul with spilled gin and rotting meat.
Three centuries before Avatar, in a faraway world called Coffee Table Film, there dwelt a beautiful princess who became a powerful ruler, The Young Victoria.
Instead of popcorn and soda, the concession stands ought to serve broken twigs and muddy water with this one.
More sub-Sirk-ian soap from Pedro Almodóvar, who was once a must-see filmmaker.
Where are Billy Crystal and the rest of City Slickers gang when we need them?
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like the Three Stooges, McHale's Navy, and the Brides of Funkenstein, the Chipmunks are a true pop-cultural sleeper sensation.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Written and directed by Nancy Meyers, whose bubbly chick flicks have set a dubious but successful standard in lightweight rom-com fare (Private Benjamin, Baby Boom, etc.) about women getting into the kind of trouble most women can only dream about.
The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus is a patented Terry Gilliam special, a remedial children's bedtime tale for anxious grown-ups.

Actor Amy Adams is in serious danger of overexposure, so it's a pleasure to report that her latest vehicle delays that inevitability by playing directly to Ms. Adams' strengths and letting her weaknesses run free like an Irish pig.
By the time the big battle rolls around in the last quarter we've had enough of Pandora and the Na'Vi and Avatar, and are ready to take another five-year vacation from James Cameron.
Architectural photographer Julius Shulman was a pivotal figure in US popular culture. He's the one who taught Americans to love modernism.
movie_title: Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Art School Confidential goes for its doctorate in Jonathan Parker's bitchy, hilarious (Untitled), the story of two pretentious brothers jealously jousting with each other in the dog-eat-dog world of fine-art cred.
Whatever George Clooney and his friends are smoking, could they please pass some of it around? We're confused and we need it.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dull world after all.

Others may try, but no one can top Guillermo Arriaga for constructing grandiose watchtowers of pretentious pathos, crisscrossed by a melancholy emotional circuitry that nevertheless reassures us that, yes, we are all interconnected, if only in our despair

Next month someone will put out a brand-new gross-out Guy Flick that erases I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell's last shred of relevance. But you and I won't see it. And Tucker Max will finally become a corporate attorney for small-arms manufacturers.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of a nail-biter like The Insider or the pathetic tale of a corporate hit-and-run victim, such as Flash of Genius, Mark's big-business shenanigans simply peter out anticlimactically over the course of six or seven years, and that's that.
Judge probably wrote Extract on the back of a pizza box, but it's funnier and truer to life as it is actually lived than anything Judd Apatow ever did.
Kore-eda's scenarios have always tended toward quiet yet troubling contemplation, but Still Walking is probably his most subdued yet, with unmistakable echoes of the great Yasujiro Ozu.

The Baader Meinhof Complex arrives as a useful tool, a history lesson in a box, on a moment in time when actual revolution seemed not only possible but in some cases likely, in parts of Western Europe and the United States.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Generally a barrel of cheap fun.
The movie lives up to its hype in its first five minutes and builds from there. It's the Awful Truth in big, bold letters.
Screenwriter Siegel, directing his first film, lavishes as much attention on forty-year-old virgin Paul as he did on "Randy the Ram" in The Wrestler.
Who would have thought that Chris Rock would make one of the best documentaries of 2009?
It's not very Hornby, but it's not bad. In fact, we could go so far as to say that An Education is one of the smarter entertainments of the season.
This wretched mishmash of clichés and lazy scene-setting is as distressing for its lack of curiosity as for its smothering sweetness. It's a criminal waste of time.
Von Trier's personal demons are thrillingly cinematic, but they're his, not necessarily ours.
Bronson just keeps coming, straight ahead, like a bull charging through the slaughterhouse door.
For a story so bald on narrative incident, The Canyon is sweaty-palms scary.
In the same way as with the Elephant Man or an Angkor Wat idol, we're fascinated with Precious' face. It's inert and monolithic, almost unknowable.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

Christian Berger's black-and-white cinematography is as gorgeously rich as writer-director Haneke's screenplay is forbiddingly austere.
A much-needed antidote to the twin curses of production bloat and imagination starvation.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

Too much eeyaahhh and probably not enough kiss-kiss meow-meow.

Superlative Australian neo-noir has everything you'd ever need for a delightfully dismal tale of deceit and murder.

Fascinating documentary, as far as it goes.
Director Borte doesn't press the dumb-laugh button hard enough.
Lowriders, alcoholism, interracial romance, gang bullies, gay hysteria. The list goes on and on. So does the movie.
Loads of violent fun, not to be taken seriously.

French Cancan is full of fire, and incredibly sexy for 1954.
In the spirit of the best nostalgic village pics, only one thing happens, and yet it turns out to mean everything to its characters.

Welcome once again to the Ministry of Fear.
It's Bong's best film yet, an intriguingly sour art-house treat, and one of the most rewarding films of the new year.

An American comedy for the other America.

Every trace of maudlin evaporates in one of Del Toro's lopsided grins.

We're finally left holding a handful of air at the end.
The jungle has been very good to Werner Herzog.
Writer-director John Gray was blessed to find the faces of actors Thurston and Murphy.
Might have been better as a documentary.

movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cold but oddly fascinating piece of work, it contains some of the best chase sequences in recent memory.
The anti-factory-farming message is timely as ever.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible to smoke enough weed to make this movie seem funny.
The screenplay would embarrass Mother Goose.
Has a strong flavor of daytime-drama soap.
Deneuve, Luchini, and Depardieu hum like a well oiled machine.
Surprisingly watchable for a one-joke time-waster.
The real life the camera catches is naturally more dramatic and unexpected than any written scenario.
The screenplay leeches all the fun out of it, and the principals - aside from Caan, who generates his own power - seem lost and abandoned.
Well-written, appropriately sour modern crime story.
The best way to look at this is as an acting exercise. As long as your patience holds, it's mildly diverting.
Too many musical interludes, too much posing, and generally not enough meat in the sandwich.
This heartily maudlin character study is sort of a crash course in Boomerology.
It's a bit too worshipful, but certainly fills in the gaps in our knowledge of the life and times of the late 1960s singer-songwriter.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Where Dahl succeeds is in transforming two essentially tired characters into fully fleshed-out human beings who fall in love.

movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A topsy-turvy wonderland of stylistic riffs and thematic threads reverberating back on themselves for the sheer, exuberant, sexy hell of it.
Spurlock is still inserting himself into stupid game-show-style situations, but this time his target is so juicy we're inclined to forgive him.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable story with tremendous human interest, about people we think we've figured out, but about whom we actually know next to nothing.
An inventive, challenging, at times emotionally bracing film, audaciously staged and laudably anti-clichéd in its character particulars, yet destined to be more admired than beloved.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Better to be "seized in a pitiless mesh of imbecilities" than to be bored to death.
If Tashlin had had the nerve, he would have romantically paired Jayne Mansfield with Little Richard and set race relations in the United States forward by about thirty years.
The Visitor gives Richard Jenkins a chance to develop a character for the whole running time.
Shrinks the world situation to fit the mood of America and gets away with it. Candy-coated reality? Yankee vanity? Maybe so. But the sunniness is welcome.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Actors Germano and Scamarcio turn in magnificent, multilayered acting jobs.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An embarrassingly toothless and endlessly boring story about characters we barely get to know doing things that are more exciting than they make it seem.
Demanding, ultimately mesmerizing variation on an antique theme wanders off into a wilderness of its own where the essential stoic loneliness of what we call the American character comes into focus.
Documentary has more on its mind than just showing off the riches of America's cinematic heritage.
Pierre Salvadori's deceptively sunny romantic comedy insinuates its point of view steadily, amidst great glamour and breeziness, only to reveal itself as a meditation on, dare we say it, capitalism.
The figure of Gibson is immediately suspect and polarizing, and ultimately too much of a distraction from this fragile TV-style family story.
We can feel the hot violence of the air in the last row of a crowded theater.
The miraculous Sandrine Bonnaire, with help from the dependable Kevin Kline, transforms a routine heartwarmer scenario into a thing of beauty.
Ponderous, inflated, overstated Spanish Civil War potboiler displays all of director Roland Joffé's worst tendencies to full disadvantage.
Branagh's direction looks the same as that of any other summer tentpole manager, and things go boom.
The calm, determined presence of Yen (following in the footsteps of Bruce Lee and Jet Li) pulls it all together, with major help from cinematographer-turned-director Andrew Lau Wai-Keung.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director/co-scenarist Spencer Susser has a definite feel for Hesher and T.J.'s little corner of the world.
The best that can be said about Everything Must Go is that it's slightly less nauseating than The Beaver.
For filmmaker Patricio Guzman, Chile's national shame seems to overpower even the stars.

A mopey character study only half-convincingly tricked out as a heist thriller.
Nothing to be embarrassed about here. Though the kick-in-the-balls scene does run on a bit.
Set the irony meter at eleven and enjoy.
We could say that The Savages is a social-problem drama about senile dementia and nursing homes, but that's a little like saying The 400 Blows is about school truancy.
Who suggested the John Huston accent? We keep expecting Daniel Plainview to molest a young niece or something.
This painful documentary ends on a hopeful note, although with a clear view of the cloud over human nature.
There's very little that's whimsical about this coming-of-age chronicle, but if we're looking for political reflection we're reading the wrong comic book.
Léaud blasts off into entirely new galaxies of rationalization and bravado, most of it debating the presumption that the "typical male's" fantasies involve either a mother or a whore.
movie_title: The Mother and the Whore (La Maman et la putain) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: We haven't had a good vagina dentata movie in theaters lately, so it's a pleasure to see Teeth filling that particular need with such obvious relish and style.

This generally pleasurable doc is a little wonky in presenting that chronology, but you eventually piece together his story. And it certainly succeeds as a study in obsession.
movie_title: Marinoni: The Fire in the Frame (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite their eagerness to work with him, Malick has an uncanny ability to expose the limits of even the best performers.
It's fascinating stuff, full of arcane asides and visual puns.

The film rarely lets you contemplate the music without competition from strong images, and another five or so minutes could have offered background to the work itself. But like Beethoven's, this Ninth leaves you wanting more.
movie_title: Following the Ninth: In the Footsteps of Beethoven's Final Symphony (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Program is a solid primer to this fascinating rise-and-fall saga -- one offering far-reaching implications about corruption in sports and celebrity culture.

The movie's funnier than it has any right to be, given the crudity of its running jokes. But The Bronze becomes more interesting when it quiets down for Greggory's burgeoning friendship with a goofy gym owner played by Silicon Valley's Thomas Middleditch.
This Circus certainly gets across the notion that art and human connection are our most renewable resources.
It's remarkable how many early traumas -- both banal and highly specific -- it addresses in its soft pastel way.
Once you get past the fact that it's not the comedy its trailers imply, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot has some unexpected strengths.
The makers of this animated update of The Little Prince approach Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's classic with respect and imagination, with initially satisfying results.
Ethan Hawke doesn't exactly resemble young Chet Baker... But in Born to Be Blue he fully conveys the fragile apartness that marked Baker's art and persona.
The Intern again speaks to the moment, at least for white, upper-middle-class hipsters and forebears untroubled by actual real-estate prices.

Just when you think not one more story can shed light on the Second World War (at least without the blessing of Tom Hanks), along comes Sophie Scholl: The Final Days, a starkly stirring tale of resistance to all-encompassing evil.
This slapdash effort, bigger on star gossip and seizure-inducing montages of material meant to be studied at leisure, provides almost no context if you're not already in the know.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For those wanting to plumb deeper existential truths, or who simply want to bathe in visual poetry, the film is a strong enough reason to get out of the house.
If anything, [the filmmakers] have amplified Kiss's most irritating quality, a kind of 'grandiose miserabilism', as the Village Voice complained of Muccino's creation.
This utterly charming film exists in a kind of dream state of memory and inspiration.
One's compassion is both challenged and expanded by a rare movie that really does go its own way.

About five minutes into the extremely funny Confetti, which is packed with some of Britain's best comic talents, it became clear that those pasty-faced, lager-swilling guys and gals were born with a taking-the-piss gene (urinus abscondus).

If viewers can get past the fact that everything here is utterly explicit, there's a lot of funny and sweet material, although the relationship stuff isn't quite as convincing as the more cynical views of human nature.
On one level, the director can be lauded for going for the gut at the expense of everything else. But a bit of homework wouldn't hurt.
Artist-turned-helmer Su Rynard gets the tough stuff (like the period backstory) right but then muffs easy business (like the contempo framing) in the time-jumping Kardia.
The film loses its way in a long, slapsticky climax.

The fine line between eccentricity and outright dopiness is skirted with British aplomb in Keeping Mum, a comedy that revives the ghoulish tradition of the Ealing Studios' heyday, with Maggie Smith standing in for Alec Guinness in, say, The Ladykillers.

Held back a year to allow Capote time to cool off, Infamous continues the Truman show by giving us a sharper, more elfin writer in his prime, and focusing more fully on his odd and ultimately wounding relationship with a convicted killer.
In any case, evidence of Lennon's weaknesses, as an artist or a human being, in no way undermines the value of his work, nor the argument against bureaucrats fighting secretly against him.
Gary Burns' latest vision of dystopia is an edgy look at exurbia, this time with a documaker's eye.

The Queen, a surprisingly intimate study of power at high levels, offers us the subtle pleasures of Helen Mirren playing a familiar figure from real life, Queen Elizabeth II of England, at one of the most challenging moments of her long reign.
If there's a more remarkable series of documentary films, or even as remarkable a premise for one, I don't expect to see it in my lifetime.

Some say the biggest offender was the application of '80s pop songs -- the soundtrack to her own upbringing -- to an otherwise detailed period piece. But throwing on great, guitar-driven tunes is actually one her cannier moves.
The film's pretty pictures are invaluable; still, it's almost shocking that such a worthy ode to nature's grace should be so clumsy.
A promising concept is gradually run into the ground.

An uplifting ode to all that's still great, or at least moderately salvageable, about the USA, this talking-head road trip -- taken by two neophyte pic-makers with a really solid Rolodex -- is a handy antidote to prevailing Generation Why cynicism.
[A] snappily edited, shockingly well balanced (and occasionally gruesome) overview.
The locals may be eccentrics, but the movie makes it clear that they are not as far away as they seem.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Overall effect, regardless of aesthetic quibbles or kudos, is to make auds aware of how imminent the risk is to these environmentally interdependent creatures.
Both a finely wrought period piece and a slice of delicately captured childhood.
If the movie just doesn't have the nostalgic pull of a Chinatown or the camp appeal of an L.A. Confidential, it may be that its material didn't really justify the full-feature treatment.
As pure cinema, there's no denying the power of Lunacy, although mostly that power can best be described as, well, sadistic.
A tight script, smart casting and sharp direction prevail over modest production values in Run Robot Run!, a sci-fi spoof of corporate culture.
There's little here for people who like their pics loud, colorful and tidy. But Sleeping Dogs does offer some raw meat for auds willing to sniff out a little something extra.
A thorny subject is handled with care in this meticulous reconstruction of life inside the East German police state, as boiled down to the experiences of just two ex-inmates.
Even if the attempt to tell a story in this B.C.-shot effort is a bit lame, the atmospherics still make it fun to watch.
There's always room for zombies, and Mile Zero maker Andrew Currie adds an instant classic to the genre with Fido.

Cohen, abetted by director Larry Charles, makes a meal of Borat Sagdiyev, a profoundly ignorant, deeply sexist, and determinedly anti-Semitic news reporter from Kazakhstan who nonetheless projects a kind of appealing, and appalling, innocence.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pic is seasoned with fine perfs by JR Bourne as a charismatic, creepy hustler and Steph Song as Constanzo's sexy potential love interest.
Thoughtful, surprisingly fast-moving docu overcomes contextual messiness to provide a memorably quirky look at Dzonghsar Khyentse Rinpoche.
The insights it offers into modern relationships are not particularly deep. But as an acting tour de force, the movie offers enough leisurely pleasures to entertain.
A fairly empty exercise in genre exploitation.
Cinematic sleight of hand tricks can't obscure the trouble brewing in the more than two hours of Now You See Me 2, which eventually succumbs to fatal sequelitis.
Clunky acting and vague storytelling will make tots more enthusiastic than parents.
The fact is, no matter how much oomph the actors put into their roles ... it's hard to buy anyone's attraction to anyone else here.
The quietly comic Moving Malcolm lives up to its title by becoming more emotionally involving as it goes along...

U.K.-born NG veteran Tim Liversedge, Roar's primary picmaker -- he produced, helmed and lensed -- has lived in southern Africa for more than 40 years, and his intense proximity to these volatile critters is unparalleled.
A less than stellar outing for the National Film Board of Canada, Westray may be of passing interest to older Canadians, but will be a tough sell even to pubcasters in other countries.
This is a chance for Reilly to strut his stuff -- so good he ought to be illegal -- in harmony or against the grain with a variety of terrific character actors.
Well mounted, frequently gripping WWII tale of GIs surviving behind German lines during the Battle of the Bulge.
Will only rock the worlds of similarly youthful boho types on alt-cinema sideroutes.
Even as a tragic hero, Duffy's a bully and a bore.

What really makes this Baby, with its murky minimalism and spare score (by Eastwood himself) more than worthwhile is its ability to subvert sports-movie verities to mine something much richer, and more disturbing, beneath the skin.
It's testimony to this Army's raw power that one is left wanting more.
Quote not available.
Funny only in an I-can't-believe-they're-doing-that kind of way.
There's a pleasing patina of pure schlock that almost -- and I stress almost -- makes Undiscovered watchable.

The elements of this Native American comedy look cloying on paper, but first-time helmer-scripter Kate Montgomery has such a winning way with her adroitly assembled cast that these concerns don't apply.

I like to think -- and please indulge me on this -- that my reaction to the controversial 9 Songs has more to do with the limitations of Michael Winterbottom's latest cinematic experiment than with any of my own nihilistic-horndog tendencies.
Dreamland might be found on a dirt road outside Sundance, but it's a path that all too obviously leads to Hollywood.
Yet more self-conscious schlock masquerading as a thoughtful effort, The Quiet thinks it out-Heathers all the Mean Girls but really just ends up whimpering in the dark.
There's pain for him and pleasure for us -- and relatively guilt-free, at that.
Computer-enhanced pictorials do most of the imaginative work in Idlewild, a wildly ambitious musical that sat on the shelf for two years, for understandable reasons.
Of course, the adults don't matter much compared with the middle-school version of the Crips, and the young cast is enjoyable indeed.

There are no guns in Half Nelson, and there don't need to be; the title refers to a wrestling move in which you turn an attacker's strength back on him. Or, if you are like Dan Dunne, you turn it on yourself.
Storytelling mechanics break down under the stress of too much information and not enough good acting.

Bon Cop, Bad Cop, a rare Canadian venture into straightforward commercialism, manages to work well as both light entertainment and running commentary on the culture clash between the English and French Canadas.
Stone really does stick to basic storytelling here and is content to focus on just a few people caught up in the maelstrom of 9/11 and leave the rest up to us.

This cleverly crafted film -- the mix of exotic locations and music is entertaining in its own right -- starts backwards by following high-quality Ethiopian beans back to where they are grown and sold for far less than they are worth.
Carves out unique territory -- even as it may freak out fans of genre convention.
This summer-fling comedy turns out to be as generic as its title suggests.
Strong enough to make believers out of non-metalheads, and inside enough to get the devil's-horns salute from the most diehard followers.
A refreshing take on an overused theme -- dysfunctional father-son connections -- starts gently and gets more compelling as it glides along like a woodworker's sharpened plane over smooth surfaces.
Any movie that lets the Daily Show's Lewis Black, as the school's ad-hoc dean, rant at will about consumerism and foul-mouthed freethinking definitely knows its S.H.I.T. from shinola.
[A] ceaselessly funny mockumentary.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A bleary-eyed fever dream lumbered with impenetrable literary references, Death and the Compass quickly loses its way and expires long before its 90 minutes are up.
Has everything the midnight crowd could possibly want.
Initially, you may want to skip Allie and Harper, but they get steadily more interesting as their frazzled road trip inches them ever closer to the beach.

The result is a movie for people who hit the multiplex unsure whether to catch a slacker comedy, a superhero movie, a political satire, or an extra-violent action flick. It's Ultra, so you don't have to choose!
The film's message is certainly distressing -- there's no way humans can survive this collective auto-da-fé -- but at least the ride is fun.
The superbly acted film, which won the best-cinematography award at this year's Sundance festival, is a dreamlike -- and sometimes quietly nightmarish -- evocation of youth.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Prophet gets a Disney makeover that's ultimately even more disturbing than it is cloying.

It's easy to see what drew these filmmakers to the beautifully written essay, which had broken hearts and wounded families built into it. What's harder to grasp is how they could turn it into something so pedestrian.
Mistress America is buoyed by smartly expressed mixed emotions.
It's a superbly acted chamber piece that will be savoured by anyone who cares about the struggle to create, and to survive.
All in all, there are enough animal high jinks here to make at least a temporary vegetarian out of the most dedicated mutton-lover.

Depending on your age, disposition, and expectations about movies, A Walk in the Woods is either a soft entertainment or a refreshing meditation on man's relationship with nature, both without and within.

Visually playful passages explaining how tracks are put together are especially knowing. And this intelligence is underscored by the clever decision to use incidental music containing no beats at all -- thus making the club-spinning scenes more exciting.
Ultimately, the stylish film offers only a few new glimpses of the man.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: India's judicial system comes under review in Court, a film that keeps a wary, and therefore amusingly light, distance from its subject.
The subject is much less cryptic and far more humble than fans would typically expect.
[A] ceaselessly entertaining action comedy from Korean writer-director Kim Seong-hun.
By and large, I try to avoid spoilers, but once you get past The Perfect Guy's obviously ironic title, there's nothing left to spoil.
Anna Muylaert's carefully composed images provide a cool stage for some hot acting -- all of which manages to be amusingly uplifting rather than sociologically bleak.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Alternately harrowing and uplifting.
A wonderful feel for place and people animates this very simply structured tale of rural northern Quebec.
Catfishing is taken to a whole new level in this disturbingly personal doc.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The kids are winsome -- a few even have nascent star power -- but the solipsism of their personal concerns grows wearying, especially as they are outpaced by events changing Europe at an ever-faster rate.
movie_title: We Did It on a Song (Chante ton bac d'abord) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [A] bittersweet ode to a phoenix who kept singeing his own wings.
movie_title: Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan Story (2015)

These friendly voices -- and many laugh-out-loud (if too frequently repeated) clips -- aren't exactly helped by a constant drone of spooky piano music
Fans of Jim Jarmusch and Luis Buñuel will be delighted by this funny, easygoing trip-out in which dreams, memories, and fleeting impulses get thrown in director Lee Kwang-kuk's blender.
[A] satisfying character study.

German indie veteran Rosa von Praunheim's stylized mix of documentary and low-budget reenactment isn't for everyone, but the fact that he doesn't care what you think of his style is part of his rude charm.
The story devolves into high-school play territory, complete with "comical" banjo music and guaranteed anachronisms every few minutes.
Searching for something, anything, to pull the story together, this turns into cheap thriller in the last 15 minutes, and fails at that, too.
The film gets better as it moves along, but it's really about a guy who was beaten by life before he even got to the board.
At less than 80 minutes, the movie takes its time to let people have surprisingly frank discussions and, given the central topic, it doesn't chicken out about what's at stake.
Pure pleasure for guitar freaks,
There are so many sharp ideas here -- nothing that couldn't be improved chemically -- the movie almost makes you feel nostalgic for sex like it never was. And never will be again.
Unfortunately, the filmmakers have little feel for the period or the genres they're spoofing, and the songs are mostly pretty bad anyway.
There's no attempt to explore the ethos of the place, but a lot is revealed through the film's playfully immersive style.
movie_title: Taking My Parents To Burning Man (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It could prove almost as definitive -- and far more easily digestible -- than Branagh's textually complete version.
A soundtrack in search of a movie, Empire Records is one teen-music effort that never finds a groove.
Pic sticks to musical side of the best-known woman exponent of the 1970s movement known as tropicalia, and that works fine, as the gray-maned diva has plenty to say in that department.

movie_review_blurb: Takes anime to a whole new level.
Watchable only for camp value.
Thanks to a perfectly blended ensemble led by Hector Elizondo, in his best screen role to date, Tortilla Soup is a warm-blooded winner with equal emphasis placed on taste buds and heartstrings.
Steers puts a lot of balls in the air, but no one, including Igby, gets developed far enough for viewers to really know and care about them.
When it wants to, this Dragon definitely breathes fire.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Top-drawer kiddie fare for both fans of the exotic and mainstream family auds.
A spin-off of the semi-hit animated TV series, Batman: Mask of the Phantasm goes even further into the roots of the bat-dude's particular pathologies.
The script is full of anachronisms, but Hairspray's sense of history delivers a needed spritz in the face.
A disturbing yet easy to watch documentary about the increasingly industrialized yanking on what used to be called the food chain.
A masterful blend of macabre storytelling, coming-of-age frankness, some shocking gore, and eerie melding of quiet sounds and incomplete imagery, as well as some subtle gender-line exploration.
There are also surprisingly few subplots for a movie that lasts more than two hours. What is on display, however, is very fertile stuff.
There's much to make you laugh and cry, but the image that lingers is that of a gentle, bewildered man carrying his past overhead like a multicoloured cloud on a leash.

Dialing back the hyperkinetic action to 9.5 wouldn't have hurt this spectacular tale, which combines many film genres and visual styles for a two-hour abusement-park ride that begins with torture and ends with love's inevitable triumph.
What's strange about the 87-minute movie is that there's nothing strange about it.
Bailey clearly has a gift for intimacy, as she has no trouble getting inside the homes and, you could say, heads of her subjects.
Amy could have included a couple of complete songs. But U.K. director Asif Kapadia makes the case for her greatness, and her downfall, almost entirely through her own actions.
This blandly titled comedy from the U.K. spends so much setup time being generically clever, it's truly unexpected when, a third of the way in, things heat up in oddball ways.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This Suite remains intriguing, if still unfinished.
The tale is a superbly written audience charmer that's afraid of neither facts nor feelings.

[The film has] a flair for the quietly theatrical and the conviction that various codes of gender and honour (religious, tribal, legal, or whatever) outweigh human connections in moments of extreme stress.
[Inside Out] will equally enchant children and the Jung at heart, with an increasingly rapid pace and trippy CGI imagery that allow no time for quasi-Broadway songs.

The filmmakers argue persuasively, with some oversimplification, that the prolonged joust was a final watershed of public debate and a harbinger of what we'd get in its place: paid pundits, usually wrong, screaming at each other.
You get the perfectly calibrated story of one young man's travels, not just to the United States from his tiny island country but to the land of expectations that come with adulthood.
The handsome, trophy-attracting film is more playful than profound, but it does contain quietly measured insights into class, comportment, and one seriously screwed-up family.
By sharp turns poignant, disturbing and hysterically funny.
Stiller one-ups his Zoolander fashion-world creation with Tugg Speedman, an action hero trying to revive his flagging, Sly Stallone-type career by appearing in the most expensive war movie ever made.
Is it all a bit precious and far-fetched? Sure, but so, the filmmaker is saying, is life.

The megabucks actor may have made M:I because it was expected of him, but his mission here was to learn something about himself-through acting, no less-and along the way he picked up something we've never seen in him before: passion.
A wonderful new animated feature from France.

The search to nail down exact return policies on modern relationships drives both the humour and the edgy parts of Maggie's Plan, which features faultless delivery of beautifully entangled dialogue from writer-director Rebecca Miller.
The superb first half of this fish-in-two-waters drama is so packed with fresh, tender insights, it's a shock when the art-house-aimed Dheepan suddenly goes full Neeson.

Until it bogs down in multiple endings that could have been trimmed or even dropped, it operates as a surprisingly piercing metaphor for everyone's central fear while facing middle age, that of being replaced.
The less you know in advance the better, once you have decided to surrender to this Franciscan's oddly spiritual journey.
The Road Forward offers an embarrassment of riches regarding the political, cultural, and day-to-day life of Canada's First Nations people, particularly in this region.
The human foreground isn't always that interesting, but the natural backdrop here is truly amazing.
Most impressively, this Story is good at capturing that sense of ineffable connection with what has come before us and what persists when we are gone. The living part's a little weak, though.
An obvious must-see for students of film history and history in general, the two-hour movie is somewhat overcrowded by Morrison's clearly passionate ambitions.
Christopher Nolan eschews Batmanesque grandiosity, not to mention irony and blatant special effects, to pursue a more authentically immersive view of this historical turning point.
What comes across is a heartfelt and aesthetically pleasing tour of ancient practices that have somehow survived the onslaught of modernity.
The 90-minute movie reaches for the ineffable, and is downright lysergic in how much it gets right.
Sequel is a validation of the earlier film's projections, most of which show the biosphere much worse off than expected 11 years later.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the real world, it might be a pain to keep hearing the voices in their heads, but for a roughly 100-minute journey, they are good company indeed.
The smoothly structured, beautifully acted Moka builds slowly toward a tug of war between thriller conventions and deeper emotions. And the audience wins.
With pedestrian direction provided by SNL veteran Dave McCary, Mooney and company drop the ball just when they decide to ground James in the world he left behind.
The script seems overly determined to knock its hero down, when the people around him could stand to do some growing up.
All problems are on this level of, um, complexity in Landline, which serves up a laundry list of humdrum conflicts.
The absorbing In Transit was the final directing effort by documentary hero Albert Maysles.
But in his feature debut, writer-director Matt Spicer has identified some basic problems without really finding a way to get past the obvious.

An inspired half-hour's worth of visual invention is spread out over a forced 80 minutes in Dave Made a Maze, a tribute to '80s horror-fantasy flicks that never quite decides what tone it wants to take.
In Rat Film, a taxonomy of urban life is laid out in vignettes that alternately delight and disgust.
Facing fear is what drives this event, and the movie, forward. And for viewers, this provides both inspiration and a certain predictability.
The poor-woman's-Nora-Ephron template is followed here, right down to the super-generic title and the dependence on a genuinely engaging cast to sell flimsy material.
Because the meaty, two-hour tale is so essentially naturalistic, it takes time to notice how elegantly framed, shot, and edited it is.
Some bright bits poke up, but all told, this Tulip tries to get too many things going, and uses too much fertilizer to do it.
Pop Aye is one companion you'll never forget.
The laid-back spirits of Jim Jarmusch, Wim Wenders, and Christopher Guest inform Radio Dreams, which follows an amusing batch of characters on a slow journey of (semi-) self-discovery.
Swagger...lives up to its name.
Beautifully observed, paced, and resolved with a nifty twist, The Teacher is one of the most enjoyably instructive movies of the year.
A highly necessary tale is told in Neither Wolf Nor Dog. You simply have to look past amateurish direction, bad writing, and even worse acting to find it.

While it's always a pleasure to encounter a literate script delivered by a surprise roster of A-list actors, the wordplay in The Only Living Boy in New York stays ahead of any real connection to somewhat stock New York characters.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although somewhat boxed in by its own physical beauty, The Fencer is so uniformly well-crafted, it should be shown in film schools as a model of technical artists operating at the highest level.
Putting the grim back in Grimm Brothers, this deceptively simple animated effort turns a lesser-known fairy tale into an edgy meditation on gendered views of nature and society.
movie_title: The Girl Without Hands (La Jeune fille sans mains) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Who among us predicted that Channing Tatum would become a major actor, equally adept at light-fingered comedy and low-key contemporary dramas?
With his dead-on outer-borough accent and sleepless, thousand-yard stare, Pattinson is utterly convincing as someone who, despite all his heavy lifting, we never come to care about.
It fails as both farce and drama, although the performances are likable enough to guarantee a relatively painless ride.
There's definitely some inspiration here for budding storytellers. Hopefully, they would take these ideas and add some genuine emotion. Plus acting.
A poorly written two-hander that's just as dull as its forgettable name.
Less a movie than a year's subscription to Architectural Digest crammed into a 130-minute montage.

The simplicity of mixing creative crafts with everyday chores recalls the village life that dominated the planet for thousands of years, and the straightforward Maudie, an Irish-Canadian coproduction, pretty much sticks to that approach.
Pleasant, but only intermittently engaging.

A documentary that should be seen by anyone interested in the future of cities -- especially those as fraught with housing problems as Vancouver -- Citizen Jane is a fascinating call to arms for urban dwellers who don't mind fighting city hall.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The worst thing about Colossal is that it feels so small.
The 90-minute doc, shot in several formats over at least five years, centres on three Torontonians who have survived well enough to describe their journeys with some clarity.

Even after the stately action shifts to Paris, everyone's feelings are so cautiously deliberated, it's hard to get excited about their remaining options, romantic or otherwise. This is a movie to admire, not love.
