movie_review_blurb: The absolutely most enthusiastic thing I can say about Our Idiot Brother is that I didn't mind sitting through it.
What we have here is Conspiracy Theory 101 all Blair-Witched-up.
It is a film that is difficult to adequately describe -- and one I believe is impossible to process in one sitting.
A thoroughly competent movie that is reasonably effective at being what it sets out to be -- a solid little thriller. It's also pretty hard to get excited about.
It's impossible not to be impressed by how director Asif Kapadia and writer Manish Pandey have managed to craft a biographical film completely out of archive footage.
I want to defend Dream House, but it's just -- well, kind of indefensible.
What is most impressive about the film is that it manages to put human faces -- not just caricatures -- on the key figures of the movement.
Not only one of the year's biggest and best surprises, but it's the most beautifully photographed film I've seen in some considerable time.
The film's cleverness is undeniable -- and it's not every day that you find two performers like Kristin Scott Thomas and Ludivine Sagnier pitted against each other.
We all know how it plays out, but that makes it no less compelling and maddening.
Misses greatness, but contains elements of greatness of the kind that only comes from filmmakers who are willing to take real chances.
So dumb and goofy and ridiculous that it's actually kind of hard not to like on those terms.
It's everything you expect -- bad writing, bad acting, bad direction, dull characters and long stretches of boredom punctuated by sudden jolts.
The best way I can think to describe the film is that it's pretty consistently pleasant.
Doesn't even quite pull off 'very good,' but it easily walks off with a solid 'good.' And in 2011, good may be good enough.
A nice little movie, and very obviously well intentioned. Unfortunately, it's also predictable and so corny that it sometimes feels like a joke in search of a punchline.
It's easy enough to sit through, it'll be even easier to forget in a few weeks.
Reginald LeBorg keeps the movie pretty effective on the atmosphere front, though the opening scenes may be the most effective of all.
A pretty neat little horror picture that's raised several notches by the presence of George Zucco.
A good film. But as drama, it falls a little shy of the mark.
There isn't a single thing I would change about the film's brisk 88-minute running time.
Never seems quite the film this aggregation of talent suggests it should have been.
It's a good film with a strong central performance. The problem is that the film isn't as strong as the performance.
A very special film that deserves a chance with discerning viewers.
A rich, sometimes rewarding, yet deeply flawed work that sometimes gets things so right that it's hard not to forgive it when it doesn't.
The film has a weird kind of poetry and beauty about it that is hard -- perhaps impossible -- to describe.
Essentially a variation on Vittorio De Sica's The Bicycle Thief, but it has a vitality and resonance all its own.
You may see -- and perhaps already have seen -- better documentaries this year than Errol Morris' Tabloid, but I doubt you'll see a more entertaining one.
One of those movies that I wanted to like more than I actually did. I did like it, but something about it just didn't ring the gong.
I think what works best about this final film is how surprisingly moving parts of it are.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A difficult, long, sometimes brutal work that truly justifies the term 'epic' -- not in the overused sense that has come to mean big and loud -- in both vision and execution.
Nearly everything about Queen to Play works, but what really sells the film -- apart from the freshness of the subject matter -- lies in the performances.
There are worse movies than Zookeeper. But I didn't see those this week; I saw Zookeeper. I can honestly say I wish I hadn't.
Bear in mind we're talking about giant mutant telepathic crabs bent on world domination.
The more sober-minded work, and the creepier film, thanks in large measure to Paul Birch's performance as the gent who is 'not of this Earth.'
With eight directors and 17 credited writers, the results aren't exactly uniform, but they work more often than not.
Easily the most inventive filmmaking I've seen all year.
It is perhaps a measure of the success of a documentary to be able to interest you in a subject that you'd not normally gravitate toward.
The most obnoxious, noisy, tedious, ugly waste of film this year.
Joins the depressingly long list of movies that are simply hard to get worked up about one way or the other.
The Tree of Life is profound, pretentious, art, twaddle, a cinematic event and a pompous bore all packed into 138-overlong minutes. And, in its own way, it's a must-see.
Art and history as seen through the eyes and mind of perhaps the most idiosyncratic filmmaker of all time.
This isn't a good Woody Allen movie. No, this is one of the great Woody Allen films.
It's mildly entertaining while it's onscreen, but the word that finally comes to mind for me is 'undistinguished.'
The most intense film I've seen all year. It's also one of the most compelling -- and, in its own way, one of the most entertaining.
Hobo with a Shotgun is what downhome we'd call a 'hoot.' Maybe two hoots. The title alone says it all.
It sets out to be a pleasant, sweet-natured entertainment that tries to avoid cynicism (perhaps a little too hard). On that basis, it succeeds well enough.
I'll gladly take this bargain-basement 95 minutes of exploitation over the 150 minutes of The Dirty Dozen any day.
Comedy of a kind that doesn't get made any more (probably due to a lack of actors who can pull off this sort of thing).
This is that rarest of comedies -- as was Easy A --where the filmmaking itself is as clever and funny as the script and the performances.
A surprisingly good vampire movie at a time when even barely decent vampire movies are rare.
Another on that increasingly frustrating list of movies that I liked, but wanted to love and didn't quite.
Perhaps the most terrifying, nightmarish film anyone has ever made about war.
It's fast, fun and funny -- and the best-looking movie Mae West ever made, having the shimmery luster you only saw in Paramount movies.
Considerably more thought-provoking than expected.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is not a great film. It is, however, sometimes a very good one, and it's always a joy to behold in visual terms.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, it's creative and well done, but it finally left a bitter taste and I found it utterly depressing.
Tries to stuff too much into a single movie, but it's good, solid mainstream moviemaking -- and that's not such a bad thing.
The usual TV actors -- including some fellow who looks the love child of Tom Cruise and Peter Gallagher's eyebrows -- being systematically offed because they cheated death.
In the movie's first scene Jason Bateman gets hit in the face with projectile baby diarrhea, followed by him getting a mouthful of it. You know -- intellectual humor.
I did find it a surprisingly agreeable afternoon's entertainment.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There is no earthly reason why Michael Winterbottom's The Trip should work, and several reasons why it shouldn't. Remarkably, it does work.
What appears to be a slyly amusing film about an experiment that sounds mostly just goofy turns into a reasonably serious indictment of those conducting the experiment.
A good film that never quite becomes a very good film, even though it sometimes flirts with greatness.
For those who claim that if I don't like a movie, they know it's good -- has Hollywood ever got a treat lined up here!
It's a good time at the movies -- something all these summer releases aim for, but very often don't achieve.
As a straightforward piece of WWI movie, it's not bad, but neither is it particularly exciting -- unless you just want to see the impressive footage of the cool old planes.
For Lubitsch, the film would mark the end of his most creative period at Paramount (1929-1933) -- and a fine final bow it is.
Compelling viewing -- not only for the issues it raises about the state of journalism, but because of the presence of the paper's media reporter David Carr.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the most vile, repellent, repulsive, depraved, degraded, debased and plain ugly movie I have ever seen.
Catapulted Alan Ladd to stardom, established Ladd and Veronica Lake as a screen team and is just plain as close to a perfect representation of film noir as you're likely to get.
For those familiar with the later Charlie Chan movies, The Black Camel is revelatory. For anyone else, it's a great introduction to the series.
movie_title: Charlie Chan in the Black Camel (1931)

movie_review_blurb: The film's aim at being shocking is generally undercut by how cheerfully foolish it all is.
Any documentary that can make sushi interesting for 90 minutes clearly does something right.
A pretentious, unpleasant, woolly headed movie that's nothing more than a cheesy horror picture for people who wouldn't be caught dead going to a cheesy horror picture.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What's surprising is just how clearly Singh has left his fingerprints all over the film.
Primarily an action picture -- albeit a very well made one that has wandered over into the area of art-house hit owing to both craftsmanship and subtitles.
A nightmarish, hallucinatory film, bathed in raw neon colors and with style to spare, and with a blistering central performance by Woody Harrleson.
At bottom a pretty basic romantic comedy of the comfort-food variety.
Solid enough, but for a non-fan fairly unremarkable.
So exactly the very definition of a Charlie Chan movie from the era when Warner Oland played the Chinese detective that it's probably the most essential of them all.
Lugosi is in fine form as the "brilliant, but unbalanced" Orloff and seems to be enjoying every last drop of his incredible perfidy.
movie_title: The Dark Eyes of London (Dead Eyes of London) (The Human Monster) (Dr. Orloff) (1940)

movie_review_blurb: It's convoluted and clever, and on that score it works quite nicely. But if you're looking for something substantial beyond this, you're looking for a different movie.
The images and the music -- and for that matter the story -- seem to belong together to create the vibrant whole of the film.
I won't go so far as to say it's good, but 21 Jump Street is certainly better than it has any right to be.
What you end up with is more an entertaining, overheated mish-mash than a great classic.
movie_title: Rocco and His Brothers (Rocco e i suoi fratelli) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: I'll be greatly surprised if anything this bad comes along again this year -- or any other year, come to that.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, the film itself is a sleep-inducing bore.
Manages to overcome an inflated running time and occasional bouts of cuteness by remembering and embracing its pulp fiction roots as an 'interplanetary romance.'
Sturges' gift for blending the sophisticated with the simple, the cynical with the sentimental has rarely been better evidenced than it is here.
If Tod Browning, Luis Buñuel, Alejandro Jodorowsky, Pedro Almodóvar and Guillermo del Toro all dropped acid and compared notes, this film might be the result.
Strictly for its target audience, who tend to be very uncritical where these movies are concerned.
You may also find that some aspects of this very foreign story seem disturbingly not all that foreign.
Solid entertainment and much better than I'd expected from the maestro of midcult, Joss Whedon.
Buried somewhere beneath more padding than Eddie Murphy's Norbit fat suit may lie an OK romantic comedy in The Five-Year Engagement.
A lot better than I'd expected. In itself, that's not saying all that much since I was prepared for it to be pretty bad.
Both improbable and dull.
All too often, I felt like I was marking time waiting for the fairly obvious plot to follow its inevitable course.
One of the pleasanter surprises I've had this year.
The biggest difference is that Sam Raimi's 2002 Spider-Man managed to be an event and this doesn't.
His best and most agreeable Madea comedy.
My immediate response is that it's a masterpiece and the best film to come out so far this year.
If you get right down to it, this might have more solid laughs than its much praised predecessor.
If you're a fan of those involved, you might cut it some slack. Or you might wish they were in a better movie.
A powerful statement on a violent society -- and a very uncomfortable one that is apt to alienate many viewers.
A sweet-natured, bittersweet little movie -- and I mean little -- about growing old.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Is it obviously a Tim Burton picture? Sure it is. That's what I expect -- and, in fact, what I want -- from a Burton movie.
Absolves Paul Weitz for having made Little Fockers and makes up for most of Robert De Niro's choices in the past few years.
Takes the fairly dreadful 'teacher who makes a difference' sub-genre and puts an interesting new spin on it that gives it the allure of something fresh.
Davies visually enhances the content of the play in a purely cinematic way.
Unlike many films, it genuinely earns every feeling it evokes.
A good-hearted, delightfully quirky film with an intelligent vibe.
If you take it as agreeably macabre nonsense, yes, you might enjoy it. If you're going to have a conniption fit over every historical inaccuracy, however, give it a pass.
A blessed reminder of just how good -- and how pointed -- British comedies can be.
While it isn't the genre-breaking work it's being pitched as, it's a work of some note all the same.
Smart, heartfelt, savvy, beautifully acted -- and clever enough at 86 minutes not to overstay its welcome.
I'd say Gone is a shoo-in for one of the worst movies of 2012, except no one will remember it even existed by December.
A film that's easier to admire (at least in part) than actually like, but it's also a difficult film to ignore.
The film is often very funny, but the humor is bitter and the film isn't full of life lessons learned -- though it may be said to be littered with life lessons for the taking.
That rare thing -- the sequel that is better than the original.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Within 5 minutes, I concluded that no one over the age of 4 could possibly withstand more than 3 minutes of those hideous rodent voices without suffering permanent damage.
Rather than finding all this exhilarating, I found it exhausting and finally a little tedious.
I am haunted by it in ways I can't make entirely clear in my own mind. I'm also not sure I want to watch it again, though I feel I'll be drawn to do so.
As soon as the lights went up in the theater, I told my viewing companions that I honestly felt that seeing the film was a privilege.
A very pleasant -- if hardly overwhelmingly great -- animated Christmas fantasy with at least two inspired choices for voice casting.
Calling Anonymous Roland Emmerich's masterpiece ranks high on the list of most meaningless claims of 2011. But it's true.
The truth, though, is that it's entirely due to this plucked buzzard-from-hell puppet that anyone remembers the movie today.
Overall, though, I didn't find it particularly satisfying
It will almost certainly be in the top two or three on my 'best of 2011' list, and it's a film I can't wait to see again.
I do not think this is a bad movie. I merely think it's not a movie for me. I neither enjoyed it, nor did I feel like it had anything of note to say.
There are some innately human aspects to the film that transcend its other limitations and missteps.
The portrait is not sensationalistic -- and while I wouldn't go so far as to call it sympathetic, neither would I call it unsympathetic.
Condon can only do so much with the material at hand -- especially in this case, where maybe an hour of plot is stretched out to 117 minutes.
Stylistically the film is jaw-dropping -- somewhere between the French New Wave and an acid trip.
movie_title: Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors (Tini zabutykh predkiv) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Very nearly as inventive and fascinating as it is frustrating.
Perfectly cast, beautifully photographed and just startlingly good entertainment.
Becomes a human, believable and quietly moving film.
It's a remarkable portrait and one that makes My Week with Marilyn a special film and one of the season's must-sees.
One very off-the-wall movie that never for a moment bothers to make a great deal of sense.
It was exactly what I expected it to be, and I was fine with that.
One of those 'inspired by a true story' things as concerns its premise, but in reality it feels more 'inspired by Nicholas Sparks.'
Utterly disposable and -- apart from Dwayne Johnson's 'pec pop of love' -- almost immediately forgettable.
I can think of no reason why anyone who doesn't have small children -- or isn't a movie critic -- would have the least interest in seeing it.
In terms of Perry's oeuvre it's surprisingly light on the cheesy melodrama.
This is Ken Russell unfiltered -- straight-up and unafraid to go wherever his mind leads him. Absolutely unique.
At least close to being a great film. It's a film that lingers in the mind -- not in the least because it's so open to interpretation.
Isn't likely to entirely appeal to Cronenberg's core fans (whatever that is at this point), but it's a richly rewarding -- and sometimes disturbing -- film in its own right.
That the film manages to be touching without being maudlin, and to be smart without being mean-spirited, is perhaps what really seals the deal.
There seem to be somewhere in the neighborhood of 18 Stephanie Plum novels by Janet Evanoich. God save us if One for the Money catches on.
It all becomes just too testosterone-fueled to take seriously.
I don't think this was meant to be funny, but I found it pretty darn amusing.
The film's Cold War setting is part of what makes it work.
A two-and-a-half-star movie raised to four-star status solely on the performances of Meryl Streep and Jim Broadbent.
The comedy is bitter and uncompromising.
Has the allure of a freshness it may not entirely deserve, but one that makes it go down very smoothly.
The only Stephen Daldry film I've seen that I don't expect to feel the need to revisit.
Apart from being easily 15 minutes too long, the movie is harmless enough.
What sells the picture is Fields first -- and the teaming of him and Skipworth coming in a strong second.
The joys of the film -- and there are some -- come almost entirely from the interplay of Karloff and Lorre.
movie_title: The Boogie Man Will Get You (1942)

movie_review_blurb: Lifeless, joyless and charmless. It also consistently mistakes glumness for profundity. In short, it's an expensive and overbearing lox.
Beautifully made and stylish to no end -- even elegant. With an assured hand, McQueen has captured the uncomfortable juxtaposition of natural beauty and unnatural ugliness.
Just this week's kiddie-flick cash grab. How you'll explain to your tykes why you've stuffed and roasted Reggie in a few weeks is your concern.
Probably fine if you're a fan of the toy, and is undoubtedly the bee's knees if you're a shareholder in the company. If not...well, that's another load of bricks altogether.
There are good things in this combined coming-of-age and road trip story, but there's a hollowness to it -- not to mention a pretty unsatisfying ending.
Cheeky, good-natured, clever and even a little on the subversive side, Ant-Man is that rarest of comic-book movies -- one that manages to be personal and doesn't take itself too seriously.
It may be little more than a convoluted -- and fairly unpleasant -- mystery thriller, but it's largely effective and holds the interest.
Slick and often clever, but it's also too long, and the spectacle of Cruise trying to prove that age has not dimmed his physical prowess gets pretty silly.
A powerful, but not always comfortable portrait of a seemingly inevitable tragedy told with uncommon immediacy.
Put simply, I think it's very good -- sometimes even great. I like it a lot, and, in time, suspect I may well love it.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A noisy, cluttered actioner with loads of explosions, fights, chases and gun play -- featuring a star who built a career on spouting badly-crafted one-liners badly.
Everything you expect from Jeunet: playful filmmaking, a fanciful story, strange plot twists, delightfully eccentric characters and a lot more seriousness than it appears on the surface.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's not that I think Tarsem Singh's Self/less is a very good movie, it's that I don't think it's anything like the awful movie it's largely been painted as.
It's about a man in his final years finally opening himself up to his own feelings and those of other people. This is simply a beautiful and tender character study.
A mix of the brilliant and the basic -- a film that truly soars when it works, but doesn't quite work all of the time.
Del Toro owns the film. His presence, the threat of his presence, the sense of his reach pervades the movie, especially in its second half.
A stylish, intelligent entertainment for grown-ups with some splendid performances.
If indeed Hiromasa Yonebayashi's When Marnie Was There turns out to be the final film to come from Studio Ghibli, it would be hard to imagine a more elegant or appropriate farewell.
Better written, better directed and better acted than any film about rampaging dinosaurs has any right to be.
A completely refreshing take on the coming-of-age comedy that succeeds by hewing closely to the subgenre's tropes while deftly turning them upside down.
Refreshingly adult, sweet-tempered and rather special little romantic comedy-drama focusing on a generally underserved age group -- and presenting that group in a new light.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Packed with period songs and with a refreshingly unsentimental anarchic vibe, this could have been great. Unfortunately, it is seriously wanting in the villain department.
Manages to overcome the triple threat of a new director, being a prequel, and being the third film in a series. This really is a pretty terrific addition.
Just misses being one of Woody Allen's great films, this is still a worthwhile addition to his filmography and a must-see for admirers of the filmmaker.
It isn't very funny and its assaults on the tear ducts are ham-handed and, for me at least, missed the mark at almost every turn.
Manages the considerable feat of being tasteless and a damp squib all at once. In short, it combines "Yuck" and "That's it?" in one sinking fit of dumbness.
Entertaining look at two gigantic egos in conflict on national television -- and of historical significance as the birth of the political TV pundit.
Works pretty well as unintentional amusement whenever it goes completely insane. Unfortunately, it's mostly just inane, and that's not much fun.
In most respects, it's an improvement over its predecessor, but it's still more of the same with better characters. Watchable, but hardly essential.
Boldly honest and frank coming-of-age film that is at once daring in its subject matter, yet very much part of its genre. Good, but not quite great.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While too long and with little new light on Jobs' failings as a human being, the questions it raises about his cult status and the way he helped change the world make it worthwhile.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Good looking, sometimes incredibly tense mountain climbing documentary with effective use of biographical material.
Deeply political, but warm, human and completely engaging drama from British director Ken Loach.
Only really works when all the parts fit together. I found it hard to judge until the film ended. Up till then, I waffled back and forth as to whether or not I even liked it.
Fast, funny, appealing, perfectly judged -- a comedy and more --this may be Noah Baumbach's best film. Co-writer star Greta Gerwig and Lola Kirke are a dream pairing.
t's not so much that the movie is actively bad -- well, the largely dismissive attitude toward women is pretty bad -- as that it's almost aggressively mediocre.
Moderately successful attempt to capture the spirit of silent movie comedy with claymation sheep. More clever than outright funny.
Spare, unadorned and unsentimental crime thriller. Well done modern B-picture stuff that may be too cold-blooded for some viewers.
Richly compelling -- despite its unlikely story -- neo-noir drama of unusual emotional and psychological complexity. Another best-of-the-year contender.
It mostly tended to confirm my suspicion that all those kids toting the book around in high school and college probably had Rod McKuen posters on their walls, too.
A compelling -- and surprisingly entertaining -- slice of time spent with a famous writer, and the tensions and evasions and possible insights it brings forth.
It's a little calmer than most Guy Ritchie movies, but it's just right for the material. Terrific to look at, brisk, stylish, funny (but just serious enough) and beautifully cast.
A well-judged, slickly-made thriller that mostly eschews the trappings of the genre for more psychological unease and a disturbingly dark vision of the world.
Just another failed August mediocrity -- destined to come and go and be consigned to the heap of forgotten movies in short order.
While it's an improvement over the standard McCarthy vehicle -- at least she plays a character rather than a caricature -- this latest is too long and too predictable to fully work.
Overall, "Lambert & Stamp" is a fascinating documentary of two men, one of the great rock bands and a moment in time.
Sets out to prove that The Rock can go toe-to-toe with two earthquakes and a tsunami and come out on top by the sheer power of his biceps and a helpful screenwriter.
Bright dialogue and great chemistry between Al Pacino and the rest of the cast raise this fairly predictable comedy-drama to very enjoyable entertainment.
Remarkably elegant film from Ethan Hawke about his friend, classical pianist and sometime-composer Seymour Bernstein, is one of early delights of 2015.
Has a few missteps -- perhaps part of its quality -- that are hard to brush aside. Even so, it is a great film -- the first such of 2015.
Curtis has so carefully crafted the film, and Mirren and Reynolds have such terrific chemistry, that it mostly works -- and it works pretty well at that.
Wild Tales isn't much interested in tender sensibilities -- rather, it trades in deliberately outraging those sensibilities in bleakly funny and anarchic ways.
The kindest word that comes to mind is "undistinguished." Unfortunately, it's also uninteresting and uninspired - as well as tedious, noisy, obvious, annoying...
No, it's not a patch on the James Whale film, but it has its points as one of Universal's "silver age" (oft times, more like tin-foil age) outings.
Chock-full of melodrama and outrageous contrivances, there's no way to call Serena good, but it's one fascinating hot mess that's entertainingly trashy.
It is never just any one thing. It is - often simultaneously - scary, exciting, suspenseful and very funny. The characters are unusual and unusually well-defined.
While I don't quite think that David Robert Mitchell's It Follows is one of the scariest movies ever made, it is certainly one of the most unsettling.
I think it's a good -- albeit specialized -- film, but considerably shy of greatness -- perhaps because it seems so very convinced of its greatness and importance.
Exciting and very effective war thriller set during "The Troubles" in Northern Ireland. More thriller than political, but very well done.
It looks terrific. It's also faithful to a fault -- and that's exactly the problem, since it makes it on the dull, unadventurous side.

Nostalgic for a world he never knew and which never really existed, progressive-minded and a little reactionary at the same time, innately sad for the passing of an era, deeply humane, and, yes, with a dash of utterly arbitrary beefcake.
Not up to the original and probably doesn't need to exist at all, but this follow-up is certainly a fine way to spend a couple of hours with our old friends from the first movie.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's noisy, bloated, confused, derivative, singularly lacking in point and occasionally obnoxious. But at worst, it's just a forgettable mediocrity -- not some kind of crime against humanity.
It's often at its best when it's off on a moody tangent. But it has something and is well worth seeing, especially if you're a horror fan or a fan of art cinema
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As a spy movie, it may rarely be more than adequate, but the compensations make up for that.
It's the same old false shuffle dealt from the same old stacked deck.
It's all on the preposterous side, but it's done with such conviction and artistry that both its melodrama and its unabashed romanticism work.
It's the kind of film that seems to me shy of a masterpiece right now, but one where I may well find it to be with time and repeat viewings.
What we end up with is a bunch of truly unpleasant, self-absorbed teenagers yelling at each other on Skype -- all recorded in grating lo-fi to maximize the headache-inducing annoyance value.
Brilliantly conceived and almost as brilliantly realized, this is one of those rare musical biopics that truly gets to the essence of its subject -- and in a creative manner.
Glorious to look at -- at least when it sticks to black and white -- and keenly perceptive, this isn't your standard documentary for most of its length.
This look into a largely unknown aspect of pop music is a treat as it celebrates the faceless musicians behind some of the biggest hits of an era.
Put on a very simple level, "Tomorrowland" feels like science fiction grounded in Rev. Norman Vincent Peale's "The Power of Positive Thinking" -- minus the God stuff.
Splendid as drama and strong on character -- the four leads are exceptional -- this is one of the year's best films and easily one of the most visually beautiful.
Strong performances, a trenchant message and brilliant uses of imagery help to overcome a screenplay that leans toward preachiness.
While it isn't likely to change your idea of cinema (at least I hope not), isn't worth the hype and has its share of problems, this is one wild ride that's worth taking.
Best of all, it's a character portrait of of deli owner David "Ziggy" Gruber -- almost a biopic, that charts not only his work, but his personal life.
A good -- but not entirely likable -- film that might have been great but isn't quite, owing to a central character who becomes increasingly unsympathetic.
It's too big. It's too frenzied. It's too full of characters it can't contain. Mostly, it's just too much everything.
The zombie redefined as a disease-of-the-week family drama centered on a mopey teen zombie.
A very different movie than you think, this is a warm, generous, kindhearted film that dares to go places other such comedies fear to tread.
I hate to trot out this idea -- it's too close to the moronic 'they don't make 'em like they used to' -- but this is the type of film it would be hard to put together today.
It may look like a standard haunted house movie on the surface, but this is really a finely crafted supernatural thriller of a very different -- and startlingly complex -- kind.
movie_title: La casa del fin de los tiempos (The House of the End Times) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Remarkable and richly layered film examining the thin line between art and life, about change, aging, death and identity, built on splendid performances by Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart
A muddled mixed bag containing some fascinating ideas, a handful of terrific scenes and some good performances.
A great film? No, but it's a well made, fast-moving drama with some terrific performances that makes it worth a look.
It probably won't change many minds -- do these things ever? -- and it may not tell you much you don't know, but this is a solid and surprisingly effective activist documentary.
I'm going against the current on Daniel Espinosa's Child 44 by simply not hating it, but I'll go further and say it's actually good -- with qualifications.
Fast-paced, funny, filled with witty lines and yet suffused with a deep melancholy, Grandma provides Lily Tomlin with her best role in ages.
Imagine my delight at finding Jermaine Clement and Taika Waititi's What We Do in the Shadows thoroughly entertaining, amusing and even charming.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Small in scale and largely unassuming, both of which may be in the movie's favor, since it never tries too hard. The film seems content to just "be."
Basically just another violent movie about drug trafficking. It's efficient enough at what it does, but what it does is neither new nor significant.
What could have been 90 minutes of cringe-inducing comedy and debatable drama is instead a work of wit, delicacy and warm humanity.
You'd be hard pressed to find a better looking movie and a more interesting premise. But, dramatically, the film suffers from unlikable characters and a certain smugness.
An absolutely magnificent animated romantic drama that captures the essence of how our past informs our present. Touching, funny, realistic and quite wonderful.
Rich and strange mystical film that is filled to the bursting point with dream images and bizarre characters.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Brothers Grimsby proudly wears its sloppiness like a misspelled badge of honor.
With or without the Cloverfield business, 10 Cloverfield Lane isn't a bad movie, merely a predictable and largely mediocre one.
When the film gets past its often noxious first 40 minutes and becomes a more appealing story, this raunchy rom-com comes into its own.
Lavishly vulgar, completely disrespectful, gratuitously bloody -- and an awful lot of tasteless fun if you're not turned off by those things.
I was at least hoping for a grand, jaw-dropping folly (like Snyder's 2011 Sucker Punch), but got something far more ordinary.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not minding the experience is as close as I'm getting to to a ringing endorsement, and somehow "not minding it" doesn't strike me as something likely to end up on a DVD cover.
What we ultimately have is mostly no better or worse than a 1950s Biblical epic -- an economical one at that -- of the kind George Clooney is supposedly the star of in Hail, Caesar!.
Somehow, all its amassed fuss and bother and cleavage and silliness and more cleavage mostly turns out to be tedious.
Gorgeous to look at, clever, funny and with a solid and atmospheric mystery at its core. But there's more here in the film's timely and relevant thematic content.
A brain-dead, obnoxious, toxic lump of xenophobia, flag-waving, stock footage, crummy CGI, dismal performances and worse writing. The jackpot of bad movies.
By no means the disaster (at least artistically) it's been painted as, this is an unusual horror movie -- one that critiques and subverts its own genre.
Lighter than usual Moore documentary that operates in a unusually upbeat manner for the usually more provocative filmmaker.
The Coen Brothers in a gleefully playful mood with a film that at once spoofs and honors the last days of the old Hollywood.
The first film of 2016 should have been shot before it exited the paddock. Not only would it have been merciful, it would have saved me from 90 minutes of sheer tedium.
A charming, touching, absolutely delightful comedy-drama with a terrific Maggie Smith performance -- and an equally fine turn from Alex Jennings.
Michael Bay blows up stuff, unleashes massive firepower and concludes not much of anything in this jingoistic mess of a movie.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hiddleston is terrific in the lead role. Unfortunately, the film housing this performance has one of the most poorly structured scripts of all time.
A chilling look at modern warfare and its detached nature. But it's also a film that works as first-rate suspenseful thriller of a generally cerebral kind.
The acting is good -- especially from Dern in his over-the-top mode -- and parts of the film are exciting. But I draw the line at finding it to be any sort of a classic.
Sweet without being cloying, crowd-pleasing without being obviously manipulative, this is how this kind of tale ought to be told. See it now before Hollywood decides to remake it.
Yeah, you almost certainly know how this is going to play out, but that doesn't keep the film from being compelling and even fascinating.
Virtually impossible to synopsize and not even easy to describe. Let me just say that this a rather special movie.
While deploring the glorification of the Warrens, I can't deny that James Wan has made one creepy horror movie.
Is Genius a great film? I won't go that far, but it is intelligent and entertaining. And moving. I'll take that.
Something at once comic and surprisingly thoughtful -- a work of great delicacy and generosity. There's a magical, almost luminous, quality to Frot's portrayal.
It may be a minor treat, but it is a treat and a terrific showcase for Gerwig -- and what it affords Ethan Hawke and Julianne Moore ain't bad either.
A mix that director Vallée, screenwriter Brian Sipe and a first-rate cast manage to turn into a cohesive whole -- despite several changes in tone.
The last time I spent 86 minutes that lasted this long, dental work was involved.
Rude, raunchy, violent and very funny action-comedy-mystery with two great leads and a surprisingly terrific newcomer. All in all, I'd call it good unwholesome fun.
Susan Sarandon shines in this unassuming, likable and sometimes even surprising comedy that manages to miss nearly every pitfall.
Often witty, frequently exciting, but neither as modern nor as important as it seems to think it is. Viewed as entertainment, however, it's worth a look.
Thoroughly standard biopic that doesn't challenge the viewer but is uniformly entertaining, splendidly acted and strikingly intelligent.
Good-hearted, charming, winning little movie with doses of genuine magic -- and an authentic sense of time and place and youthfulness. It might restore your faith in the musical film.
It is obvious early on that Cheadle is giving us a combination shaggy dog adventure yarn and a marvelous portrait (not story) of the man and his music.
So much of the food and its unassuming nature -- and especially Gold's enthusiasm for it -- is, like the film itself, very appealing indeed.
Jeff Nichols latest, Midnight Special, is the writer-director's most complex and accomplished film to date.
It is Austen -- reasonably at least -- with a touch of Oscar Wilde and full-on Whit Stillman. Funny, appealing, civilized -- and fully aware of the artifice holding it all together.
Absolutely the only thing wrong with Kung Fu Panda 3 is that it's the third film in a series that is starting to show the inevitable signs of strain.
No matter how cosmically God-awful you think Fifty Shades of Black probably is, I assure you it's even worse than that.
I don't think I'd change a thing. It's the offhand, shambling, messy, sketchy quality that makes Joy such a special little movie. It's a movie I think time will treat kindly.
Stark, powerful, finely crafted, but inclined to redundancy in its excessive length.
It's powerful, and it's still timely, but 99 Homes is also obvious and increasingly less compelling as it goes on.
A deeply disappointing film from an incredibly talented filmmaker. It sometimes works. More often, it doesn't. It's mostly watchable, but it's a lot of fuss over not much.
It's better than you probably think, and children should love it. It looks good, is pleasant enough, but anything more than that -- probably not.
Guillermo del Toro's gothic horror, haunted house shocker -- perhaps the most visually striking film of the year -- is in a class by itself. A rich and effective horror movie.
Solid old-fashioned moviemaking with everything that implies. Sure, it's well-made and it does what it sets out to do, but there's an inescapable sense of ossification.
The first half is just not good, but it gives way in its second half to a movie that's very worth seeing to a degree that at least comes close to cancelling out the wonky first half.
It's nothing new under the sun, but this is a charmingly unassuming and often very funny little movie.
It's kind of the love child of Michael Haneke and Eli Roth, meaning that it's basically arty torture-porn, but made on tranquilizers.
Landing somewhere between art-house and solid mainstream entertainment, Pawn Sacrifice probably owes its art-house cred to its cast, subject matter and screenwriter Steven Knight .
It's well-made. It boasts a lot of good actors. It proves (if proof were needed) that Johnny Depp can underplay. But it's also neither particularly compelling, nor exciting.
I once denounced a Nicolas Cage movie as a 'moose fellation party.' This is more like a moose fellation orgy -- but with entrails.
Smart, lively, funny, raunchy, blessed with two terrific leads and a writer-director with real style. The downside? It can't entirely escape its rom-com tendencies.
A largely bland, extremely frantic animated horror comedy aimed at kids and Adam Sandler completists.
At once solid -- as concerns the basic story -- and disappointingly insubstantial -- as concerns creating a portrait of its famous subject.
Edging close to greatness, this is a very good -- albeit rather sad -- character study about friendship, addiction and the hope for redemption -- or the next closest thing.
Somewhere at the intersection of reality TV and a Coen Brothers picture lies Finders Keepers -- as peculiar and entertaining a story as you're likely to find.
Ridley Scott's The Martian may not be a great film, but it is great pop entertainment. For a full two hours and 20 minutes, it has the ability to hold an audience spellbound.
Effective, quirky and even downright strange, this sequel overcomes a bumpy start to become a minor delight of the fall season.
Smart, funny, emotionally affecting -- if maybe a little overstuffed -- film anchored to interesting characters is much better than you've perhaps been led to believe.
Much more than a 'disease of the week' movie, this is a sharply written, beautifully acted work that edges into the must-see realm.
Not only has Diesel plopped the mantle of Cage on his shoulders, he seems to have borrowed one of Cage's justly celebrated hairpieces.
The best film of the year has arrived - a grand banquet of sight and sound that is at once funny and tragic. This is an absolute must-see.
It's the kind of high-toned message picture that allows the viewer to feel safely progressive-minded with no personal risk.
It does exactly what it needs to be a crowd-pleaser in that regard. But whether it breaks any new ground ... not so much.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly pretty effective agitprop drama, but with an unfortunate tendency toward speech-making and a rushed -- and overly melodramatic -- conclusion.
A brilliant, blistering, angry and very awkwardly funny look at a tragic situation. A stylish, whirligig farce of a tragedy.
The visuals outweigh the words. Ideally, they should enhance the words, but here they tend to overtake them. I don't think it's the best approach to Shakespeare.
Not an outright disaster by any means, but neither is this seasonal horror picture anything to get excited about.
If you're old enough to read this, you're probably too old for the very thin story being told in Pixar's latest.
There's enough here that is both fresh and keyed in to the heritage of Frankenstein legacy to make Victor Frankenstein very worthwhile. That it also has something on its mind is even better.
A well-intentioned, large, brown movie that's inclined to be rather dull
Either a return to form, a winking homage to the whole series, or a dumbing down of the angsty, introspective Bond of the Daniel Craig era. Choose up sides.
Highly-acclaimed -- and admittedly unusual -- tale that doesn't live up to its premise or its reception.
Works as history, as justification for the value of real journalism and as a still relevant cautionary tale on the perils of willful ignorance.
The film seems less the problem than the idea that the story could, and should, be dramatized.
The cinematic equivalent of being deluged with fruitcake batter while an Osmond Family Christmas record plays on an endless loop.
Yeah, I've seen worse, but that could be said of many things without suggesting anyone else should.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly effective as drama and thought-provoking on every other level, Truth only stumbles owing to a tendency to preach, but not enough to sink the film.
Solidly made, largely entertaining, but hardly the groundbreaking work it's been touted as.
Far and away, the best thing about this latest is the claim that this is the last of the Paranormal series. I can think of no better Halloween treat -- assuming it's true.
Something a little different -- and very much the same, too -- from Britain's horror meister Tod Slaughter, The Crimes of Stephen Hawke is a pure melodramatic delight.
Among the year's more pleasant surprises in terms of blockbusters and would-be blockbusters is Matthew Vaughn's X-Men: First Class.
The lack of a normal story structure will baffle and even bore some viewers. But I highly recommend trying it. If you can tap into its vibe, it's amazing.
Perhaps no one over age 16 should ever see this movie. That may not be the worst advice I could give you.
The kind of movie where one is frequently told to park one's brain at the door. I have no doubt this would help, but even at the door, my brain would have raised objections.
A film that at once disturbingly deconstructs human behavior in an almost clinical -- and bitterly comic -- manner, while evidencing great warmth and fondness for its benighted characters.
It was strong stuff in 1925 and it remains strong today.
Noah's Ark isn't just a fascinating curio from a very bygone era, it's surprisingly entertaining -- and it is most certainly a spectacle of note.
Has a strange beauty, an intensely creepy atmosphere, and a grandly operatic feel.
Contains not one speck of the post-modern snark that has plagued animated movies for over a decade. It has no interest in being 'with it.'
I unreservedly love Richard Shepard's Dom Hemingway, and I strongly urge everyone with a taste for quirky, dark crime comedy of the British variety to beat a path to it.
The problem with the film comes from a tendency to not be able to deliver on its attempts at the Big Scares.
Turturro's major inspiration, and the thing that makes Fading Gigolo rather special, was teaming himself with Allen. They are a screen team made in heaven.
It is streets ahead of most of what we get that is labeled science fiction. It's intelligent. It explains its premise -- within reason. Its dialogue isn't chuckleheaded.
Sure, it has something to say, but it hardly feels like its out to change the world -- only a very small part of it. And it succeeds with sincere feelings and a beguiling charm
movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Everything you could hope for in a late 1970s-early 1980s horror picture -- and then some. It's exploitative, it's in crashingly bad taste, it's cheesy and it's pretty silly.
The trip is a rewarding one that ends on a note of bittersweet magic that is hopeful without being the least gooey. You need to see this film.
Seek out this beautifully made and acted little gem of a movie. You will not regret it, and I think I've just found one more 2014 release that will be on my Ten Best list.
It does a very good job of what it sets out to do. The question is whether or not I really care about what it does. Therein lies the problem. I don't think I really do.
Though it's certainly good -- and should be seen by discerning horror fans -- Oculus is a few scares shy of the 'instant classic' some are claiming.
A horror thriller of unusual complexity. It is also blessed with some of the blackest humor I've seen in a while.
Let's be honest, this movie is for the fans.
It's startling and it's not always easy to follow, but it's also amazing. It's unlike anything else and it's brilliant. I desperately need to see it again.
movie_title: Muriel ou Le Temps d'un Retour (The Time of Return) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: Is it creepy? Yes. Is it puzzling? Yes. Is it disturbing? Yes. Will it appeal to you? That's a hard call, but it will have an appeal to those looking for something out of the ordinary.
In the last 15 minutes, it won me over almost completely, but it wasn't enough to make me overlook the film's considerable shortcomings.

Elegant, somber, literary-minded, otherworldy, inexpressibly sad, sometimes very funny. Jim Jarmusch's Only Lovers Left Alive is both one of the most unusual vampire pictures ever made and probably one of the best.
Clever and fast-paced with a welcome streak of dark humor, this sci-fi actioner is undeniably entertaining, if ultimately not terribly substantial.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Alternately violent and tedious road movie of the post-apocalyptic variety that remains watchable thanks to some odd touches and an interesting performance from Robert Pattinson.
The Immigrant isn't a lot fun, but it's touched with a kind of greatness we don't see very often.
A clever, brisk, entertaining spy picture that has a lot more Ken Russell in it than you might suspect.
The great charm of Lukas Moodysson's We Are the Best! lies in its total lack of pretension and adult editorializing.
The kind of film where people tend to be quick off the mark to slap the term "masterpiece" on it -- a term that's in danger of becoming as meaningless as "classic" has already become.
At best, it's a watchable mess (right down to its prestige-picture muted color and Eastwood's trademark bad old-age make-up), but it is a mess.
It's mostly the meticulous filmmaking and those two performances that raise Pilgrimage to the level of art. There's not a misjudged moment and not an indifferently framed shot.

For all its classic-era echoes, the structure of The Railway Man with its nightmares, flashbacks and even outright fantasy scenes is fairly modern, making the film much more than an exercise in 'making them like they used to.'
What seems like a limited stunt concept turns out to be one of the most intense -- and cinematic -- experiences of the year, anchored to a brilliant performance by Tom Hardy.
It's not a particularly deep film, but it's one that takes the viewer through a labyrinthian chain of events that provides a wild ride that won't soon be forgotten.
Never feels like there's anything really at stake here, making it hard to be all that invested in the characters. Pleasant only takes you so far.
Stupefying in its unfunniness, arrogance and outright narcissism, A Million Ways to Die in the West is a shoo-in for my Worst of the Year list come December.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The best I can say about Maleficent is that it isn't as bad as I thought it would be, but that's faint praise indeed.
Typical lifestyles of the ennui-ridden overprivileged, but there are moments of near brilliance and an ending that makes up for much.

While the film manages to drag the actual attack out to 45 minutes of its ponderous 183 minute running time, that still leaves a lot of movie to be taken up by what passes for plot -- a convoluted romance of the heavily cliched kind.

The story is largely inessential, however. What counts -- apart from the glimpse into a long-vanished world and the remarkable technique of the film -- is how surprisingly compelling the lives of these characters are.
movie_title: Sous les Toits de Paris (Under the Roofs of Paris) (1930)

movie_review_blurb: I found the images occasionally striking, and sometimes bizarre, but I never connected with them in any meaningful way.
It lives. It breathes. It has a sense of humor. It is very probably the best comic book movie since Singer gave us X2: X-Men United back in 2003.
God may not be dead, but I'd be willing to wager this movie at least gave him a faint wave of nausea.
A brilliant film that is funny, marvelously creative and always just a little bit sad. Easily the best film to come along this year -- and it will probably still be at the end of the year.
The film is far from what we usually see.
An educational show with the addition of a moronic plot and a lot of poop and flatulence gags.
The kind of sensation that you only get from a master filmmaker and it restores one's faith a little in film for its own sake.
An almost perfect blend -- sometimes alarmingly bitter, sometimes sadly -- and amusingly -- sweet.
The uneasy peace that has existed lately between the cinema of Tyler Perry and me has been sorely tested by this one.
A profoundly entertaining collection of none-too-bright folks who think they're smarter than everyone else. And it's all set to the best soundtrack of the year.
Saving Mr. Banks is a confection and should be viewed as such. In that regard, it works admirably, which is all you can reasonably ask.
The first two-thirds of Catching Fire is truly compelling. Unfortunately, that last third is something else altogether.
Has nothing to do with the noble - and undervalued - art of plate spinning. (I confess this disappointed me slightly.) No, it's just an oddly titled documentary about three restaurants.
Standard issue in-the-bleak-midwinter animated kiddie movie.
This turns into a squabble that climaxes with Elsa going all Carrie-at-the-prom and freezing the kingdom, before storming off to sing a power ballad.
If Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto don't garner Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor nods, there is no justice in Oscardom.
It's a perfect soufflé of a movie -- or to borrow an apt phrase from Ian Anderson, it's a 'breath of champagne on a sparkling night.'
It may not be anything all that special, but it's harmless, well-made and entertaining on its own terms.
Helena Bonham Carter's Miss Havisham is quite the most fascinating incarnation of this character I've ever seen, and she's matched every step of the way by Ralph Fiennes as Abel Magwitch.
The sex scenes here look more like a lot of hard work than an outburst of passion. Gynecological? Perhaps. Erotic? Perhaps not.
This complete charmer of a movie delighted me from start to finish. In fact, About Time may well be the two most purely pleasurable hours I've spent in the cinema all year.
A surprisingly successful stunt. How successful it is will vary from viewer to viewer.
Not a great picture, but a curious and curiously involving one.
All in all, Black Dragons is deliciously silly with some magnificently dopey dialogue.
When told that space would be tight this week I asked if I could review Devil's Due by simply saying, 'Trust me, folks, this thing sucks a moose.'
Though The Invisible Woman is a good, surprisingly complex and thoughtful film -- it is about as far as it's possible to get from 'action-packed.'
Any way you slice it, I, Frankenstein is quite a few stitches shy of the classic monster.
A film of great nuance and substance that sucks you into its story without apparent effort.
Rockwell's presence and performance raises it to another level. He accounts for at least one star of my review.
I had a good time with Mr. Peabody & Sherman. It's funny, clever, well-made, entertaining and even a little touching without succumbing to outright gooeyness.
It's simple stuff -- finely wrought entertainment -- but on its own merits, it works.
This is poverty row gold.
The first of Lugosi's "personality" vehicles -- a film built almost entirely around Lugosi doing what can best be described as Lugosi-like things.

Less to do with making the Germans look good than it's about the perils of nationalism for its own sake, self-delusion, disillusionment and just plain getting sucked into something over which you have no control.
One thing is certainly true, however. The film's tagline, 'The only motion picture of its kind,' is undeniable. The results make it clear why this is still the case.
One of Fellini's most effective films -- probably the best of his neo-realist dramas.
movie_title: Nights of Cabiria (Le Notti di Cabiria) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: The film itself -- a quasi-autobiography of writer-director Cameron Crowe -- is still good, but not as good as it seemed 14 years ago.
The Wind Rises is a frequently remarkable film -- easily the best animated film of 2013 and fully of deserving its Oscar Nomination.
As a thriller, Omar is quite on a par with the slickest action suspense film, and its twists and turns keep it compelling on a pure entertainment level.
Hooked me from the first moment and kept me hooked all the way through.
I would not call it time well spent.
It's a very good exercise. I recommend the film -- so long as you realize that it's about as far from cheerful as you're likely to get, and emotional involvement may be hard to find.
A lumbering monstrosity of a movie with all manner of preposterous hairstyles and improbable fashions. Worth seeing -- once anyway -- at least as wayward legend.
It was almost touching to reach the end of Vampire Academy and find that it not only left itself open for a sequel, but seemed so certain of that eventuality that it set one up.
Is The Monuments Men a disappointment? Yes, it is, but it isn't a crashing disappointment.
This is quite simply glorious filmmaking.
Not as fresh or funny as its 2010 predecessor but with a bang-up second half, much visual beauty and a surprising emotional resonance.
It is a difficult movie -- at once bitterly funny, deeply unsettling and sometimes a little silly. That's not a bad description of Hollywood and the cult of celebrity, too.
Isn't the worst bag of Beelzebub buffoonery to ever douse audiences with holy water. This does not make Deliver Us from Evil good.
Everything about it is so indie that it feels like it's following a formula as rigid as that of any romcom or teen-meat-on-the-hoof slasher picture.
The movie has no real identity and feels like it was made by a committee.
All too often the film seems too much like canned theater -- a mere recording of a stage event.
Annie is not the awful film it's been painted as. In fact, it has much in its favor.
One of the richest, most personal, most beautiful, most disturbing and ultimately strangest films of the year.
Calling it the best horror picture of the year -- though it is -- does it a grave disservice, since it is, in fact, one of the best horror films of our relatively young century.
Rarely, however, has its visual beauty been equaled.
Nothing but a vanity project for Jackie Gleason. The concept and story is his. The overbearing musical score is his. He's onscreen nearly all the time.
The results -- with Richelieu dividing his time between bringing young lovers together and saving the country -- are pretty specious as history, but they're certainly entertaining fun.
Is The Imitation Game middlebrow stuff as some have claimed? In a sense, yes, it probably is, but that doesn't prevent it being compelling entertainment.
The good news is that Mockingjay 1 is better than its predecessors. The bad news is that it would, I feel certain, be all but incomprehensible to anyone who hadn't seen those films.
Has great moments, not so great moments and some pretty old hat moments, but it's unfailingly interesting.
A punishing 110 minutes of flatulence, diarrhea, bad malapropisms, infantile sex gags and gross-out jokes that are gross without the impediment of actually being funny.
Strong, sharply focused, straightforward activist documentary that allows its anger to be simply conveyed by amassing the facts and letting those directly impacted speak for themselves.
I really cannot find anything specifically wrong with the film in a strict sense. But I am left with a profound sense of "so what?" by the movie.
Fairly appalling flapdoodle starring a bunch of generically pretty, "good-enough-for-TV" actors you've never heard of as teens ill-advisedly screwing around with a Ouija board.
Invariably entertaining and -- better still -- it's a horror movie with more on its mind than making you jump or grossing you out.
Wisely banks on the inherent cool factor of Murray's presence to keep it from completely being subsumed by the treacle pit of sentiment it perilously navigates.
This is a movie that fully earns its every emotional pull and has the wisdom -- and structure -- to dole them out through the film with amazing canniness.
Solidly good Brit Oscar Bait.
If ever a movie could be said to have too much of everything, this outburst of hallucinatory psychedelia is it. But there are times where too much is exactly what is called for.
This is a rich, richly entertaining, often very funny movie with fine characterizations, and it definitely deserves your attention.
I can't deny that The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death is a good looking, decently made ghost story. What I also can't deny is that it mostly just doesn't work, isn't scary and drags.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Cheeky, rude, stylized, stylish, in crashingly bad taste and with something to offend absolutely everyone. In short, check it out.
There is a very good chance that I will see nothing worse all year. I'm pretty sure I will see nothing more brain-witheringly stupid and boring -- or less sexy.
High, Wide and Handsome is a fine film - beautiful to look at, stylish and very entertaining. It gets better every time I see it, too.
The most notable thing about it is that even with the amazing aggregation of asininity crammed into its running time, it still manages be a thudding bore.
I'm saying it could have been more worthwhile and aware than it is. As for the film, it has two strong performances and enough grace notes to make that a solid yes, you should see this.
It's big. It's goofy. It's highly imaginative. It has a little something on its mind. And it's fun. In other words, it's a film from the Wachowskis.
The boys from Belgium have made a good film here, but not, I think, quite a great one. That it's built around a very good performance certainly helps.
The most startling thing about it is that anyone thought this story needed telling a third time -- and not just one anyone, but a group of them had to come to this crackpot conclusion.
There are people who can resist lines like, 'He forced my little girl to listen to original Broadway cast albums while he had his way with her,' but I am not one of those people.
You may not like it, but it's hardly the worst movie ever made. It isn't even anywhere near the worst movie released this month.
Creature with the Atom Brain is so very 1950s -- right down Richard Denning as the pipe-smoking egghead scientist who puts together the solution -- that it's a delight.
A remarkable work -- so far ahead of any live-action (well, mostly live-action) family movies that it would be disgraceful to mention it in the same breath with them.
Is Cake a great picture? Oh, good heavens, no. This is a small, unassuming movie that does contain an impressive performance from Aniston -- even without the nomination.
Miller's often ponderous detachment gives the film the kind of gravitas -- real or illusory -- that keeps it from seeming to be the kind of tabloid trash its story basically is.
What makes the film -- for any of its shortcomings -- such a vital work is how relevant its depiction of the events of 50 years ago are to today.
What might have been a penetrating film about the war and its after-effects becomes a standard war movie that often feels like a shooter videogame.
Whether or not the film strikes a blow for free speech, it most certainly strikes one for lowbrow humor and dubious taste.
In a sense, Mauvais Sang is a poetic, tragic love story (actually three love stories) disguised as a B movie.
What makes the film work is really found in its occasional shock effects combined with its utterly straight-faced acceptance of the supernatural and the overall atmosphere it generates.
Essentially a very old-fashioned war movie -- but one tricked out with post-"Saving Private Ryan" gore. That may or may not be a bad thing.
Every time the story strays from Sir Wilfrid, the interest level goes down a notch. Fortunately for the viewer, it doesn't get away from him very long at any point.
The filmmakers may not have made a great movie, but they have a remarkable subject.
Boasts a mad scientist (Bela Lugosi), RKO's unasked for answer to Abbott and Costello (Wally Brown and Alan Carney) and a mischievous monkey for simian value.
The segments are uneven -- the curse of the portmanteau format -- but each of the three has merit, and the central one with Edward G. Robinson is a standout.
A wildly enjoyable minor Ford work, loaded with all manner of Ford touches, and one truly disturbing sequence that seems to come out of nowhere.
A luminous Helen Mirren leads a first-rate cast in this familiar but thoroughly charming and appealing culture-clash, food-centered romantic comedy.
A sparkling champagne cocktail of a romantic comedy only Woody Allen could make. It may be lightweight -- though perhaps not entirely -- but it's a little slice of cinema heaven.

movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The things that are good about Jen McGowan's debut feature are so very good that it would be altogether too easy to overpraise the film -- and that would do no one any favors.

An improvement over run-of-the-mill movies of its type. The screenplay is generally intelligent, characters are surprisingly well-defined, and the acting is above average.
Splendid on nearly every level.
A sadder, more penetrating - yet still very funny - work that may linger in the mind longer than The Trip.
