Our star-crossed lovers are so emotionally off-channel, it's easy to forget the origin of the film's title...
With little room for either narrative detail or character development, Tarsem's exploration of a deranged mind soon loses momentum.
McGregor's and Judd's attentive, focused performances never allow their characters to become lost in Elliott's fractured, virtual America.
The movie may have been designed to shift Pokémon product but it also comes down hard on the side of friendship, mutual respect and resourcefulness.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The Siege attempts to update the bluffs and counterfeints of the Cold War spy thriller, not to advance any ideological point but to obscure the fact that it doesn't have one.
[An] expertly plotted Nordic noir.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mikkel Norgaard, the director, propels the story by smartly sticking to the formula he used in the previous film: hints of menace, gorgeously shadowed shots and long flashbacks.
Sure, you could point out a few shortcomings here and there. But those sins are easy to overlook.
movie_title: A Conspiracy of Faith (Flaskepost fra P) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If the screen went dark during "The Music of Strangers," that would be a disappointment. But if the sound failed, that would be a tragedy.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Don't expect simple answers in "Germans & Jews." Just prepare for formidable questions. Those are the real reasons to see this incisive documentary.
Mr. Allen has made an engrossing and tense documentary, though his insider knowledge is sometimes a hindrance.
To be sure, nothing in this film is easy to hear. But that doesn't mean that it shouldn't be said, and learned from.
As lovely as the movie is to look at (and the final scene is exceptionally wonderful), it's too oblique to concentrate its energies and sharpen its focus.
It's a movie whose good heart is outweighed by its heavy hand.
I must have breathed while watching "Cash Only." But it sure felt as if I didn't. This brutal and severe film has that effect.
A stylishly shot, eerily scored and moodily acted film that wants for nothing but a plot. Depending on how you like your movies, this is either a walkout or a must-see.
This documentary, consisting almost entirely of his recollections in his own voice, does a pretty good job of outlining his life and his terribly dangerous times.

It's appealing to adults and accessible to younger viewers. And it delivers an environmental message that is strong and serious while remaining encouraging and optimistic. That's important to hear. The rest is just amazing to watch.
"Indian Point" is a good overview of the issues, with insights into the problems of regulating the industry.
"Defying the Nazis: The Sharps' War" is a generic documentary about two people who were anything but. Yet even when the film wanes, its subjects still come across as remarkable.
movie_title: Defying the Nazis: The Sharps' War (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With its charming actors, "For a Few Bullets," directed by Pan Anzi, has its heart in the right place, I suppose. Where its head is, though, I can't quite say.
The tension in "Citizen Soldier" is enough to make you gnaw through your fingernails.
art scrappy, part sweet and wholly enjoyable, "The Lost Arcade" is a love letter to a vanished piece of New York, and a little wish for the future.
From start to finish, it's absorbing.
movie_title: The People vs. Fritz Bauer (Der Staat Gegen Fritz Bauer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Making a Killing" generates a disgust that can't be shaken.
movie_title: Making a Killing: Guns, Greed, and The NRA (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like a funny friend in a melancholy mood, this film has humor at its center, even during its saddest scenes.
Floyd Norman doesn't think he's special. Many others know differently, and for those who need more proof, "Floyd Norman: An Animated Life" is delighted to supply it.
There are several ways to look at these scenes. But all you really have to do is listen.
movie_title: The Academy of Muses (La academia de las musas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [A] trauma that only people who have experienced it can truly comprehend.
The story behind "Landfill Harmonic" is so good that even some imperfect filmmaking can't hold it back.
Even though Martine and John are capable adults, you find yourself wanting to encourage them on their journey, and also to remind them that it's O.K. to feel sad sometimes. In fact, it's normal.

You won't walk away with a degree in business or psychology after watching "Silicon Cowboys." But this documentary leaves you with a curious feeling that you've earned college credit in both, and gotten a few laughs as well.

Connor Jessup wonderfully inhabits the teenage Oscar, who observes others while trying to find himself. Aaron Abrams, as his father, and Aliocha Schneider and Sofia Banzhaf, as friends, are just as multilayered.
Approaching the story for the traditional trappings - narrative, action, even logic - is to ensure disappointment. But look to it for beauty and lyricism, and you may find a deeper satisfaction.
Tough. As in, tough to watch. Tough to consider. Tough to ignore.
movie_title: How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate Can't Change (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Right from the start, this involving documentary asks much of its audience and poses questions that are unnerving yet engrossing.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie that promises an "epic journey" to explore a family's "long-buried suffering," it's strangely unsatisfying, and eventually wearisome, to find that this clan is deeply troubled perhaps only in the eyes of its filmmaker.
For this director, exposition can't hold a candle to elegantly staged shootouts. And who can blame him. He knows his strengths.
There's a whole lot of hogwash in "Secret of Water," a cheesy documentary stuffed full of pseudoscience masquerading as profound truth.
Even with sections recalling both "The Crucible" and an "Afterschool Special," it still fashions a story that's fairly fresh and often absorbing.
The fragmented and existential atmosphere, reminiscent of a Paul Auster novel, is an interesting reward for sticking with the tale.
There might be an engaging film buried beneath the severe dialogue, portentous music and ominous shadows of "1915." But a relentless and heavy-handed script makes the effort to find it seem futile.
You may miss a few moments of "An Open Secret," either while looking away during its unsettling stories or closing your eyes in frustration. This potent documentary elicits those kinds of reactions.
Even knowing the secret of "A Gay Girl in Damascus" doesn't make this documentary any less tense. That's a testament to Sophie Deraspe, a director who understands how to let a plot unfold.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Once an idea is introduced, it's tossed aside, unexplored; though there's plenty of talk, this isn't exactly a sci-fi "My Dinner With Andre." Tense music substitutes for genuine tension.
It's as if Mr. Pedro were one of those peppy neighbors who simply must show you all the video he took on his latest vacation, outtakes and all.
movie_title: Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It certainly demands patience (and a forgiving eye) as it experiments with an odd style. Yet it's also a compassionate look at characters who don't dwell on life.
As the terror shifts from suggested to explicit, the eeriness wanes and this supernatural story becomes muddled.
The makers of "A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story" leave a few too many questions unanswered, but their subject's immense optimism steamrolls through the documentary's shortcomings.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful documentary that follows a group of disabled adults who work together to make a movie.
Catalina Aguilar Mastretta's script is free of speechifying and delivers just enough story line to keep a plot in motion; words are rarely used when expressions can better convey feelings.
An exceptionally absorbing documentary.
So resolved to tell you something that it never notices it's overtelling you everything.
movie_title: The Prime Ministers: Soldiers and Peacemakers (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Really, when a film works this hard to rouse you, there's no shame in just giving in.
This is a film that holds tight to its sorrow while trying not to scare you away.
Long before the director inserts scenes from her own wedding video into "Rock in the Red Zone," it's apparent that she's grown quite close to her subject.
Despite a lackluster start, this documentary redeems itself by the finale.
It's a fond and forgiving tribute to the man, filled with music that moves beyond happy and sad, and toward something like brilliance.
movie_title: Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Struggles aren't ignored here; they're just surmounted with patience and devotion. That may be a good strategy in life, but it can be static to watch on screen.
Though the timeline and a few details could use further clarification, "dream/killer" remains fast-paced and frightening.
Granted, you don't watch a documentary about sustainable agriculture for "Star Wars"-type thrills. Yet you may still find yourself quietly cheering for the low-key rebels of "Polyfaces."
There are three good laughs in "Mountain Men" and two modestly dramatic sections. That averages out to a decent moment every 18 minutes.
A remarkably enjoyable, and sometimes very funny, documentary about a frightening topic.
Whether the actresses believe the girl's story, I can't say. But they know how to act as though they do.
While it can be frustrating to see some filmmakers dash off copies of other movies, it's deeply enjoyable to find one who so appreciates his inspirations.
Because of its shortcomings, "(T)error" serves as evidence of a broken system rather than an indictment of it. Yet such evidence is worrisome and points to a threat to civil rights.
At its best, "The Wanted 18" follows a worthy tradition of highlighting absurdities that arise during conflict ...

Take "Ice Road Truckers," mix it with "The Martian" and blend in a book of verse, and you've got something that resembles "Passage to Mars," a beguiling documentary that's concerned as much with images as it is with information.
Sure, the filmmakers overdo their work. But it's all in the service of love, and somehow that makes it O.K.
Several times in "Chronically Metropolitan," a man stares at a screen as nothing happens. You'll know just how he feels.
Here the filmmakers take a chance and turn a strange-seeming premise into a fast-moving tale.
It's possible to admire each scene and still see this film, in its entirety, as in need of some serious sharpening.
You've seen it all before, though it's pleasant enough to watch again.
As a girl, she says, she had wanted to be a dancer. In some way you can see that in her work: She has made activism an art form.
Mr. Davidman ends up not far from where he begins - his first line is "It's complicated." But that doesn't mean nothing is gained.
This potent film gives equal weight to complex emotions as well as bare facts. In the same way, it's not just the story of a man's death, but also a study of the aftermath.
"Bobbi Jene" may interest viewers who are well versed in contemporary dance. All others are on their own.
The script relies on subtext and Ms. Nowlin's expressions to convey her condition. She's up to the task; even in the many silent moments, she's compelling.

Like a "Black Mirror" episode combined with a philosophy seminar, "Realive" has plenty of brains. Yet it has a heart, too, and that adds a surprising amount of emotion to this above-average science-fiction film.
Even when its plot starts to sag, "Walking Out" remains beautiful to watch.
Though this film doesn't give definitive answers on what happened to Ms. Johnson, it keeps her memory alive. That itself is a victory over indifference.
movie_title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Diamond Island" feels like a little dream; a film that, at the end, you don't finish as much as awaken from.
Like a haiku, "The Departure" weighs its words carefully. But silences, too, play a vital role here.
Nightmarish stories intertwine with dreamy visuals to create an unsettling, and strangely entrancing, film in "Tempestad."
"Mully" isn't much in the way of cinema. But its courageous subject makes this documentary's shortcomings easier to overlook.
The film remains engaging for its stories, and is likely to be more instructive in the future, when passions have cooled. Judging by most people here, that won't be soon.
The truth turns into a tangled mess in "A River Below," a bold and urgent documentary whose seemingly straightforward story quickly runs awry.
While there may be no completely dispassionate way to discuss its topic - the Armenian genocide - the film's balance of emotion and composure helps make its stories even stronger.
For such a cerebral documentary, "The New Radical" packs a wicked punch.

Everyone interviewed in this sobering documentary - Israeli or Palestinian - agrees that something must be done to stop the bloodshed in their land. But even talking about solutions proves problematic.
No matter the topic, Mr. Kirchheimer keeps "My Coffee With Jewish Friends" accessible, and cerebral without a shred of pretension.
The filmmakers are determined to sound a wake-up siren, and they blast it here with extra strength.
Dashed hopes, breathless victories and painful regrets make up "Shot in the Dark," a documentary that has the rhythm of some spare yet deeply felt street poetry.
A documentary that's remarkably engaging despite treating its rough-and-tumble hero with kid gloves.
During military battles, bullets whiz by and explosions shake the cameras. Nerve-racking scenes follow Ukraine's extraordinarily bold volunteer soldiers.
movie_title: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine (2018)

movie_review_blurb: While it is maddening to see the aversion to open-minded education by Mr. Aziz ("'Progressive thought' is dying," he declares, pleased), we also see the stark poverty that leaves others with few choices but to follow him.
Nuttier than a bakery full of fruitcakes and sleazier than a cheap strip club, "68 Kill" is a proudly morbid heist movie that wallows in bad taste and still comes off as absurdly funny.
Mr. Fogel could be considered either daring or foolhardy for his initial plan. But his work with Dr. Rodchenkov is levelheaded, and his documentary illuminating.

My heart broke a little near the end of "Menashe," a sweet comedy that's not without a bit of sadness. For sure, this funny and tender film prompts cheerful smiles, but sometimes they turn melancholy.
Here's what sounds like one dud job: calculating bird populations in Antarctica. But here's what that work has inspired: one swell documentary.
While this sober documentary about rape during wartime treats those words and its subject with the required gravity, there are also moments of inspiration.
Scenes ... make you want to scream in frustration at the bureaucracy faced by combat veterans seeking mental health services.

This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isn't shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.

While more information on the animals and their ecosystems is needed, the stakes described here are immense, as is the sorrow over majestic creatures massacred only so that their tusks can be made into baubles.
"Asperger's Are Us" rarely stretches to be funny or poignant or touching, and that makes this documentary all the more of each.
"Ali and Nino" aspires to epicness and comes pretty close to getting there.
Mr. Fessenden's ambition is admirable, and there's more than a little raw skill on display. If this, his first feature, isn't always worth recommending, his talents are certainly worth encouraging.
If there aren't many big laughs here, there are enough smiles to make the time pass pleasantly enough.
A very fine film.

There's a lot to laugh at, and to learn from, in "Tickling Giants," a documentary that starts off by telling the story of one man and ends up speaking volumes about satire, freedom of expression and political pressure.
The art is the star and Ms. Axelrod features plenty of it.
The barbarity described in "Finding Oscar" is stomach-turning, but moments of courage still shine through in this unsettling yet vital documentary.
It's been a terrific few years for music documentaries, and that winning streak continues with "Rumble: The Indians Who Rocked the World."
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This documentary serves as a feature-length advertisement for the artist, and is about as daring as a billboard for skim milk.
True, discussions of art tend to be subjective and open-ended. But these works were made to be debated with a passion that is sometimes lacking here.
You'll have to wade through several topics to get to the heart of "Legion of Brothers," but once you're there, some intense stories make the effort worthwhile.
Joe Piscatella, the director, dives in immediately to set a speedy pace. He also provides a quick summary of Hong Kong's recent history, and looks to the future.
Aspirations matter, and the cast members remain dedicated to their brooding roles as the script admirably reaches for emotions it only sometimes captures.
Michael Bonfiglio, the film's director, provides a concise overview of the issues.
It should go without saying, but Mr. Greenleaf knows it's worth showing: On the field and off, we are all so much alike.
As stinging as a slap in the face, "Paulina" feels as if it's waking you from a stupor, then shaking you, demanding that you ask yourself some impossible questions about idealism and justice.
"All the Rage" overrides most of its shortcomings by keeping a breezy tone and by showing Dr. Sarno to be a convincing speaker, as well as an affable and somewhat crusty character.
If we don't always know what drives Curie, we see the determination itself. That's enough to keep the film moving along.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You may find yourself championing its subjects even while feeling confounded by the omission of details by its filmmaker.
These personality-free characters fade from your mind even as you're watching the screen, making the brutality waged against them akin to animated mutilation of cartoon creatures.
The portraits drawn of these young people frequently feel half-finished. As soon as a story or a profile turns compelling, the movie switches to another topic.
The humor is dry and the acting deadpan in "Women Who Kill," a comedy that plays it droll and is all the funnier for it.
It's hard not to be inspired by a life this well lived.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary that is as rewarding as this artist's work.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As blandly lucid as Barney is wildly and perplexingly imaginative.
Sillen finds nobility in the poet's ceaseless commitment to observation, self-examination, and what he called just plain "doing your job."
movie_title: I am Secretly an Important Man (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "Toy Story" goes Shakespearean in this animated retelling of the tale of the star-crossed lovers of Verona.
[A] moving, lyrical account ...
A Balinese dancer, an African tribesman, a disfigured marine, a Japanese stripper all stand composed, confident, and dignified, daring you to break the gaze.
Red Riding Hood is actually a fun, goofy ride, albeit one lathered in chintz and froth.
A tween-baiting update that sullies the elegant fairytale with privileged brats in penthouses. Beastly is a crass, spirit-sapping bore.
A potential cult hit in the making, call this Dazed And Confused for the Members Only set.
This extremely formulaic time-waster offers little beyond its lame Hallmark greeting-card platitudes.
Carrey fans will be let down by the rubber-faced one playing straight man to a pack of penguins. While kids may find the plot p-p-past its sell-by date.
Graham is lovely and Beatty a natural, but if you're not seven years old, it's one long headache.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [Leaves] you with nothing more than a few poke-y moments and wistful memories of Piranha 3D.
If you can get past the hokey premise, then you could be in for a good time with this lumbering 3D disaster-porn noisemaker.
Heigl's fine and there's some zingy dialogue, but the violence jars with the comedy and, despite being written and directed by women, it still comes off as needlessly sexist.
A low-budget, low-watt belly botherer saved from history's dustbin by a few gruesome moments and a gob-smack of an ending that (almost) makes it worth the slog.
Despite its meagre budget, Grave Encounters boasts surprisingly solid acting, vertigo-baiting hand-held camera antics and enough [REC]- style shock-horror to keep your pulse throbbing throughout.
Quote not available.
Luc Besson's clunky, space-bound actioner apes '80s B-flick excess but skimps on all the good parts.
Diaries is dark and gruesome, but with little in the way of genuine shock or surprise, you should expect the expected.
In this doomy surburban horror the real terrors don't come from space.
Although only slightly more outrageous than reality, The Campaign is a funny, pacy peek behind the political curtain.
Savages is punishing in places, but there are enough colourful characters and careening twists to make it worth the effort.
Very weird fun.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Sparkle isn't Dreamgirls - but fans of schmaltzy showbiz fairytales should enjoy it.
Fans of Pine's eyebrows will enjoy all the bushy furrowing, but otherwise, there are more important things to cry about.
105 painful minutes of a fat guy getting punched in the face and falling down.
Grisly and goofy, this ode to the Shaw Brothers' '70s-era kung fu epics serves up 96 minutes of murder and mutilation and not a lot else.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Gleeks and Glee-haters alike should rally around this raucous musical comedy.

A series of musty gross-out gags ranging in sophistication from sperm bank hijinks to sloppy man-on-man kissing, Bob Odenkirk's cringemaker-with-a-heart is a ragged Xerox of Dumb And Dumber that seems incredibly creaky after the summer of Superbad.
The leads are fine, but the movie's about as fun as summer school.
Fairytale horror that is low on scares and velocity but buoyed by the syrup-thick atmosphere and the creepy stares of the young actresses.
A wasted opportunity: put the two leads in a movie that didn't lazily rely on its high concept to do the work, and you'd really have something to laugh about.
Loud, predictable fun from Simon 'Con Air' West.
A thoughtful, slow-boiling, politically charged thriller. It takes an hour for Dwayne to become The Rock, but it's worth the wait.
If teens battling soldiers sounds like your cup of tea, drink deep. If not, stick with Red Dawn.
They're estranged. Tired antics ensue.
Cat lovers may be unnerved, but fright fans will just yawn their way to the exit.
Generic, yes, but gleeful with it.
where the number-one superguy used to solve crazy mix-ups like this in 15 minutes, The Cleaner takes a laboured, exposition-larded hour and a half.
If you thought She's All That was all that, this will pass the time for you - but if you thought She's All That was all that, well, so would practically any film.
Cube's maudlin, overly precious relationship with his son hits a few sour notes, but Morgan's rubbery, half-crazy Leejohn always drags the film back into its manic, cartoony groove.
Strange Wilderness is a never-ending bundle of self-consciously raunchy skits aimed at under-achieving slackers who are too high to notice how desperately pathetic it all is.
The stench is still thick on the corpse of Meet The Spartans, but apparently filmgoers can't get enough of lame-duck lampoons from Scary Movie alumni.
Well-dressed, sure, with a few kicks for green teens, but hardly a wild night.

Space Chimps tries to please both kids and parents with a queasy mix of rapid-fire, Looney Tunes-y slapstick and sly pop culture references, but the surprisingly flat animation and tired jokes keep it from ever leaving orbit.
As expected, his plan unravels within minutes of leaving the driveway.
Jay Lee's wannabe cult flick will draw cackles from forgiving fans of cheap'n'cheesy sexploitation.
Recalling the shmaltziest bits of similar city-slicker-meetsbumpkin romcoms like Doc Hollywood and Sweet Home Alabama, New In Town is pure Valentine's Day drivel.
Hampered by the 15 rating, director David S Goyer is reduced to yawn-worthy jump-scares and recycled Exorcist gags to do his dirty work.
Not Easily Broken is 99 long minutes worth of sobbing and hand wringing, with little insight and even less humour. Deadly stuff.
Fun, witless and pretension-free, 12 Rounds is Die Hard meets Saw meets WWE: pure chest-thumping testosterone cinema, edited like a jackhammer and delivered at thrash-punk velocity.
Although they're all indebted to some other film, there are some nice touches here.
Lurching woozily between daytimesoap psychodrama and a brainless, claws-out, pseudo-feminist slasher flick, Obsessed is one boiled rabbit away from bad-film nirvana.
It's a novel premise, but an unworkable one.
Toothless and obvious, even its 'best' gag - a farting-ballerina set piece - was done more effectively, for free, on YouTube a year ago.
Pure eye-poking, boob-baring raunch that will tickle your inner idiot and wind up everyone else something rotten.
Armored's first half is an overwrought, eye-rolling bro-venture, but once the actual robbery takes place, the film ratchets up into a solid testosterone-soaked thriller.
It's a two-ton nuclear warhead of aggressive lameness, a hard, pounding rain of flop sweat and triteness and depression.
Filled with slapstick guffaws, dodgy accents and copious pratfalls, Brian Levant's light-hearted action comedy succeeds because it stays true to what it actually is: a kids' movie.

Classic underdog vs smug establishment stuff, you might think. But it's all played out in puke-slathered anti-comedy sketches better suited to no-budget YouTube videos than a multimillion-dollar film.
There isn't a kid alive who could possibly buy into the soulless treacle that serves as sentiment here. Forgettable mush.
To quote Clint Eastwood's Monco in For A Few Dollars More, you people need a new sheriff.
It's marginally sharper than the likes of Meet The Spartans -- yes, that good -- but essentially as tatty as a porn parody, without all the best bits.
Directed with bland efficiency by the typically family-friendly Andy Fickman (Race To Witch Mountain, The Game Plan), You Again never seems to find the tone it's aiming for.
A retro-stylised fantasy-satire that balances knowingness with affection, winning kids and olds over in the process. Wry, spry and very funny.

Any potential retro-charm is quickly rubbed out by creepy CGI, a tired reality-TV conceit and failure to grasp that Yogi's appeal lies in his delivery and quick wit, not eye-stabbing 3D gimmicks or life-like depictions of picnic-basket heists.
Marred by cheapjack CGI and poor character design (the squishy-faced critters look like they came out of a cereal packet, not outer space), this very kid-centric caper is numbingly mediocre.
An orgy of bloody explosions that'd be tough to endure if it weren't so inadvertently self-parodic.
Eight years on from Wedding Crashers, [Vaughn and Wilson] successfully rekindle their irascible shtick.
A jagged, unbalanced (in every sense) revenge flick that nonetheless offers up twists and brooding noir-ness.
Director Ivan Reitman jazzes the talky proceedings up with split screens and transitions galore, but it's still just a minor-league Moneyball.
More character-driven than gory, The Calling is a slow-burner, but it's laced with pitch-black humour and appealing character quirks.
Fun in parts but mostly big, dumb and LOUD, the new TMNT is essentially Transformers in a half-shell.
While enthralled with its own retro-futuristic trappings at heart, this is a pitch-black dramedy with a mean-streak.
Serviceable, but entirely predictable.
The predictable script lulls you into laughing at some very tired gags, but at least Hart refrains from screaming through the whole thing.
A film that plays like the most disposable Saturday-matinee fodder imaginable.
By the end you will quite possibly hate cats, Spacey, and the '80s.
It's not funny or inspirational, just loud and trite.
There is less depth to this film than a petrol station greeting card, but it's essentially harmless.
Though the title guarantees uplift, this gruelling drama spends an hour dragging you into a well of depression.
Some decent jump scares here and there, but the best part of the whole ordeal is watching Cohan keep an admirably straight face through this nonsense.
A harmless kids' toon that's probably the least annoying Schneider vehicle in years.
Yet another young adult novel gets squashed into a bland, Saturday afternoon time-waster.
It'd be a complete eye-roller if not for the ferocious Hahn ripping through the thin script like a comedic atom bomb.
There are glimmers of Efron's sweetness and Devine's screwball intensity, but it's mostly a fumble of lame gags.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ride Along 2 may be the first mainstream comedy in years to feature a cast this diverse and for that it deserves some sort of accolade. But that's it. Otherwise its the same eye-rolling numbskullery as the first.
Bay turns a divisive political issue into a film about machine guns, dirt, blood and gung-ho patriotism. Expect spectacle; insight, not so much.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hobbled by inept storytelling and drab visuals, itll leave toon fans wishing theyd stuck with their hazy childhood memories.
Rest assured your last camping trip packed more thrills.
Its a fine story, but you already saw the better, tauter version half a decade ago.
If the goal here was to replicate the banal horror of wedding-attendance obligations, then Table 19 nails it.
Blood-soaked, action-packed and delightfully single-minded.
Chimpanzee intermittently veers into Disney-esque cheese - seriously, a 'bad' monkey named Scar? - but is otherwise a delight.
As baffling as it is dull, Dark Tower is a disappointment for both hardcore fans and the King-curious. Stick with the books.
Stenberg's effervescent turn can't save this from curdling early into manipulative, melodramatic mush.
Muddy and slow in spots, but offbeat enough to keep you watching.
If you're looking for laughs, look elsewhere.
It's an allegory painted in broad strokes, but several set-pieces are nail-biters, and more than once it captures the insanity of election campaigns with stark clarity.
Not surprisingly, gags about gambling and strippers ensue. Also not surprisingly, the lightweight laughs dissolve into eye-rolling melodrama.
Funny, absurd and smart-stupid enough to keep everyone happy.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sean Harris' horrific demon-soldier and a climactic gorecaked exorcism scene that cranks up the crazy to 11 are the only bright spots in this rainy, preachy, miscast terror tale.
Segel and Diaz are fine, cute and up for it, but they are let down by a cynical script more interested in selling hardware than entertaining the audience.
Its long, dry patches of colourless storytelling suggest it makes more sense as a book, one to read before you fall asleep to dream of better movies.
Ashley Bell's nuanced performance and a surprisingly pyrotechnic finale liven up a gloomy sequel.

This proudly perverted morality play is certainly done well; whether it ought to have been done at all is an open question.
Tchoupitoulas is as much an evocation of childhood innocence as it is a portrait of New Orleans nightlife.
Redmon and Sabin remain nonjudgmental on these and other matters of the exploitative environment they observe.
Keyhole may be Guy Maddin's first film shot in high-definition digital video, but that doesn't mean this Canadian auteur is suddenly going against his usual backward-looking style.
If you want to see a lot of inventive kick-ass action, this film will thoroughly satisfy--nothing more, nothing less.
As far as what the film sets out to do and how it goes about doing it, there isn't a whole lot one can fault about it; it's pretty much a perfect film in those regards.
It does lightly suggest scintillating questions about just how much of a responsibility artists have to reflecting current political moments in their music.
The film is unassailable as activism, a work that demands to be seen and talked about.
An air of resignation hangs prominently over Goodbye, a sense of despair so oppressive that it seems to invade the world its main character inhabits.
The end results are mixed but nevertheless scintillating and provocative enough to be worth taking seriously.
Twilight Portrait, as infuriating as it sometimes is in the moment, is ultimately haunting in its ambiguities.
For long stretches in its first two acts, Lynn Shelton's film is distinguished by a disarming sense of freedom and spontaneity.
A generally affecting and occasionally insightful drama about the ways people handle an awareness of mortality.
Though the title of Alex Karpovsky's new film takes on a literal meaning its final moments, it also applies metaphorically to Rubberneck as a whole
A wide-ranging piece of literary criticism brought to vivid cinematic life, bursting with ideas and inspired visual translations of them.
It does lightly suggest scintillating questions about the responsibility artists have in reflecting current political moments in their music.
D'Elia's debut feature is, I think, a challenge worth taking. Here, it appears, is a real emerging vision, original, gutsy, and uncompromising.
As entertaining as the doc is, it never really measures up to the fascination and sheer force of personality of its subject.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As a portrait of a galvanized and galvanizing artist it's compelling, if less rigorous and multifaceted than it might have been in more inquisitive hands.
One can see the difference between the two traumatized main female characters right in their faces.
Charming and occasionally insightful.
Whatever one ends up thinking about The Snowtown Murders, it's difficult to deny that it's a deeply impressive work.
Even at its messiest and most meandering, We Have a Pope exudes a refreshing warmth toward its characters.
DP Lol Crawley's best efforts can't quite overcome the rather awkward performances of the film's mostly nonprofessional cast.
One could say that Jones has a knack for putting across familiar ideas with enough skill, intelligence, and heart to make the end result seem fresh enough.
Glodell breaks all sorts of rules in Bellflower, but he isn't doing it just to show off.
If the film had been neater and more precise with its aims and means, the film might not have the uneasy cumulative effect it has.
Fairly thrilling, but also just numbing and repetitive.
As the oddball premise of Kyle Killen's script played out, I kept wishing that someone other than Foster had directed this material.
As far as middlebrow biopics go, it may not break any molds, but it's a reasonably sensitive and occasionally insightful look into the mind and psyche of an impassioned and deeply troubled artist.
In Jiro Dreams of Sushi, Gelb details, among other things, the painstaking process that goes into creating these mouthwatering pieces of sushi.
If The Journals of Musan indicates anything, it's that people, for the most part, either can't or simply aren't willing to comprehend the circumstances behind others' actions.
Cairo Exit has other virtues to recommend it beyond topical relevance.
You can probably guess what must happen during the course of this road trip. Even less surprising than its story arc, however, are its character details.
If nothing else, The Loneliest Planet, the second fiction film from Russian-American filmmaker Julia Loktev, is a terrific example of a minimalist style employed with near-maximum effectiveness.
Le Havre may be mild stuff overall, but it's pleasant enough, amusing and humane in good measure. For me, in other words, it's a promising initial encounter with Kaurismäki's distinctive world.
A sudden attempt at poetry only serves to underline the skin-deep nature of Ulrich Köhler's economic analysis.
Though the film's title suggests we're about to watch some kind of fairy tale, that turns out not to be quite the case.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Durkin deserves full credit for his direction of the actors, all of whom ground a potentially sensationalistic scenario in psychologically realistic characterizations.

Goodbye First Love is essentially your standard coming-of-age tale, but Mia Hansen-Løve handles it with the same wisdom and emotional insight with which she treated the struggles of a broken family in her last film, The Father of My Children.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I would imagine no one goes to a documentary like Corman's World expecting cinematic interest. We go expecting, if not necessarily insights into the man himself or his work, at least a good overview of his life and legacy.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: What a film like Undefeated never gets around to questioning is whether football really ought to be pushed onto these kids as the goal--their entry into higher education and future success.
Kumaré can't quite escape a hovering sense that Vikram Gandhi is only willing to take his self-examination so far
As far as hagiographies go, Corman's World is breezy and entertaining enough to be absorbing, especially for the uninitiated.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Kivu Ruhorahoza dares to demolish fiction's inherent distance from what might be considered "reality."
Even with the heaviness of some of its subject matter, the doc remains limpid and unsentimental until the very end, in keeping with its subject.
Mark Mori goes a bit overboard in hammering home his appreciation of Bettie Page's significance, allowing the film to occasionally lapse into repetitiveness.
Offers at least one way to couch propaganda in a way that doesn't seem like the genuine article on the face of it.
movie_title: It Is No Dream: The Life of Theodor Herzl (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The images and interviews Robert H. Lieberman and his crew have managed to capture are eye-opening enough to justify the dangerous effort.
movie_title: They Call It Myanmar: Lifting The Curtain (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A Case of You is a frustrating case of a great opportunity blown.
After a disappointingly conventional action-movie climax, James sucker-punches us with a final scene that ends the film on a tantalizingly ironic note.
Not even its problematically touristic gaze is enough to derail the fascination of this absurd tale's many nightmarish twists and turns.
In the end, what's the point, especially when, in the case of The New Blood, there isn't a whole heck of a lot in the way of human interest or wit to compensate for the lack of viscera?
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VII - The New Blood (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the most promising thing about Cretton, though, at least going by this one feature film under his belt, is his generosity of vision and the refreshingly wide emotional range that vision admits.
Waxwork is certainly no hidden horror gem, but its flashes of wit and genuine enthusiasm for the horror genre are enough to make it a reasonably enjoyable time.
These myriad impressions never quite add up to anything coherent by the end, but perhaps the incoherence is precisely the point.
Ron Maxwell's film, from beginning to end, exudes all the excitement of a textbook history lesson.
The found-footage gimmick mostly comes off as window dressing for what turns out to be yet another mad-scientist-run-amok romp.

Its discursiveness does have the intriguing effect of leaving behind a myriad of impressions about its subjects rather than settling on pat interpretations.
If you grant the documentary its slanted perspective at the outset, it works well as its own state-of-the-union address.

movie_review_blurb: Anthony Wong does a creditable job of conveying Ip Man's reflectiveness through his twilight years, occasionally cutting through the hagiographic nature of the enterprise.

For Ben Stiller, apparently, Thurber's classic story is grist not for a sympathetic exploration of the universal human desires to dream and live, but to craft what eventually amounts to a totem to his own vanity.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: By the end, Spike Jonze pushes past his tightrope of sincerity and irony into a near-spiritual realm that still maintains its fragilely intimate, bittersweet vibe.
Rocky's journey of self-realization undoubtedly has a universal resonance to it that intermittently yields poignant and inspiring moments. But where are the poor Indian kids in all of this?
The filmmakers use a wide range of cinematic techniques to convey the tenuous environment in which their subjects find themselves.
Offers the ins and outs of the world of wine as an implicit metaphor for art appreciation, from both aesthetic and financial standpoints.
Bob Byington's perspective may be above it all, but that doesn't quite account for the shades of melancholy that pop up unexpectedly in lines of dialogue and in some of the performances.

Perhaps the most promising thing about Cretton, though, at least going by this one feature film under his belt, is his generosity of vision and the refreshingly wide emotional range that vision admits.
There's something deeply problematic about a film that seems to lavish so much creative glee in so thoroughly and gruesomely degrading its protagonists, and to no particularly revelatory ends.
Cool, precise, omniscient in its gaze.
The emphasis in Like Someone In Love is on the "like" rather than on the "love."
No film as full of creative energy and imagination as this one can be said to be entirely nihilistic.
A proudly optimistic spirit animates this joyous film, illustrated by a combination of thrilling street ballet, exultant music, and unflagging verve.
One can sense the healing power of art simply by basking in his presence, which no amount of irritating directorial interventions can completely undermine.
movie_title: Far Out Isn't Far Enough: The Tomi Ungerer Story (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The film is incredibly cynical, but the experience of watching it is occasionally joyful in its sense of freedom.

On a political level, the film is far from a Godardian dialectic, so the view of history that emerges is, to say the least, blinkered.
Comes off as little more than a feature-length trashing of colleagues who director and celebrity photographer Kevin Mazur feels are giving his profession a bad name.
Purports to tell the true story of the titular imprisoned, controversially outspoken death-penalty opponent, but eventually degenerates into an orgy of congratulation.
The film looks so glossy, plasticized, and unreal that all you end up thinking about is special effects.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If you prefer your social commentary in the form of a glorified sitcom with broad humor and even broader caricatures, look no further.

Filled with all sorts of misanthropic grace notes that suggest equal-opportunity contempt toward just about everyone involved.

It suggests an allegory for a certain kind of artistic creation, one more interested in exactitude than spontaneity.
Alex Winter knows he has a great and timely subject and, for the most part, allows these people and the larger story to speak for themselves.
An exemplary example of a documentary that successfully puts human faces on wider issues, eschewing polemics in favor of the personal.

Not just interesting in how it foreshadows the filmmaker's more mature works, but also a gripping piece of storytelling in its own right.
If The World of Kanako is ultimately difficult to wholly dismiss as simply an extended wallow in escalating unpleasantness, much of this can be credited to Koji Yakusho's performance.

There are enough moments in Raw where the grand metaphor resonates .., to keep one emotionally invested throughout

Perhaps most important of Ozon's worldview is the film's universal humanism.

It is, in other words, the kind of horror film that transcends genre and reaches that rare but exalted sweet spot of touching on genuine human fears.

"We're due for a shift in the definition of what it means to be human," one scientist says; with Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World, Herzog regards that sentiment with a healthy measure of both awe and skepticism.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

Like any person worth knowing, warts and all, the more we get to know Donald and Peter, the more affecting the film becomes.
For all its faults, Wolves manages to be reasonably involving.
All the film has to show for its efforts are tired platitudes about the value of altruism and living each day as it if were the last.

What a strange and still-radical swan song it remains.

movie_review_blurb: A melancholy air blows through every haunted frame of Hong Sang-soo's On the Beach at Night Alone.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Joseph Cedar charts Norman's rise-and-fall arc with the attention to detail of a procedural.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This whole nauseating enterprise smacks of the basest exploitation.

Cohn's film is ultimately a genuinely inspiring one, noteworthy in the way it achieves its uplift honestly and without sentimentality.

Laura Poitras doesn't indulge in score-settling cheap shots, but seriously grapples with her contradictory subject.

there's no soul to any of it: not in its wholly unsurprising plot twists; not in its noisy action set pieces; and certainly not in the performances
