Eastwood's best direction since Unforgiven and arguably the best, most mature work of his career.
So clever, so funny, so suavely entertaining that it comes as a shock to realize that it's not nearly as satisfying as all those qualities would lead you to believe.
More schlocky than satisfying.
Aside from Paltrow's performance, Sylvia is neither a film so spectacular it shouldn't be missed nor something so tepid you have to stay away.
An especially warm comedy with a hidden heart.
A thoughtful, analytical yet still emotional film, meticulously investigated and absolutely compelling.
An unreal film about a real situation, unavoidably cartoonish, as was the earlier Tears of the Sun, in its attempt to join crucial issues to ridiculous melodrama.
Brother Bear does have a satisfying ending and it's nice to see a G-rated film without bathroom humor, but there is too much formula and not enough reason to pay attention here.
More than being a smart and accurate look at magazine journalism -- no small matter -- Shattered Glass is also a compelling portrait of a psychosis at work.
Like a nightmare that never ends, this is a vision of madness, loneliness and, yes, horror that, once seen, demands to be viewed over and over again. It is that haunting, and that good.
Though it would be dishonest to call this an unqualified success, it would be churlish not to tip the hat to Love Actually's genuine charm.

Making this pay off without winking at the audience is a difficult task, and 'Elf' doesn't always feel all of a piece. But in 'Saturday Night Live' alumnus and star Will Ferrell, the film has a guide who steers it unerringly over the bumpy patches.

It's like the Discovery Channel version of the Greatest Story Ever Told, an earnest, not particularly distinguished piece of work that has none of the touch of the poet that made Pasolini's The Gospel According to St. Matthew such a triumph.
Master and Commander intends to be an intelligent epic, but it's the epic qualities more than the intelligence that hold us.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A pleasing mainstream comedy that uses new people and attitudes to entertain in old-fashioned ways.
In the end, star charisma and Liman's style win us over and we relax into a sophisticated summertime diversion that is noticeably intended for adults.
An enticing invitation to get your feet wet in the world of surfing, to experience the beauty and feel the rush of this most addictive of pastimes.
Though the film's second half has some good action moments, it never fulfills the promise of its earliest scenes.
Oblivious to how formulaic and uninvolving all this gets is director Hunter, who to all intents and purposes seems to view the film as one long Diet Pepsi spot.
A movie with the younger crowd in mind, but older adults savvy enough to disregard labels will find it surprisingly rewarding.
An ambitious, high-minded flop that wants to do good in the world, a failure with a pedigree, if you will.

It is so adroit in its structure, so insightful in how it explores its vivid characters that it forces us to acknowledge not only how complicated all lives are but also how easy it is to be self-centered and miss those complications in everyone else.
A breath of stale air that likes to pretend hard guys always have a witty answer to every question and fatal bullets to the head leave tiny bloodless holes.
Brisk and involving with a streamlined forward propulsion, it's the kind of superhero movie we want if we have to have superhero movies at all.
To be next to these birds as they are flying is frankly mesmerizing.
Even with its drawbacks, Blue Car remains an intimate, thoughtful drama, with a performance no one is likely to forget.
A much better documentary -- more revealing, more emotional and more surprising -- than its pedestrian English title would have you believe.
movie_title: Etoiles: Dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Simply not as satisfying as the original.
Confident, uncompromising and blisteringly realistic, Sweet Sixteen is a gritty and immediate film yet it goes right to the emotions.
Erupts with sea creatures that showcase Stanton and company's gift for character and peerless eye for skewering contemporary culture.
When the words 'Dedicated to those who came before' appear on screen at the close, you can almost feel all those ancestors joining modern audiences in applauding what has been accomplished here.
This is finally a particularly naked and invasive form of voyeurism, The Real World for the PBS crowd.
A bombshell in its home country, Herod's Law is made with the kind of flair that ensures a following everywhere politicians are venal and voters hope against hope for deliverance.
It is quite well done, with a fine cast finding time between tears, anger, deception and recriminations to do some surprisingly strong and affecting acting.
They won't be making another film like this any time soon, and the chance to see all those elephants is not one you get every day.
There is a fundamental air of truth about it, a sense that, horrific though things seem, this is how it must have been.
If it's also a messy story, peopled with characters who don't know whom to trust, it almost seems as if its reflecting the current state of Israeli affairs.
A piece of sophisticated, subtle filmmaking that is both thoughtful and thought-provoking.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Camp has a good deal of the appeal, and the drawbacks, of a high school play. It can be pokey and overly earnest and its dramatics are not always polished, but, on the other hand, would you want them to be?
It is not as exceptional a film as the reality deserves, but with a story this strong and races this expertly re-created, it squeezes out a victory by being as good a movie as it needs to be.
Disturbing and intriguing, Dirty Pretty Things fits a great deal into its 94 quicksilver minutes.
Offers up a subversive comic sensibility, one that somehow combines Buster Keaton's deadpan stare with Frank Capra's tireless optimism and filters them both through a black-ice Finnish point of view.
A comic actor of genius who raises silliness to an art form, the wonderfully expressive Atkinson makes excellent use of those devastating looks in the spy spoof Johnny English.
As forgettable as a bad day in the Disneyland parking lot.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There's little here that isn't overly familiar and formulaic, nothing that's even in the same arena with the eye candy of those vivid adventures.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An expertly paced and efficient sci-fi thrill machine, 'T3' effectively marries impressive action sequences with persuasive storytelling and its star's uniquely appealing style of 'No' drama -- as in no reaction, no expression, no emotion of any kind.
Despite the fact that a group of gifted professionals created exactly the cinematic effects they were after, it's hard to take great pleasure in what's been achieved.

Wasting the talents of Kate Hudson, Luke Wilson and Sophie Marceau, this Rob Reiner-directed film is unconvincing in its core idea -- said to be inspired by Dostoevsky but likely to have the poor man weeping in his grave -- and in its execution.
A tidy thriller that marks the tight and confident directing debut of Scott Roberts, it does a surprisingly good job with undeniably familiar material.

Neither conventionally told nor resolved, and able to make the most eccentric situations believable, I Capture the Castle is both an ordinary story and a special one -- and that, finally, is the secret of its success.
With Christian Bale in the title role, this is a film noir Batman, a brooding, disturbing piece of work that starts slowly but ends up crafting a world that just might haunt your dreams.

My Father My Lord is an impressive first feature that stands out for its emotional qualities, its ambition and its brevity. In this day of endless epics, this 73-minute Israeli film manages to do a lot with very little time.
Herbie: Fully Loaded is that modern rarity, a genial, sweet-natured family film, G-rated and proud of it, an old-fashioned Disney movie to the core.
We Americans inevitably feel we know the best way to do everything, but the great accomplishment of Sicko is that it is difficult to watch this slyly confrontational film and remain sure.
Brad Bird's Ratatouille is so audacious you have to fall in love with its unlikely hero.

Though he has a way with CGI toys and action set pieces, director Bay does not have a noticeable gift for making human beings come to life. Transformers' multiple earthling story lines are tedious and oddly lifeless.
Thinned down from the series' longest book, Phoenix can't shake an episodic feeling that makes it difficult to develop momentum.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Too serious to be an out-and-out comedy, too funny not to be one, My Best Friend is a lot easier to enjoy than to classify.
It's a special pleasure to report that the French Lady Chatterley is the most frankly sensual movie in memory.
Brightness has never seemed as menacing as it does in Sunshine, the nail-bitingly tense science-fiction thriller.
[It] builds a sly and unexpected human comedy out of a dispute over whether a revolution would still be a revolution if nobody showed up.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A sprightly new documentary that's as compulsively watchable as the vintage video game it focuses on is addictive.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Still effectively creepy and surprisingly unnerving despite the occasional misstep and rumors of a troubled production, the new film illustrates why and how the power of the original story remains undiminished more than half a century after its creation.
An impeccably acted character drama revolving around a mother and her teenage twin sons, Private Property shows how strong and how terrifying the bonds within families can be.
Made with energy and style...
[Director] Mangold has brought welcome intensity to the project, giving 3:10 to Yuma a visceral, immediate quality that makes it realistic and mythic all at the same time.
A tour de force.
That this implausible stew works as well as it does is in part a tribute to the unlikely but enjoyable rapport that forms between old school McClane and his youthful computer-savvy companion.
It feels good to remember those days, even now. Especially now.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's sense of responsibility proves almost paralyzing, allowing the production to be overwhelmed by the seriousness of what it's attempting.
Though it offers interesting stories, Shadow Company does feel a little scattered.
Hugely ambitious and not without moments of success, this indulgent 2 hour and 40 minute epic ends up as unwieldy as its elongated title.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's [Penn's] warmest, most celebratory and most completely realized film and, though you might not guess it from the material, it is also arguably his most personal.
It wants us to feel as if we're watching something relevant when what's really going on is a slick excuse for efficient mayhem that's not half as smart as it would like to be.
...an involving, offbeat and truly unusual American independent film.
Surprisingly vast and involving.

With the George Clooney-starring Michael Clayton, [Tony Gilroy] has not only saved his best script for himself, he's also turned out a smart and suspenseful legal thriller that comes completely alive on-screen.

The longer it goes, the more frustrating it becomes, as [director] Bar Lev declines to come down on one side or the other. It makes his presence in the Olmsteads' lives serve no real purpose other than exploitation of their misery for his own good.

A brooding meditation on the unnerving power and terrible cost of emotional and political masquerades, the Chinese-language Lust, Caution gets under your skin with its examination of what qualifies as love and what does not.

Jacques Vergès is such a compelling, complex and contradictory character that if he didn't exist someone would be obliged to invent him. It is the gift of Terror's Advocate to simply present Vergès as is.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Straight ahead in form but unnerving and unexpected in content.
This is a film whose daring and delicate blend of apparent irreconcilables will sweep you off your feet if you're not careful.
Brooding, somber film is ragged around the edges and not without problematic aspects.

Less a brave movie than a foolhardy one. Trapped in a no man's land between seriousness and pulp trash, it plays like a combination of Death Wish and The Hours. If that sounds like an awkward fit, it is.

Though it is erratic and can come off as manufactured, this film has the gift of gathering strength as it goes on. It harnesses the talents of stars Halle Berry and Benicio Del Toro in ways that ultimately make us sit up and take notice.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Both moving and frighteningly real.
Earnest, gee-whiz and foursquare, this simple and intentionally inoffensive sequel gets points for being easy to take and scrupulously avoiding obvious sources of irritation.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A grindhouse-inspired concoction that may not contain a shred of originality, but it is executed with unbridled bombast and glee.
A magnificent film almost no one knows about, this hidden classic offers a wider variety of pleasures than most contemporary works can even aspire to.
While peripheral elements of Becket do show their age, the core of the film's appeal remains incandescent, and that is the on-screen collaboration between Burton and O'Toole.
The Situation is promoting itself as the first American dramatic feature film to deal with the occupation of Iraq. While that may be true, it turns out not to matter that much.
Not only is the subject matter different for Spielberg, the way it is treated is a departure both for him and for the business as usual standards of major studio releases.
Filled with tension, deception and bravura acting, Breach is a crackling tale of real-life espionage that doubles as a compelling psychological drama.

Director Michael Apted and his team understand the challenges of this kind of story and have met them with intelligence and energy. [He] has managed to be true to the outsized emotions of the story without giving way to sentimentality.
A fine cast and a realistic touch give the charming farce a sweetness and emotional intimacy.
Grbavica is a film we watch with our heart in our mouth, wondering when, if ever, the war will end for those who lived through it and, at least physically, survived.
Snyder's 300 certainly has its share of the latest toys, but they make for a better coming-attractions trailer than a full-length theatrical film.

Though it likely will not persuade people to join the ranks, experiencing life behind the walls has an undeniable effect. We've been allowed a glimpse of eternity. And who would not be changed by that?

Loach has the gift of finding the intensely moving private emotions in broad, societal dilemmas. He does that with his fine new film, The Wind That Shakes the Barley, and he does a few new things as well.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shooter is executed with such efficiency and energy by action maestro Antoine Fuqua that ignoring flaws and becoming involved in the proceedings isn't a matter of choice.
The great virtue of Offside is that it never degenerates into an us-versus-them situation. [Director Pahani] understands that a repressive system victimizes the oppressors as much as the oppressed.
A fascinating and surprisingly involving film.

An effective homage to the kind of small-scale thrillers we never forget. We can't avoid knowing where The Lookout is headed, but we are so deep inside its characters' heads that we wouldn't want to go anywhere else.

An impeccably made psychological melodrama. It's a story of destruction, dependence and betrayal set not only in the world of classical music but in the French culture of politeness where form and decorum are everything.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As subversive as it is traditional, both enamored of conventional notions of heroism and frankly contemptuous of them.
... still has the power to move us.

By the time everything falls into place, it doesn't much matter. The best thrillers don't just show up for the closing credits, they are involving all along the way. That's where Perfect Stranger goes imperfectly wrong.
This is a film with a story we have not seen before, a story about American troops so unusual it needed a German director to ferret it out.
Writer-director Kasdan has made the best film he can make now, which is no small thing. He will make even better ones in the future, which might be a very big thing indeed.
A complete master of cinematic farce, [director] Veber's latest venture, The Valet, makes creating deliciously funny comedy look a lot easier than it has any right to.
We live on the fault line along with these characters, and it is an experience that is not easy to shake off.

To see Tamblyn's work here, to see her character almost simultaneously embody pain, terror, anguish, embarrassment, regret and just about any emotion you can think of, is to watch the kind of acting the medium exists to provide.
[Spider-Man 3 has] an ungainly, cumbersome feeling, as if its plot elements were the product of competing contractors who never saw the need to cooperate on a coherent final product.
... a serious and amusing black farce that does without obvious heroes or villains ...
Zoo is a cool sensibility married to a hot topic, a poetic film about a forbidden, unsettling subject.

Are you looking for a little film you can make your own, an enchanting, unpretentious blend of music and romance you can watch forever? If you do, Once is about to come into your life and make it whole.
Ocean's Thirteen will please those who delight in its persistent self-mythologizing, but the thrill of the original is gone, and nothing can bring it back.

It's that paradoxical melodrama that point-blank refuses to acknowledge that it's being melodramatic, conveying its scenario with enough intensity, psychological acuity and forceful acting to ignore labels and flat-out overpower audiences.
If what you want is a star-driven sophisticated romantic comedy that is successfully aimed at actual adults, the wait can seem like forever. Until now.
Narrrowly cast documentary focuses so exclusively on a publicity tour the former president took in the closing months of 2006 that a more accurate title might be Jimmy Carter How I Sold My Book.
Less a dispassionate examination than a celebratory infomercial on its central character.
Search out this vivid film in a theater. Don't let the sacrifices he [Director Lou Ye] made be in vain.

Outrageous and outlandish, Emmerich's 10,000 BC is easy to mock, but it is so cheerfully shameless and terminally silly that you have to admire its effrontery and accept its creator... as a certified crackpot visionary.
Though Girls Rock! is nothing if not well meaning, it doesn't always feel like the best possible film on the subject.
Brisk and agreeable, a handcrafted ode to the brew that is the beverage of choice where the Chinese, among many others, are concerned.
One of the strongest examples yet of a fearless new wave that has made Israel's cinema a force on the international scene.
No one who sees this intriguing documentary will want to argue with reporter Greider when he forcefully insists, "We need a more mature regard for the future." We do indeed.

This largely Spanish-language film brings on the waterworks because its core story is undeniably affecting. The whole movie, however, would be more convincing if the elements around that vital core were more multidimensional and less contrived.
Stop-Loss is a film that does it right.
Genially preposterous and pleasantly diverting, it balances calculation against humanity and generally comes out on top.
The music's insistent richness builds and builds, its sound becoming so deep and persuasive that qualms about age fade and the rhythms carry us away.

If some of this sounds like stereotypical Italian behavior, and if in fact My Brother Is an Only Child has a weakness for abrupt and melodramatic plot devices, it has other virtues that make it truly satisfying.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You won't believe the world of Young@Heart, but you'll have a hard time resisting it.

The filmmakers come off like their protagonist, wide-eyed tourists in an exotic realm. If you've been looking for a martial arts film to take granny and the kids to, this might be the one, but a Jackie Chan-Jet Li collaboration deserves better than that.

The film has a sense of the genial absurdity of life, a whimsical appreciation of the inescapable randomness of our anything-can-happen existence, of how fragile yet resilient are the bonds that draw people together.

The wave-like Rashomon structure of the story, combined with the steady pace and moody look of "Vivere" are lulling, but in the end the situation is neither believable nor fantastic enough to be very compelling.
Downey's unbeatable charisma makes these problems less troublesome than they would be otherwise, but wouldn't it be nice if they didn't exist at all?
You may wish that Made of Honor had given its stars something more of interest to occupy their time. And ours.
Squarely in the tradition of the kind of teenage movies the Disney organization used to make before teens discovered horror and gore.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One of the real pluses of Up the Yangtze, aside from its empathy with its subjects, is its striking visual quality.
Spielberg clearly got enormous pleasure employing a lifetime's worth of skill and turning out wave after wave of smartly done stunts and effects set pieces.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An honest look at a complicated human situation,... it turns out to be a darker film than might be expected.
To see how these conflicts play out, to see how both sides came to realize that they had unexpected things to learn from these remarkable young people, is where Blindsight really makes its mark.

Hollywood Chinese is both a history of the Chinese presence in American films and a meditation on the difficulties Chinese Americans have had in being seen as individuals and in putting the reality of their experience on screen.

Having Bodrov, who directed the excellent The Prisoner of the Mountains, in charge here is an advantage. Though there is only so much any director can do with characters who are next door to mythic, Bodrov can do more than most, and it helps.

This haunting phantasmagoria of a film -- comic, singular, surreal -- is not only something no one but the Canadian director could have made, it's also a film no one else would have even wanted to make. Which is the heart of its appeal.
Daring and traditional, groundbreaking and familiar, apocalyptic and sentimental, Wall-E gains strength from embracing contradictions that would destroy other films.
Trumbo is an unconventional film about an unconventional man.
It's a strange feeling to see the summer's most promising premise self-destruct into something bizarre and unsatisfying, but that is the Hancock experience.

Tell everyone about Tell No One. Not just because this is a top-notch thriller so twisty you may forget to breathe, but because for a long time it looked like you wouldn't be able to tell anyone at all.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to think of a more remarkable tribute to the resilience of the human spirit than the one Umberto D. puts on the screen.
Focus is really the heart of Morris' unsettling film, which strikes a remarkable balance between art and disturbance, between beauty and pain.
Will leave you speechless two times over -- first with despair, then with joy.
OK as far as it goes, which is not far enough.
Demonstrates that no matter how many Holocaust stories the movies tell, there are always new and unexpected ones waiting to be revealed.
It takes nerve to call a film American Gangster -- But once you see this finely made and richly satisfying film, you understand it's the only title possible.

The best material is the result of the rare opportunity to shoot inside those refugee camps: hearing firsthand testimony from victims about the catastrophic horrors inflicted on their villages is forceful and persuasive.
Italian documentary filmmaker Davide Ferrario, who specializes in what he calls "on the road" documentaries, decided to retrace Primo Levi's steps in modern Europe. It was a wise choice.
An intense, nihilistic thriller as well as a model of implacable storytelling, this is a film you can't stop watching even though you very much wish you could.
War/Dance is as irresistible as the rhythms of African music on its soundtrack.

If you want to understand what the pressure of Hollywood does to talent, if you want to experience where the movie business is heading in a big way, this benighted but likely remunerative film is the place to start.
An unabashed valentine to Anna Faris, an opportunity for the actress to show that she can carry a movie composed of often hilarious nonstop misadventures.
This film is kind of a mess. Even if you agree with its politics, you will probably weep at the ineptitude of it all.
An unexpectedly charming and enlightening film.
It's obvious but inescapable: Enchanted is as good as its name.
There is a rawness to the characterization in this lacerating film that pushes family drama right to the edge.
Intelligent, involving and conspicuously adult, "Starting Out in the Evening" is almost shocking in its distinctiveness, its ability to create high drama from an unlikely source.
The film, based on the memoir of Jean-Dominique Bauby, handles delicate subject matter with sensitivity and imagination.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Given its origins, it's not surprising that Yiddish Theater: A Love Story has a catch-as-catch-can feeling to it. But nothing can take away from the flavor of being caught up in the battles and dreams of a formidable group of people.
[An] ultimately satisfying and successful version of the opening volume of the celebrated His Dark Materials trilogy.
These performers not only have the looks for a sweeping love story, they also have the skill to throw themselves into the proceedings like they really mean it.

The Israeli film that's become celebrated for what it lacks -- enough Hebrew to contend for the best foreign language Oscar -- can now be seen and appreciated for what it has in abundance: visual wit, verbal charm and a completely droll sense of humor.
Initially intriguing and energetic, this film ends up demonstrating that a good script needs to be more than a clever concept and fine direction must be more than moving things fast.
A sweet and somber film that works hard to overcome its limitations.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This slick romantic comedy has several things going for it, including an interesting premise and an attractive cast. Getting all its elements to cohere, however, is too often just beyond its grasp.
Military Intelligence and You! is two movies for the price of one. It's both a loving spoof of World War II films and a pointed satire on America's involvement in Iraq.
It is sweet but not saccharine, an intimate film that doesn't stint on the desperation and anxiety that go along with the search for love.
A meticulous examination...Taxi is impressive.
Dreamgirls is the entire musical package, a triumph of old school on-screen glamour, and we wouldn't want it any other way.
One of the few adaptations that gives a novel the film it deserves.
There Will Be Blood, the joint venture between actor Daniel Day-Lewis and director Paul Thomas Anderson, might be the most incendiary combination since the Molotov cocktail.
Working hard on both sides of the camera, Washington has grafted his intensity onto this production, giving it a kind of backbone it would not otherwise have.

Charlie Wilson's War is an anachronism, the wrong movie at the wrong time. Not only does it tell its tale in a style that feels dated and artificial, the story itself focuses on events that history has overtaken.
It conveys unblinking and despairing emotional truth with enough intensity to leave you gasping for air.
This gleeful skewering of American popular music works because of the talents of director Jake Kasdan and a cast led by John C. Reilly.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Marc Forster-directed version of the Khaled Hosseini novel does one part of the story so well that its success underlines what's lacking in what remains.
A message this political has rarely been delivered in so poetic a form.

Because the violence is used not for titillation but to create a world we can be fearful about, because the film lives up to its tagline that "Innocence has a power evil cannot resist," we see it all without wishing we were somewhere else.
An intricate, deliberately paced 2-hour and 37-minute work that not only quietly presents this quicksand world but also makes us feel what it would be like to live in it.

Made with palpable energy, intensity and excitement, it compellingly creates a world gone mad that is uncomfortably close to the one we live in. It is a Blade Runner for the 21st century, a worthy successor to that epic of dystopian decay.
Despite its drawbacks, Zorro is acceptable in a pinch though not without its puzzling elements.
As journeys go, this is one to treasure.

A powerful, poignant, provocative drama, it gets its strength from its dispassion, from an uncompromising determination to explain rather than justify or condemn, to put a human face on incomprehensible acts.
As much as we intellectually admire Jarhead, it's a cold film that only sporadically makes the kind of emotional connection it's after.

Greenwald has shrewdly chosen not to go with classic talking head types like economists, academics and journalists. Instead he talked to current and former Wal-Mart employees, including several with a dozen or more years with the company.
movie_title: Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film's inability to resist the lure of maximum exploitation becomes frustrating.
Bee Season is affecting in ways that movies have all but given up trying to be.
The stories and people presented here are involving enough to enthrall anyone.

It's not until Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire that a film has successfully re-created the sense of stirring magical adventure and engaged, edge-of-your-seat excitement that has made the books such an international phenomenon.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A fearless and ambitious piece of work, made with equal parts passion and calculation, an unapologetically entertaining major studio release with compelling real-world relevance, a film that takes numerous risks and thrives on them all.
... largely succeeds.
movie_title: One Bright Shining Moment: The Forgotten Summer of George McGovern (2005)

movie_review_blurb: With its emphasis on muddy streets, muddier language and raunchy behavior, Libertine is a trying experience.
Not only one of Kazan's richest films and Dean's first significant role, it is also arguably the actor's best performance.
It's a deeply felt, emotional love story that deals with the uncharted, mysterious ways of the human heart just as so many mainstream films have before it. The two lovers here just happen to be men.
A respectful comedy whose interest for most audiences will be part anthropological, Ushpizin walks an interesting line.
Just as there will always be an England, there will always be a certain kind of English film: the highly polished entertainment, well-acted, genteelly amusing and impeccably turned out.

The film's overall frantic tone can't disguise the fact that the picture offers little delivery for all its buildup. Everyone involved with this production must have known there was a good movie somewhere, but no one's been quite able to find it.

In this age of feckless and unapologetic zealotry, with leaders whose passion for extremism has led to the lamentable results we see all around us, Munich's even-handed cry for peace is not an act of equivocation but one of bravery.
To come across Classe Tous Risques is like discovering a bottle of marvelous French wine you didn't remember you had, opening it and finding it every bit as delicious as its reputation promised.
Tristan has its slightly silly moments, but rather like those fondly remembered epics of Hollywood past, its energy and entertainment value carry the day.

The Boys of Baraka's greatest service is in shining a light on a problem many people don't want to talk about: our willingness to throw away the lives of kids who grow up in dangerous neighborhoods far from quality schools.
It immerses you in its reality one toe at a time, until suddenly you are in over your head, gasping for air as the horror of the situation reveals itself in all its savage devastation.

It's the record of a life, a musical and spiritual autobiography, and as directed by Jonathan Demme it taps into the kind of unashamed, unsentimental emotion that's become increasingly rare in films of any kind.
What we essentially have here is an old-fashioned, not always convincing B picture with A-list stars.
To appreciate Night Watch, you have to accept it as one of those chaotic cartoon movies that refuse to completely add up.
As befits a film about a woman who took much of her strength from religious conviction, Jentsch's performance seems to be lit from within.
Bruce's story, and the way he lives it before our eyes in several incarnations, makes this an unexpectedly emotional, continually disconcerting film.

CSA is rough around the edges, especially where the acting and some of the film's invented characters are concerned. But the way CSA works out its ideas is so provoking that its drawbacks are not difficult to ignore.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hall's bleak vision, his gift for working with darkness and rain, rivals classic film noir of the 1940s and '50s in its visual mastery.
Must fun of all, however, is basking in Chappelle's ability to be effortlessly funny.

Hollywood is always making family comedies, but they are rarely about real families: relations who are as difficult as they are wonderful, people who both love and irritate the heck out of each other. Families like The Family Stone.
Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang turns into a film that is too ostentatiously pleased with itself, so in love with its own cleverness it doesn't notice it's darn near worn you out.

Studio filmmaking can make an event as fantastical as an alien invasion look like reality, and it can make something that actually took place feel as fake as crocodile tears. Which is what happens with North Country.
It offers a look at the kind of Americans not often put on movie screens.
With War of the Worlds [Spielberg] has made what is arguably one of the best 1950s science fiction films ever.
You leave this film intrigued by its aspiration and not likely to forget the world it's introduced you to.
A blistering film you feel in the pit of your stomach, a jumpy, edgy piece of work that thrusts us into a personal maelstrom so tortured and intense, the emotions could be spread with a knife.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Bergman has never been an ordinary filmmaker, and what he's given us is no genial last hurrah but rather an intensely dramatic, at times lacerating examination of life's conundrums that is exhilarating in its fearlessness and its command.
Burton's gifts ensure you won't be able to take your eyes off the screen, but that doesn't necessarily mean you'll be happy with what you're seeing.

An intimate, chatty film, both cheeky and thorough, the kind of high-class historical gossip you might get if an eminent Soviet historian like Robert Conquest or Richard Pipes went to work for the National Enquirer.
Degenerates into a fearsome chase movie.
A slick piece of summer entertainment that is counting on elaborate special effects to make its derivative, convoluted story line all but irrelevant.

Yet for all its ballyhooed candor about sexual matters, it's a surprisingly baffling and opaque film, too artistic to be standard pornography and too zealously focused on being graphic to the exclusion of all else to succeed as drama.
A consummate entertainment rich with the romantic atmosphere of Paris in the 1950s.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: With no plot, character or dialogue worth experiencing, let alone remembering, the film merely occupies space on the screen and hopes for the best.

An amiable sentimental fantasy, joining running, religion and a boy with a whole lot of problems into an earnest production that entertains even as it milks some of its situations for all they're worth.
A disturbing and provocative tale of obsession, bravado and self-invention that leaves you open-mouthed for all kinds of reasons.

The World has a lot to say and is not in any unholy rush to say it.

This is one terrific thriller with several wicked tricks up its sleeve, each more satisfying than the last.

movie_review_blurb: Acutely observed, faultlessly acted, graced with piercing emotion and unsparing honesty, it will make you laugh because you can't bear to cry.

Good Night, and Good Luck couldn't be more unlikely, more unfashionable -- or more compelling.
With every studio comedy looking for a formula for success, it's refreshing to find a heroically whimsical film that succeeds by following no formula known to dog or man.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Simultaneously innocent and sophisticated, this honestly emotional fable shows why every Ballard film -- and his last was released almost a decade ago -- is a special event.
A deeply personal and unexpectedly poetic film.

A potent and imaginative creative biography of virtuoso percussionist Glennie.
If you've ever seen a movie, you know what's going to happen.
A film that grips us dramatically, intellectually and emotionally.

"The Revenant" is a classic B picture fortified with all manner of Grade A resources.

A godsend for audiences who hunger for rich emotion presented with wit, grace and not a trace of sentimentality, "Brooklyn" illustrates the power of restraint in dealing with poignant, impassioned material.

Nelson understands the play of outsized personalities and unexpected events, and he's helped that enough time has passed for former Panthers to feel comfortable telling their stories, especially to someone of Nelson's stature in the documentary world.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As it turns out, Imax 3-D works better for yaks than it does for people.
A bleak, claustrophobic based-on-fact film that draws us completely into a dark world of crime and complicity.
Hansen-Love is an assured and naturally empathetic director who specializes in making us care more about her characters than seems likely at the outset.
As music and cultural critic Stanley Crouch says, "You only have to hear her once. No one sounds like her except her."
[An] accomplished, quietly devastating documentary ...
"A Borrowed Identity" starts out nice and easy but don't be fooled. This is a soft-seeming film about a hard-edged, difficult subject, an Israeli film that offers a picture from life's other side.

Farhadi has written a first-rate script, enabling intricate plotting to intertwine with well-defined characters, and "About Elly" shows him at ease with the wide variety of situations his writing explores.
"Minions'" all-silliness all-the-time philosophy will put a smile on faces and keep it there, like a fizzy beverage on a hot afternoon.

If the key to price in real estate is "location, location, location," the key to success in vérité-style documentaries is "access, access, access." Which is what "Cartel Land" has in compelling amounts.
You can't have a good Ant-Man movie without a good Ant-Man, and in the genial and charming everyman Paul Rudd, the filmmakers have done it right.
An elegant puzzler that presents the sage of Baker Street dealing with the one thing he's never had to contend with before: his own emotions.

A shocking and significant film, a further illumination of one of recent history's great horrors, a documentary that will make a difference in the world. It is also an exceptionally difficult film to actually watch.
"Southpaw" is proof of contrivance's clout, but there is a limit to what it can do.

Though placing the cheerleading Eckers front and center as key interview subjects gives their film a self-congratulatory, gee-whiz quality, "Outrageous" compensates by giving you a good sense of who Tucker was and how she got where she did.
Cruise has played Ethan Hunt so often it would be understandable if he phoned it in, but one of the pleasures of "Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" is that he doesn't.
"Phoenix" is an intoxicating witches' brew, equal parts melodrama and moral parable, that audaciously mixes diverse elements to compelling, disturbing effect.
Autobiographical in nature, unconventional in structure, this is the story of Marlon Brando not as the world saw him but as he saw himself.
Playful, absurd and endearingly inventive, this unstoppably amusing feature reminds us why Britain's Aardman Animations is a mainstay of the current cartooning golden age.
Once those super powers kick in, the whole film goes into a more standard gear. We've seen it all before, and it's safe to say we'll be seeing it all again as well.
"Pawn Sacrifice" is a solid and entertaining addition to the Fischer film canon.
"A Brilliant Young Mind" is not the film you think it is. It's better.
Given what it attempts, "Time Out of Mind" should be considered a success.
It turned one man's culturally specific journey into a lively and engaging universal story made with an unmistakable sense of fun.

Gibney is certainly good at what he does, and "Steve Jobs" is at its best in providing a brisk summation of the man's life. Or, more accurately, lives, for Jobs seemed to have been more people than one would have thought possible.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Second Mother" is a satisfying contradiction. It's a soap opera with a social conscience that casually mixes dramatic elements about serious class issues with a crowd-pleasing audience picture sensibility.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lawrence delivers on what dramatic beats half a novel affords him. You just wish there were more of them and that they provided a more complete, more satisfying story arc.
With its mixture of tones, its multiple plot focuses and its singular use of the virtuosity of Spanish guitarist Narciso Yepes on the soundtrack, it is very much its own film.
Hubert Sauper goes where other people don't go, sees what the crowd doesn't see and creates unsettling, provocative political documentaries that are unlike anyone else's.
Though children may be satisfied (if the witch stuff doesn't scare them) adults will have a harder time with the by-the-numbers confrontations between the witches and the plucky youths.

Though the "Meru" climbing and outdoor footage is spectacular, it is the personal struggle of each of the climbers, and the candid way they talk about them on camera, that give this film its considerable impact.
Small, smart and inescapably independent, "People Places Things" has its own offbeat and charmingly low-key way of seeing the world.
"Straight Outta Compton" ends up juggling more story lines and moods than it can handle.
Diablo Cody's dispiriting screenplay is all about everyone coming to love Ricki, faults and all, and that is just not convincingly done.
"Rosenwald" used to be a name to conjure with, but no more, and that is a shame this vivid, engaging documentary attempts to do something about.
It may sound like a standard-issue advocacy documentary concerned, as so many are, with the perils of global warming, but it's a lot more than that.
A despairing, intentionally disturbing film that draws us into a maelstrom of desperate emotions, it holds up a dark mirror to the American dream and does not like what it sees.
Stewart acquits himself solidly, though not thrillingly, as a beginning director ...
Earnest and well-intentioned but ultimately inert, "The Monuments Men" talks a better game than it can deliver.
At three hours and 38 minutes, "The Last of the Unjust," like Lanzmann himself at his advanced age, is ungainly but powerful.

Deftly written by Richard Curtis and directed by the versatile Mike Newell, Four Weddings is as good as its word, breezily following a small circle of friends through every one of the events the title promises.

Because it is fearlessly sincere and not totally successful, "Winter's Tale" is easy to mock. But it is also hard not to admire its willingness to go all out in its quest for the grandest of romantic gestures.
It all sounds quite convincing in theory, but in practice this mélange of imagery is aimed more at the inside of Reggio's head than anywhere else.
"Child's Pose" sounds like something simple and easy, but don't be fooled.
The Godfather is overflowing with life, rich with all the grand emotions and vital juices of existence, up to and including blood.
This warm and affectionate human comedy from India is charming in a delicate and unforced way.
"Generation War" has a texture and an interest that American stories do not.
"Non-Stop" is a crisp, efficient thriller that benefits greatly from the intangibles Neeson can be counted on to supply.

In the Name of the Father is a model of this kind of engaged, enraged filmmaking, a politically charged Fugitive that uses one of the most celebrated cases of recent British history to steamroller an audience with the power of rousing, polemical cinema.
movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A confident, eccentric debut about a trio of shambling and guileless friends who become the Candides of crime, Rocket feels particularly refreshing because it never compromises on its delicate deadpan sensibility.
Formidable, indomitable, irascible: Pick your adjective, and it pretty much describes the force of nature who holds the stage in "Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me."
Anderson works so assiduously to create obsessively detailed on-screen worlds that the effect has sometimes been hermetic, even stifling. "The Grand Budapest," however, is anything but.
Breakdown gets the music right and has the benefit of strong acting, but its unapologetically melodramatic plot has a tendency to throw everything at you but the kitchen sink.
Watching a film won't make you smarter, but if there ever was one that could, it would be "Particle Fever," a movie so mind-bending you can almost feel your brain cells growing as you're watching it.
"Le Week-End" is a sour and misanthropic film masquerading as an honest and sensitive romance.
If you can't place the name, or want to know more, "Anita" is a splendid place to start.

Though its main appeal will be to those who read the book and are young adults either in fact or in spirit, "Divergent" does have something for the rest of us and that's the chance to see the pair of performers who make that romantic music together.

As much a fantasia inspired by the Old Testament as a literal retelling of that tale, "Noah" manages to blend the expected with the unexpected and does it with so much gusto and cinematic energy you won't want to divert your eyes from the screen.
What we find out about Maier, revealed in self-portraits as a striking woman with a singular sense of self, is fascinating.
They're black and white instead of fat and thin, but Wesley Snipes and Woody Harrelson have the makings of a classic comedy team, the Laurel and Hardy of the half-court game.
Everything about Legends of the Fall shouts epic filmmaking and it is not an altogether unpleasant sound.
Much against Rumsfeld's will, what the film inevitably reveals, in Morris' words, is "a man using language to obscure the world from himself as well as from others."
"Captain America" is everything a big budget superhero film should be - except inspired.

Every moment between stars Guy Pearce and Felicity Jones feels so much like an explosion about to go off that viewers may hesitate to so much as take a breath at the wrong time for fear of disturbing the film's delicate equilibrium.
"Ilo Ilo" is writer-director Anthony Chen's first film, but breathtaking intimacy in storytelling is already second nature to him.
It interviews friends and confidants, provides glimpses of what she was like as a person and, best of all, shows us clips of her dancing, which tell us so much of what we need to know.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Though "Draft Day" feels far less authentic than the baseball-themed "Moneyball," it can be amusing to watch all this inside football stuff if you are an NFL fan.
Move over, Charles Darwin, when it comes to great tales about the Galapagos, you've got company.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It continues to charm and delight for the same reasons it did back in 1964.
movie_title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (Les Parapluies de Cherbourg) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: Its children-switched-at-birth story sounds schematic, but what we see on screen is both meaningful and deeply moving.
"Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit" comes off as a reasonable facsimile, serviceable but not compelling, something that could pass for the real thing if you're not looking too hard.
It's most successful when it is being off-center, a state of grace it doesn't quite have the nerve to maintain.

[It] sounds somewhat schematic, [but] it plays better than that because the two actors bring quite a bit to their roles, and because the script has worked hard to make the issues feel real and relevant.
It earns its considerable impact by telling an unnerving story and leaving it, in ways both daring and effective, fundamentally unresolved.
When a director who never ever blinks takes on a horrific subject, a nightmare in broad daylight is the inevitable result. Welcome, if that is the right word, to the world of 12 Years a Slave.
As cold, precise and soulless as the diamonds that figure briefly in its plot, "The Counselor" is an extremely unpleasant piece of business.
A remarkable documentary, though only partially for the reason its creators intended.
Foodie phantasmagoria and something more.

Moviegoing holds few pleasures greater than watching an established star completely inhabit a role that exactly suits his personality and abilities. And seeing Paul Newman in Nobody's Fool defines that pleasure.
The conclusion is chilling, disturbing and perfectly in keeping with what has taken place before.
"The Square" bears witness to history in an articulate, thoughtful and intensely dramatic way.
"Ender's Game" turns out to be our game as well.
To see "The Wind Rises" is to simultaneously marvel at the work of a master and regret that this film is likely his last.
Aftermath is a bombshell disguised as a thriller.
Summations can't convey the filmmaking delicacy that marries tart-tongued comedy with unexpected warmth in a story that touches on family, memory, getting old and staying alive.
Aladdin is a film of wonders. To see it is to be the smallest child, open-mouthed at the screen's sense of magic, as well as the most knowing adult, eager to laugh at some surprisingly sly humor.
An effective piece of melodramatic popular entertainment that savvily builds on the foundation established by the first Hunger Games movie.
Dench is not the only reason to see this unapologetic crowd-pleaser, but she is the best one.

The parade of creatures Del Toro and his team have come up with as this scenario unfolds, starting with a tour of the legendary Troll Market that one-ups the Mos Eisley cantina scene in Star Wars, will make you want to tip your hat in wonder.
I have to confess that (a) I never saw this Pulitzer Prize-winning vehicle by Tracy Letts when it was on stage and (b) nothing about this film version makes me regret that choice.
It turns out to be as compellingly dramatic as anything [Dickens] put on the page.
Stiller's sensibility creates a movie that's smarter than you think it will be. Kind of like Walter Mitty himself.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though it's a story we've heard so often that we perhaps take it for granted, seeing all the events of this remarkable journey laid out for us in a two-hour and 21-minute feature underlines its not-to-be-believed qualities.
Acerbic, emotional, provocative, it's a risky high dive off the big board with a plot that sounds like a gimmick but ends up haunting, odd and a bit wonderful.
Dizzying, outlandishly entertaining ...
An ambitious and provocative piece of work that is intriguingly balanced between being a warning and a celebration.
The Ref benefits from having actor's actors like Davis and Spacey in the leads.
Lean, muscular and on the money, The Last Days on Mars takes a familiar story and tells it so tautly that we are pleased to be on board.

In addition to everything else, "Inside Llewyn Davis" is very much a roman à clef about those early folk years, with many of its characters inspired by real people the Coens reconstitute after viewing them through their very particular lens.

Part avant-garde art film, part amusing but morbid fairy tale, it is a delightfully ghoulish holiday musical that displays more inventiveness in its brief 75 minutes than some studios can manage in an entire year.

The most memorable thing about Sweet Dreams is that it allows us to experience the resilience, the capacity for happiness these women retain in spite of all they've been through. There's a lesson there for all of us.
"The Great Beauty" is drop-dead gorgeous, a film that is luxuriously, seductively, stunningly cinematic.

Can an ogre live happily ever after? Can fairy tale characters be content with their fairy tale lives? Can an Oscar-winning animated success generate a successful sequel? To all these questions, Shrek 2 is happy to answer yes, yes and yes.
This dispassionate but devastating film looks at the drug wars from two very different but chillingly complementary perspectives.

Lawrence ... thrives here, but even her skill and determination can't stabilize a film that goes off in any number of directions and rarely feels confident about the kind of story it wants to be telling.
It's the majesty and beauty of water at its most pure that stays with us longest.
Despite its age it's that rare science fiction film that doesn't seem to have dated at all.
It marries ferocious, unnerving violence and waves of profanity to powerful, psychologically acute performances in a way that is intensely dramatic as well as almost unbearable to watch at times.
Incident at Oglala is an even-handed cry of outrage, a coolly passionate documentary that focuses a piercing ray of light on an American scandal.

"My Old Lady" certainly has satisfactions, but they are incomplete ones.
While "The Drop" has an enviable feeling for the dark end of the street, the kind of across-the-board success it's seeking remains just out of reach.
Though it's set in the context of a highly combustible international situation, its emphasis is always on the personal, on these two men and what they came to mean to each other.
"A Walk Among the Tombstones" is the creepiest film I've seen in quite some time, and that's not meant as a compliment.

Sometimes the stories we think we know, the stories where we don't want to hear another word, turn out to be the most involving of all, the ones we in fact know the least about. So it is with "Last Days in Vietnam."
"Life's a Breeze" is a small film with a considerable amount of charm. Comic and idiosyncratic, it takes a warmhearted view toward its protagonists while still seeing them for exactly who they are.
A tense thriller that also has more on its mind than the familiar genre constraints it operates under.
None of Jimi Hendrix's classic music found its way into "Jimi: All Is By My Side," but that doesn't hurt this moody, mesmerizing film one bit.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Pride" is an unapologetic crowd-pleaser of a movie, but it has some potent points to make, and the reality of what happened has a power of its own.
"Gone Girl" shows the remarkable things that can happen when filmmaker and material are this well matched.

Blessed with a loose, anarchic B-picture soul that encourages you to enjoy yourself even when you're not quite sure what's going on, the scruffy Guardians is irreverent in a way that can bring the first Star Wars to mind.
A striking example of Japanese hand-drawn animation, it casually combines things you wouldn't expect in one place.
A small-scale gem of a movie, both dramatically aware and psychologically astute.
Duvall and Downey create a memorable mutual antipathy with echoes that go back as far as Raymond Massey squaring off against James Dean in "East of Eden."
If memorable war movies mean something to you, open that book to a new page and add "Fury" to the list. It belongs there.
Starring a trio of top male actors in splendid roles, the intricate, intimate "Felony" is a police story crossed with a perceptive psychological drama.
"The Tale of the Princess Kaguya" is a marvel of Japanese animation, a hand-drawn, painterly epic that submerges us in a world of beauty.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The director's form of genial cinematic dementia is guaranteed not to be to all tastes at all times, but those who are looking for something strange and different will feel right at home.

Carping about as significant a film as "Citizenfour" feels beside the point. You can wish its faults didn't exist, but it does a real service in detailing what the scary consequences of those NSA actions could be.

A great deal of the fun of watching this very assured film is seeing with what energetic panache the actor takes on the mantle of the mobster J. Edgar Hoover once called "the most dangerous man in America."

A smart, engaged film powered by an altogether remarkable performance by Jake Gyllenhaal, it is melodrama grounded in a disturbing reality, an extreme scenario that is troubling because it cuts close to the bone.
As adroitly written and directed by Sweden's Ruben Ostlund, "Force Majeure" is a precise film about an out-of-control situation.
A lovely film that brings great emotion and a dead-on feeling for time, place and recaptured mood to a story that is as universal as it is personal.
It's a mass audience picture that's intelligent as well as epic, with a sophisticated script that's as interested in emotional moments as immersive visuals. Which is saying a lot.
It's quite a triumph for Diplomacy in general and Schlöndorff's pinpoint filmmaking in particular to involve us as thoroughly as it does in the ebb and flow of their compelling conversation.
Redmayne and Jones are beautifully compatible as Hawking and his then-wife Jane as they navigate the ebb and flow of 25 years of their relationship.
"Le Jour Se Leve" is an exploration of the question of who we love and why and how we love them that is surprisingly fresh and involving.
The Supreme Price may sound like a metaphorical title, but after seeing this strong, forthright documentary, you'll understand it's the literal truth.
"Life of Crime" has the authentic Leonard snap, crackle and pop.

Odd, offbeat, somehow endearing, the bleakly comic "Frank" has its own kind of charm as well as some pointed, poignant things to say about the mysterious nature of creativity, where it comes from and where it might all go.
"If I Stay" shuttles between lachrymose developments at the hospital and a series of flashbacks that detail the Mia-Adam relationship. Not surprisingly, the romance is where you want to be.
While the makers of Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves may have set out to bury the poor old duffer of Sherwood Forest in a welter of trendy banter, they have ended up burying themselves as well.

Its preoccupation with snazzy computer-generated special effects has left key plot points so unclear at least one baffled viewer had to retreat to the book to find out why some things happened and others did not.
A brisk and familiar courtroom drama of the old school, as pleasant to watch as it is predictable, Men more than anything else is a tribute to pure star power.
It is Trzebuchowska's face, and her character's situation, her existential and practical journey, that hold our interest in "Ida."
It deals lightly with topics like ego, friendship, rivalry and love, and it does so within the context of an exploration of the personal and professional lives of a pair of actors.
It's that rare film that captures and conveys the romance of the theatrical experience.
movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You can see the stuff "Million Dollar Arm" throws at you from miles away, but that doesn't stop this baseball movie from being genially enjoyable.
Holding all these elements together is Van Sant's sensibility, such an elusive thing it instinctively squirms away from any attempt to pigeonhole it.
It's a star-driven mass-market entertainment that's smart, exciting and unexpected while not stinting on genre satisfactions.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A thoroughly engaging documentary ...
If you're considering college for your children or are just a concerned citizen, this comprehensive documentary gives you a lot to ponder.
A film shot in 100-degree-plus heat that chills the blood as well as the soul.

No one expects movies like this one, set as it is in the largely mythological world of fiercely competitive daily newspapering, to be realistic. But neither should they be as flaccid and unconvincing as what we are presented with here.
Eastwood, as always, has simply done things his own way, and the result is a leisurely old-school entertainment with a bit more edge than you may be expecting.
A more sophisticated work than it appears about a man whose life was more complicated than the world knew.
A moving documentary that will leave you heartsick as well as more than a little angry.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Just when you are ready to completely write off "Begin Again," the music starts to play, the camera takes it all in and makes us a part of it, and the film's unpersuasive emotions don't seem to matter as much.

The fate of some very old bones may not sound like compelling cinema, but when they compose the 65-million-year-old skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex that was 41 feet long and 18 feet high back in the day, all bets are off.
A kind of ho-hum experience, wherein a lot of bullets are expended and a lot of structures exploded to minimal dramatic effect.

It's no spoiler to reveal that these tornadoes just happen to be the biggest storms that ever were, and watching them chew up buildings like they were so many corn bread muffins can't help but be involving.
If there is room for romantic fantasy in your life, this cinematic equivalent of comfort food goes down easy enough, and it's hard to begrudge it that.

In a world drowning in bad news about dementia - an estimated 5 million Americans currently suffer, 10 million serve as their caregivers, with both numbers inevitably going up - "Alive Inside" is positively tonic.
"Get on Up" is more frustrating than fulfilling, a disjointed film that suffers from having a more ambitious plan than it's got the ability to execute.
It sounds contrived, and it is. It sounds like a bit of a stunt, and it is that too. It may even sound boring, but that it is not.
Part philosophical/scientific treatise, part action movie, a film that goes from mayhem to boredom in a heartbeat.
Though the relentlessness of the on-screen antics threatens to wear you out, the film is over before that can quite happen.
What this Disney feature lacks in the title department it makes up for with fluid visuals and fast-moving action of the, yes, firefighting variety.
Astute, unhurried and gently amusing, it will be welcomed by the director's fans while serving as a fine introduction for those who know him not.

"Dawn's" vision of masses of intelligent apes swarming the screen as masters of all they survey is even more impressive than it was the last time around and reason enough to see the film all by itself.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's another mark of the director's skill that he took me deeper into aspects of that life that I thought I knew the most about.
"Manakamana" is simple in conception, but the reactions it evokes in viewers will be complex and multifaceted.
[A] crackerjack thriller, at once brooding, claustrophobic and unbearably tense ...
"The Missing Picture" is personal and unexpected, a documentary that mixes media in an unusual way to very potent effect.
Landesman has pushed too hard to make this story fit into a dramatic mold, alternating melodrama and romance with those earnest warnings in a way that is more ungainly than effective.
The film wants us to feel, as one of the men they protect says, "I'm proud to know Americans like you," but we're never really given the opportunity.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not every day that you end up rooting for a bank, but the story "Abacus: Small Enough to Jail" tells is no ordinary tale.

The thrilling documentary "Dawson City: Frozen Time" is indescribable not because it's ambiguous (it's totally straightforward) but because it does so many things so beautifully it is hard to know where to begin.

This warmly sentimental G-rated film about facing new realities and recapturing lost dreams has, despite its relatively adult story line, a beguilingly effortless feeling to it, as if it had nothing to prove.
A movie that allows its actors to fully inhabit their characters in a potent but low-key way.
A passionate, opinionated, drop-dead fascinating documentary essay about that country's film history put together by a clear-eyed enthusiast who was born to tell the tale.
movie_title: My Journey Through French Cinema (Voyage À Travers Le Cinéma Français) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A tense psychological thriller whose twisty plot benefits from a bravura performance by Emmanuelle Devos.
A remarkable documentary that paradoxically proves that when it comes to silence, there is a lot to be said as well as a great deal to be shown.
Tells a fascinating but inevitably grim story, both more interesting and more downbeat than one might anticipate.
Persuasive rather than polemical, it's the unusual issue film that deals in counterintuitive reason rather than barely controlled hysteria.
Against considerable odds, "Spider-Man: Homecoming" finds its pace and rhythm by the end.
Music documentaries are thick on the land, and political ones are numerous as well, but "Mali Blues" is different in that it artfully combines hypnotic music with definite societal concerns.
This may not be exact history, but it certainly makes an impression.
Exact and exacting, made with formidable skill and unwavering focus, "Lady Macbeth" is a film that demands to be admired and cares little if you actually like it.

Part of what makes "City of Ghosts" compelling is a chance to view disturbing footage of ISIS atrocities, clandestinely shot with cellphones and so revealing and incendiary the videoers faced death if captured.
"The Mummy" is trying to do so many different things, has so many different reasons for being (not to mention so many screenwriters), that a kind of narrative chaos is the all but inevitable result.
"Chasing Coral" presents the evidence with beauty, intelligence and a surprising amount of emotion.

Imagine Buster Keaton crossed with David Lynch, with a bit of Billy Wilder satire tossed into the mix, and you'll have a rough idea of the wild and crazy tightrope 1963's absurdist "Il Boom" manages to walk.
Frozen River asks is how much that communality will mean in the context of an uncaring, unforgiving world. It is a powerful question, and the film answers it in the best way possible.
[An] involving and unexpectedly passionate film ...
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Santoalla" is really concerned with cultures in collision, with what happens when dreams of paradise clash, good intentions become unhinged and the darker angels of our nature gain the upper hand.
It's a gentle, melancholy father-and-son story that's as notable for an evocation of its self-contained world as it is for its drama.
Heartening and unashamedly emotional, it's a certified crowd pleaser that doesn't care who knows it.
This tense, convincing independent film is the most accomplished violent thriller in quite some time.
Languages have magic - dead or dying ones most of all - and some of that sorcery has made it onto the screen in the evocatively titled Mexican feature "I Dream in Another Language."
movie_title: I Dream in Another Language (Sueño en otro idioma) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Harrelson ... thoroughly understands Rex from the inside, immersing himself in the role of this charismatic man in a way that allows us to see both how compelling and how dangerous a parent he was.
"Escapes" is as unconventional as its subject, demonstrating the charming things that can happen when a life in no way ordinary gets documented by a filmmaker most unusual.
Suzu's story becomes so deeply personal that when an animated hand waves at the audience at the film's conclusion, we will feel like waving back, like we would to a friend.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Backdraft truly shows us fire the way we've never seen it before.
If it verges on being a little too pleased with itself for its own good, that's an acceptable price to pay for something that makes you smile.
"Whitney's" story makes for strong and compelling viewing even though it has something of a cobbled together feel to it.
An engaging documentary ...
movie_title: Midnight Return: The Story of Billy Hayes and Turkey (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman" is an involving film that tells a more complicated story than its unexciting title would indicate.
Not only a triumphant exercise in dark and delicious romantic ambiguity, the pitfalls of being taken in are what this melodramatic thriller is all about.
"Past Life" is straight-ahead filmmaking heightened by a connection to a pervasive Israeli reality not often found on film.
It wants its stand-alone story of Wolverine and Professor Xavier to be taken seriously as authentic drama. And, to a surprising extent, it succeeds.

Nehama, who grew up in an Orthodox Jerusalem community like the one in the film, has said her goal was "to tell the story of the moderate people who are forced to deal with growing religious extremism," and "The Women's Balcony" definitely does that.
As its name suggests, "Keep Quiet" is a somber, careful documentary, but despite its measured tone its subject matter is wall to wall disturbing.
Story and soul are never going to be kings on Skull Island, but they could have fared better than this.

In a political climate in which all things progressive are at risk, the film is a reminder of the long and difficult work that victory took as well as a notification that no triumph can be taken for granted.

At times haphazard but always involving ...

Belief begets belief, and the faith that star Jessica Chastain and director Niki Caro have in "The Zookeeper's Wife" turn this World War II drama into an emotional experience that is straight-ahead but satisfying.

[The film] surprises us on several levels. It reveals Egypt's familiar Arab Spring experience through a lens, that of satiric comedy, which is very different from the way we usually see it. And it has the personal element of Youssef's involving story.

movie_review_blurb: "Legion of Brothers" is a story of heroism writ bold, but it is also something more.
"Justice" is as relevant today as when it came out, if not more so.
It sounds paradoxical but, if done right, films about a life ending can be the most life-affirming films you'll see. "Truman," a great success in its native Spain, is definitely done right.
The strength of "Let It Fall" is in its remarkable contemporary interviews, compelling both for the people recorded and the way the conversations are allowed to unfold.
Gives a full sense of the anarchy and rage of the post-King verdict days, thrusting us fully and disturbingly into events in very much of a You Are There manner.
A documentary understandably in awe of its subject, a film that finally fascinates despite some initial bumps in the road.

"The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Maki" is a lovely piece of work, a sweet, warmly observed tale overlaid with just the right amount of Scandinavian melancholy, a combination that perfectly suits its quietly engaging protagonist.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With a title that sounds standard but turns out to be specific, "One Week and a Day" keeps an impeccable balance between absurdity and sadness, comedy and heartbreak.
movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone seeking a demonstration of how completely orthodoxy and heresy can change places need look no further than the brisk documentary "Citizen Jane: Battle for the City."

movie_review_blurb: Though individually and as a group the Guardians don't do anything they didn't do in the first film, "Vol. 2's" insistence on hitting everything twice as hard soon becomes wearing.

The people brought to life here, using a combination of the written obituary and news clips, are a varied and fascinating bunch.
More interesting than you might imagine. But not interesting enough.
An assured, nervy black satire on America's involvement in Afghanistan and on one particular soldier, commander of U.S. forces and four-star Gen. Glen McMahon, a.k.a. Big Glen or the Glenimal.

movie_title: Spirit Game: Pride of a Nation (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A handsomely mounted World War II-era romantic thriller, enlivened by vibrant performances and vivid sexual encounters and inspired by a little-known footnote to history, the story of a ruler who left but never went away.

One hell of a wild ride, a Twilight of the Gods that takes no prisoners and leaves audiences desperate for mercy.

Simple, powerful, made with conviction and skill, "1945" proceeds as inexorably as Sámuel and his son on their long walk into town.

movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Magical, thrilling and romantic to the core, a sensual and fantastical fairy tale with moral overtones, it's a film that plays by all the rules and none of them, going its own way with fierce abandon.
No matter what you're expecting, "Foxtrot" is not the film you expect it to be. It's better.

What makes "Bombshell" intriguing is not just Lamarr's gift for invention, it's also what a fiery individualist she was, someone who had no regrets about her eventful life ("You learn from everything"), not even its racy, tabloid elements.
This is a satisfying indie western, a dark and brooding film made with both a modern touch and real love for the genre.
Propulsive major studio cinema made with a real-world purpose in mind, it's a risky venture that succeeds across the board.
A tale of physical, emotional and even moral survival, "Hostiles" deals in people pushed to their limits and then some, individuals marked in the deepest way by the violence of the frontier.

movie_review_blurb: Akin was inspired to tell the story by real-life political events in Germany, and his skills as a filmmaker are such that escape from this unsettling film is not in the cards.

movie_review_blurb: An austere poem of crime, Le Samourai manages to have a grip of an old-fashioned potboiler as well. Not a half-bad combination.

The Late Show has the grace to allow us to see the craft and competence that remains in [Wells].
Rollercoaster, slambang title notwithstanding, is a singularly tepid piece of work, so dull not even Sensurround can keep you fully awake.
It's Neeson Time, and it's not in the man to let us down.
Undercut by an air of self-congratulatory pomposity that the film is way too insubstantial to support.
We didn't know we'd been yearning for it until it arrived, but now that it's here it's unmistakable that the wait for a film like "Black Panther" has been way longer than it should have been.
A single act of heroism can truly transform a life, but that action does not necessarily make for a transformative motion picture.
The film allows us, at least to a certain extent, to get behind the public persona to the private person.
If just hearing animator Nick Park's name doesn't bring an anticipatory smile to your face, watching a few minutes of the thoroughly amusing "Early Man" will do the trick.
Against all expectations, "Young Karl Marx" makes this kind of brainy content bracing and dramatic.

Because of his long friendship with Hondros, director Campbell has gotten key people on camera ...

Even if some things have changed, spending time with an artist who's concerned, as he's said in interviews, with "the permanence of temporary objects and the temporality of permanent objects," is always worth the journey.
Thorough, impressive and smartly put together, joining dynamically edited verite footage with a series of thoughtful interviews, "Breaking Point" serves a pair of interlocking purposes.
movie_title: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Korty is sensitive in the best sense.

What elevates "Lange" is its wide range of idiosyncratic, delightful characters, its belief in humanity in all its crazy variety, and its abundance of high spirits and raffish charm that are absolutely contagious.
movie_title: The Crime of Monsieur Lange (Le Crime de Monsieur Lange) (1936)

movie_review_blurb: Though the level of acting is uniformly quite high, the true star of The Best Intentions is Bergman's script.

"The Teacher" benefits not only from filmmakers who join a multifaceted understanding of human nature with a fastidious control of technique and style, but also from being set in a particular time and place.

Though this story couldn't mean more to Jolie, she hasn't been able to make it mean as much to us.

movie_review_blurb: Made with care and conviction as it explores this unexpected relationship, "Our Souls at Night" understands both what changes in people as they age and what remains the same.

movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

Because the series' plot reveal turns out to be more confusing than compelling, and because turning a novel into two films invariably leads to inflated productions, only the most devoted fans of the book will pledge allegiance to what's on the screen.

A smart and thoughtful examination of who the man was and how he got that way.

A film essay that's powerfully and painfully relevant today even though its subject died almost 30 years ago.

A sweet date-night movie about a date that wasn't really a date. Until it was.

movie_review_blurb: Honest, direct and dramatic without any sense of special pleading or situations pushed too hard.

movie_review_blurb: "Moonlight" is magic.

This is a popular entertainment with a knockout punch so intense and unnerving it'll have you worrying if it's safe to close your eyes at night.

An exquisite chamber piece made with the kind of sensitivity and nuance that's become almost a lost art.

A lively, easygoing farce filled with high-energy music and amusing complications.

As sequels go, this one is acceptable, nothing more, nothing less.

More than a keenly dramatic look at how this country treats the poor and dispossessed. It's also a film that was hijacked by its subjects. They saw an opportunity, they took it, and the grand jury prize at Sundance was the result.

A cinéma vérité look at the rootless Native American community that once upon a time lived in Bunker Hill and hung out in downtown bars such as Club Ritz, this Kent Mackenzie film is a brooding picture of a darkly beautiful, long-gone Los Angeles.
